Interesting game. I feel it mixes mmorpg and real time fighting like Tekken. 
At first, it's kind of overwhelming, there is a lot of items( long item descriptions...) and shiny things on the screen. 
First thing to do would be main quest. There are several path you can take to to get too bored when remaking a character. 
Season servers help you grind faster to get to the endgame content and try several classes without spending weeks on the xp. You don't have to only grind, tho, because the game has a LOT to do. 

It's one of the main thing that got me to stay and play every weeks.
- You can explore, do local quests which have many types. 
- You can talk to ncp and get friendship with them with a mini game. This requires to talk to ncp anytime you encounter a new one. I believe it can unlock functions or items to buy/sales on their items but I never delve too much on this part because I don't really like the mini game. 
- You can do pretty much any type of life work you can imagine in an mmo. Fishing, cutting wood, grass, have a house(can furnish and craft furniture) and a garden. You can cook, do alchemy in a very complicated looking but very cool way.
-This also has a management side to it where you buy houses in cities, transform them into workshop. You then buy or make equipment to place there so they can go gather and craft items (some are workers only perhaps? im not an expert)
It's a bit long to learn or get into but very fun.
-There is a lot of quality of life stuff that are cool like autopathing to quest locations (you will still have to look for some stuff yourself and it is slower than running manually on a horse), stuff to do while autopathing (little mini games or reading)
-I never participate in community stuff but I enjoy doing lifeskills in my corner and the fact it's a one time buy is very advantageous for poor me.

Is the game good in 2024? 

It's practically one of the horsemen of the apocalypse In my book when it comes to setting a high-bar for the next generation of MMORPGs, Because of BDO's amazing graphics and Insane combat system its easily one of MY personal favorite games of all time. Yes it has its flaws but I learned trying out a lot of new MMORPGs
that they can't deliver the amount of things BDO had to offer me as a MMORPG. it was truly amazing for me the first day I logged in.

Customization is Good and the Classes are good, although gender locked. It still has a variety of choices for both sides. On top of a open world there's various different mounts and things to traverse the world so you don't seem like you're going to point A to point B in a trip of 20 minutes afk'ing auto-path'ing. 

Costumes and Glamouring Accessories ingame? 

The game has a lot of costumes inside it's game shop, But don't let that discourage you, there is alternative ways to get costumes from players who post them inside the in-game marketboard, You can place a order of the item you desire and it will be(although might take some time) it will be sold eventually to you. There's also seasonal rewards and events where they give away some sets of costumes. This is what I know so far from some players who have managed to secure a costume they wanted.

The storyline is Chaotic?

BDO definitely has its own lure and it's own world story developing around the creatures and lands you explore. I found myself doing storyline quest, simply because it gives me something to do alone when I'm done grinding or I'm just finding something to do in the game that isn't PVP. For some, The story hits, and for some the story is just "there..." In my though its got some scenes fully voice acted and animated compared to HOW BDO STARTED? i'll take this over the OLD-bdo story-telling. the renewing was from Bronze to golden quality in my opinion. 


Overall Experience: 

In 2024... I simply feel like there's nothing out there like this yet? but at the same time, relief the game is actually improving the way that it is since I started playing it. It simply makes it hard to quit a good game that doesn't lets new generation over-take their MMO,  Just like ESO and FFXIV and WoW, there's a game for everyone out there, and who knows if this one is just the game for you ?
if you want a game that will last you years to come black desert is one of those games that always has you somthing to do that said its allso a grind fest so no easey ways to get max Gear score quick

Almost 400 hours into this game and majority of those hours have been accumulated during times that I played and stopped over time, so I'm going to give an honest review of the game to the average new player. Be aware that this is a game where classes are Gender locked because "S.E.X. sells" and Pearl Abyss isn't changing that anytime soon. Currently there are 9 male classes and 18 female classes making it a 1:2 ratio.

Let's start from the top with just my thoughts from playing, and just recently I started to invest a lot of time in the game and take it seriously. This game is not a game that holds your hands like you'd expect from World of Warcraft, FFXIV, New World, etc. This is a game of trial and error, you *WILL* get confused, you *WILL* have to learn combos, you *WILL* have to invest a lot of hours before you're remotely ready for "End-game". You will be left to yourself to learn just about everything unless you ask the community on what you should and should not do. The tutorial is hardly a tutorial, it gives you the general idea of how "some" combat works. 

Starting out, you're going to be putting in some time choosing what class best suits you, and no two classes are alike (except for a few like Witch and Wizard, Kunoichi and Ninja, Musa and Maehwa, which you can expect those classes to have very similar performance.) After the creation of your character (which for new players I highly recommend playing as a Seasonal character and start catching up to early end-game. After the completion of your Seasonal character, then begins the endless grind. Do not expect a lot of group content, for the most part this is a single-person experience, however there are some group content like PvP, and some bosses. Don't expect the kind of experience you had from New World, WoW, FFXIV-- throw most of those expectations out the window.

In all realism, this game is for those who want a long-term experience, and players who got a niche for Mortal Kombat-esque games that got a dash of MMORPG elements to it.

Pros:
Great game to sink hours of game-time into
You're not frantically gearing up for Raid nights
No Mythic+ system
No dicey expansions
It's $10 when not on sale
The endgame experience is what YOU choose.

Cons:
Classes are Gender Locked.
It takes ages to get top tier armor
You're going to be FIENDIN' for some CRONS.
You may develop arthritis or Carpal Tunnel Syndrome for button smashing: SHIFT, W, E, F, X, C, Z, Q, A, S, D.
You'll slowly forget you have a family outside of BDO.
WHY AREN'T OUTFITS JUST FAMILY BOUND IF I CAN GET THAT OUTFIT ON ANOTHER CHARACTER?!?!?!?!?!?!

I stopped playing Black Desert Online not long ago, around the time of that infamous transfer email everyone was talking about. Honestly, I didn't think much of it at the time. Why would I? Who expects to lose their entire account just because they miss an email...

Fast forward to today, and guess what? I tried to log in, and boom - account's gone. Apparently, that transfer window was real, and I completely missed it. Now, I'm left wondering: Is it really too much to ask for companies to clearly communicate critical information and give players a reasonable timeframe to take action? Especially when we're talking about accounts potentially worth hundreds or even thousands of dollars?

This whole situation honestly feels like a slap in the face to loyal players like me. Black Desert, seriously, where's the concern for your customers? When is losing everything supposed to be our problem?

This review isn't just about my own frustration, but about raising awareness for others who might be in the same boat. Think twice before hitting that "dismiss" button on any important-sounding email from BDO, folks. And Black Desert, for the love of your player base, do better next time.  So when did it become a concern to bdo about making this important and do the auto transfer? when they only spent a few bucks or maybe couple hundred what about a couple $#@ thousand?   Oh I made purchases before steam and when  I connected bdo to steam .. Unfair Contractual Terms but hey dont matter they didnt xfer in time so we win and they will want to play again and spend more money.. run away trust me after seeing people having their account banned for pretending to  use a macro.. lol  or not paying attention to bdo e-mails .. yeah

--------------------------------
the scenery, some graphics, and environments look nice, characters and classes have cool abilities and great combat potential
but, most AI and monsters you face in the game have little to no variety, especially in their attacks, they just take hits and bonk you, with the only difficulty being in the health and damage differences between levels

even with the variety of skills your character could use for great combat against difficult enemies, it doesn't matter, because you can just spam any attack or AoE skill at a group of mindless mobs (nearly all the enemies in the game)

although the environments look nice from a distance, the level design is terrible, with either large empty spaces for the levels, or just big boxes lacking detail and a few with rocks or chairs
everything you encounter in the wilderness will either be a plain filled with mobs, a forest filled with mobs, a camp filled with mobs, or a cave filled with mobs, etc, with nothing else relevant to gameplay, environment, or level design to make it fun or interesting to explore and play.
when the environments and levels are somewhat well-developed, having some cool mechanics, like in some of the few dungeon areas, the MMO component ruins them with other players clearing the dungeons and completing puzzles either for you, or at the exact same time as you

PvP is unplayable in oceania, no servers, really aids latency

the soundtrack is okay, but each region just has a loop of the same repetitive tracks

the short storyline not only has terrible missions and writing, a repeat of 'interact with X npcs', 'kill Y mindless mobs in this area', it has stayed the exact same (with little to no new missions, lore, anything) for ages, and you usually have to replay the entire thing across all of your characters

isn't even too fun with friends, as the only thing you can really do together is try to manage the jank and complete ur story missions at the EXACT same time and order, or mindlessly kill mindless mobs together for quicker mindless grinding

at this point, the game is practically a walking, grinding, and lifeskilling sim to level up and drip out your characters and their fishing skills for literally no reason
--------------------------------
unless you're into watching paint dry and/or gathering water in a stream, exploring big empty open areas, watching someone automatically fish, or watching your character hit a rock/tree all day until you run out of stamina (which you need to grind or pay to increase) or something, this game is pretty fucking terrible, especially long-term



TLDR: sh*t, gets old fast -- clock out, play lost ark

The entire game is a grinding simulator, some people like that but when it takes hundreds of hours to make minuscule progress it gets quite bleak. 

The game is very micro transaction heavy and does its utmost to make you buy things (honestly worse than most mobile games) and the enhancement system is obviously rigged. 

The fan boys will tell you intro level understanding of probability but anyone who has taken an actual class on it will know that items with a 56% chance of success simply do not fail 10+ times, plus they monetize the items around the enhancement system (in other words their incentive is to make you fail over and over again.) Hey there, fellow adventurers! Let's dive into the wild world of Black Desert, where you can ride on anything from horses to llamas and even camels. This game's got it all: PvP fights for the brave and life skills for those who prefer a more chill vibe. Personally, I'm all about those life skills—they keep me busy in the best way possible!

Graphics:
Picture this: you can tweak the graphics to fit your PC setup like a glove. Whether you're rocking a fancy rig or an old laptop from the prehistoric era, Black Desert adapts like magic. So, no matter your setup, you're in for a visually stunning ride!

Gameplay:
Black Desert serves up a double dose of fun with its PvP showdowns and laid-back life skills. From fishing to farming, there's never a dull moment. Sure, mastering everything takes time, but hey, it's all part of the adventure, right?

Microtransactions:
Now, let's talk cash. Some folks think Black Desert is pay-to-win, but that's just a myth. You can splurge on fashion for your character, but you can't buy your way to victory. The in-game store is more about convenience than giving you an unfair advantage.

Support and Community:
Need a hand? The game's support team is on it like a wizard with a spell book. They'll help you out, even if you've done something silly (we've all been there!). Plus, there are tons of YouTube videos and guides to help you on your journey. As someone who spends a lot of time at home, Black Desert has been a lifesaver, bringing me into a world full of adventure and friendship.

Conclusion:
In the land of Black Desert, where time flies faster than a magic carpet, I give this game a solid 10 out of 10! It's addictive, it's fun, and it's a whole new world waiting to be explored. So saddle up, friends, and let's ride into the sunset together!

My experience with this game has been mostly positive, but there are definitely a lot of things the game still needs to improve. The new player experience is (still) very confusing and difficult to get through without any help. Hell, even just picking a class to start with is daunting bc the game does a crap job of explaining how each class works or feels to play. I highly recommend looking up class picking guides. Blue Squadron on YouTube has a whole "choose your class" series that helped me through that process.

Don't get me wrong. The game has a whole host of problems it needs to work on, most of them centering around the game being able to explain itself to the player without the aid of outside help. That said, this game is also a lot of fun. I find myself coming back once a year just to give it another fair shot bc I know it has potential. I fell off of this game a lot in the past, and I can't say for sure that I won't fall off again. But I still think the experience of playing this game was worth it regardless. The combo system if a combat system that you really don't see often / at all in other MMO titles, and BDO did a fantastic job implementing it in their game. Even on Succession Nova (frequently toted as the worst class to play in the game. Not to be confused with Awakening Nova, toted as one of / the best classes for pvp / pve.), I feel the power and complexity of the combat engine on a visceral level. Pulling off your class's combos feels compelling and powerful. In short, it just feels good to play the game.

Where the game falls short in this respect is the absurd amount of non-gameplay things you are basically forced to do in order to fully unlock the actual gameplay. For example, you essentially unlock a whole new and unique style of combat for you character once you awaken them, but you're also not able to test out your new abilities very much unless you stop following the main story line (typically because you're over-leveled and one-shotting every enemy rather than actually having to use your combos). And even then, shortly after awakening you discover a new quest line that everyone essentially has to do in order to unlock the game's fast-travel system. The sad part is that this quest line is substantially long and has little to no combat to speak of, meaning you end up feeling like you're doing your chores almost immediately after the game hands you a brand new toy that you would rather be playing with instead.

Man, reading this makes me feel like I should NOT recommend the game, but I promise it is worth playing. It requires you (the player) to put in a lot of work in order to enjoy it. But I guarantee that it's worth it. That said, if you aren't patient then you may just want to skip this one.

Love this game, I quit back in the day w/ BDO when they implemented xigncode, and after years many years, they finally removed the stupid anti-cheat, so I got back on the moment they took it off, and played it with friends.  Been putting in tons of hours, even in a Guild I like and love, however I quit again...Why?

They re-implemented Xigncode again.  Why?  No idea but idiocy on their part.  Uninstalled the game as soon as I could and guess what?  Xigncode is STILL in my PC just like how it was back in the day.

I had to manually uninstall it once again, for why in the world would an anti-cheat continue to linger on even after the game that it was implemented for is no longer in my 
 pc anymore?  

It scans your ENTIRE PC, going through all of your folders, data, info (remember that an Anti-cheat should NOT be doing this in the first place) and sends them to who knows where, and considering that this anti-cheat is made by a Chinese company with connections to the CCP, well, let's just say I'm not stupid, and I couldn't hit the uninstall fast enough.

Sad really, since I love BDO (my hours prove it!) but not enough for it to keep xigncode running around in my PC.  

GGs BDO, since this will be the last time I play the game either until they remove again, or I will have transitioned to another game that doesn't run xigncode.

After 5.5k hours of gameplay, I would NOT recommend BDO to anyone.

The main reasons are:

1) P2W; BDO's sales strategy is designed around making you purchase items or feel worse about playing without them.

2) Toxic community; after LoL, this is probably the most toxic community I have met in my 20 years of gaming. Most of the community has spent so much money on BDO that they will DO ANYTHING to justify their purchase. 

3) 15vs15 uncapped(gear score) Guild Vs Guild; the nail in the coffin and the end for me. Progression is everything in BDO; a difference of 30 in GS can swing the tides and the top payers are always ahead. What's the point of competing when there's no fair competition?

Minimum you will have to spend if you want t4 pets and a tent is about 500$ if you have the base game but with the conqueror edition you only have to spend about 150$. Endgame is the same as early and mid game, just brainless grinding but in different zones, so play at your own pace to not get burnt out.

I've played an additional 2138 Hours since my original review.  
BDO still has the worst PvP I've ever seen in an MMO.  PvP just devolves in to getting your opponent stuck in a stun lock situation where they can't response.  You still can't tell where attacks are coming from 99% of the time.  THere are a lot of times I can see my character getting hit but I can't even tell where the attack is coming from.   When I can Its already to late.  You essentially have to come up with an infinite combo that exploits your classes protections and be using them.  Essentially,  you are punching the air to keep your protections up.  Your opponent is doing the same.  And its all about which character has a gap in their defense first.  

PvE has gotten better with the inclusion of season play.   You can get a decently geared character ready to farm for the things you need.  Leveling itself is not a grind anymore.  Even without being Power leveled you can get to level 60 pretty quick.  

But really,  there is no substance there.   You go to one area run pack to pack blowing them up collecting the loot until you get the thing you want.  Then you go to the next spot to farm different monsters which might as well just be reskined version of what you have already been killing.  The content itself is not challenging.  It basically devolves in to a yes or no where or not you can kill it.  Its all gear based.  You can certainly skill your way through some spots but the grind becomes so inefficient that it is not worth your time.  

This game really really needs instanced 5/10 man raid content.   Currently,  there are very few reasons in PvE to actually group.  You will spent 99% of your time solo.  Even when you find 'group' content it still feels like you are solo along with a bunch of other people who are soloing.  

Overall,  the PvP is shallow and the PvE is shallow.  Its basically all paced in such a way that you always 'have something you could do'  but its basically the same thing.  go here kills 100000 mobs until you collect 100 of something then go to another location and kill things to collect 100 of something.  Same mechanic everywhere.  

They say the game is 'sandbox'.  It doesn't feel sandbox.  It feels like a solo game with other people running around doing solo things. 


Original:
Worst PvP I have ever seen in a MMO.  There is so much Crowd Control (CC) and Area of Effect (AoE) going on that basically it just devolves in to spamming your AoE abilities...stupid thing is that nearly all abilities have some sort of CC effect attached to them.  The contra to this abilities gives you some sort of invulnerability.  

PvP is about trying to CC your opponent and avoid being CC'd at the same time.  

PvE is just there to support PvP.  If you don't want to PvP then there is no real reason to play this game...becaues PvP will come your way either way.  

The game isn't P2W...You can't pay any sum of money and come out ahead of other players.  The items on convenience items that be obtained in game.  It is either time spent or money spent...You are still going to have to grind levels and gear.  Which give you the same 'buffs' you can pay for in the shop.  

PvP is hand down the worst I've ever seen.  I regret buying this game.  

Its really only popular because of the fact that if you out gear people you win.  Skill isn't required.  

If its not the CC kicking your ass its the gear.  If its not those two things then its the prolific amount of RNG in the game.

BDO is an evolved Hack'n'Slash in a full PVPVE game.  This game is really hardcore playing oriented (and quite always "solo surrounded by other players"). Everything is here hard to obtein : casual players, be prepared for pain. 

CashShop is expensive and can become a dangerous slot machine (ex : horsing resets for coursier : you buy tokens just "to try again" not "to success"). 
Quests are "not uninteresting" but PVE is quite always grinding against packs of mobs. PVP promotes hardcore players in endgame/specific gears, can be practiced anywhere or on specific BG/wars.  Toxicity, free ganking (mostly in low level zones or against weak/AFK players), and no "friendly playing" anywhere resume global social environment (you'll be ignore, pushed to get away, or loop attacked/killed for no reason). 
Housing is nice, many events happen, crafting (trading/horsing/sailing) is really interesting and can be a 100% way to play this game. 
Seasons servers can offer now full PVE rules and good gear to help new players.

A real esthetic PVPVE/crafting sandbox with vartiety and good gameplay qualities.

New Players

Added some extra I thought I needed to mention, but there is too much to say about BDO.
--
If you have good graphic card, try remastered graphics and filmic filter and mess with some settings.

Everyone can have several small houses in towns, plus giant mansion (no need to compete with other players for a house). You may need to compete with players in certain towns if you wanna make special items.

There is pvp but it unlocks after u do a quest at 49 which u can skip if u just wanna do lifeskilling for example. 

This game is the perfect chill game if you enjoy lifeskilling by yourself and using workers you hire. You can focus on Lifeskilling from start and just do quests related to it if thats what u wanna do. Bartering sail on ship fight pirates and sea monsters while trading good over sea, trading (wagon+horses).

There is alot of work you wanna do afk, you can minimize the game or do something else in real life. No you can't afk train something and not be logged in.

There is party content but not much, you can grind with friends usually 2-3 in groups. Guild bosses recently got reworked and you can get hired to other guilds as a mercenary everyday. It is very good money and lots of people are doing it. Mechanics got made better as well.

There are only 4 dungeons in the game and more coming or a raid will be added soon.

PvP enjoyers say pvp is mostly dead, peoplle mostly just fight over grinding spots sometimes or do Nodewars.
--

Always start off by creating a season character, create a trial character lets you try out the character you are interested in and I highly recommend doing so because each character plays very differently. Most thing I enjoy about this game is all the combo moves but you can also use hotbar for skills if u dont wanna feel like your playing mortal combat.
Follow quests recommendet by black spirit and ingame seasonal guide. Join a guild to get help and power levels. Focus on one thing at a time cause there is alot of stuff to learn and tons of items with sheet long details.

Exiting season character has been made much much easier and better. You can now get T9 horse and tet black star weapon of your choice for free. They have been working alot on Quality of life updates and improving many aspects of the game as well adding new content. 

It takes time to get a new boat and although many people tell you sea content is dead it means mostly that it gets you less money than grinding in certain areas but don't get fooled it is amazing adventure and alot of fun if you enjoy that kind of stuff, like me.

You play alot solo compared to other mmos, although the chat in the game is done very well and you can chat with everyone across all of the servers using group chat to ask for help.
The game has alot of complicateted ways of doing things but the GMs in the game are amazing and are sometimes available in chat to ask. There are many guides and alot to learn and alot to grind, this is kinda like warframe where you kill groups of enemies for rare loot all the time.

Upgrading your weapons, horses, characters feels very special because it is difficult and takes alot of work and time.

Just playing alittle and logging in gets you tons of rewards so it wont be insanely hard to upgrade your main character to decent stats, you also need several characters to quickly login to other areas like worldbosses and if you just want a break from monster grinding and go do something else like sailing, lifeskilling, questing or just chilling.

i love korean grindy mmos where you stand in one area for the entire day and grind mobs over and over. (not being sarcastic., if you hate grinding and grinding a lot do not download this game and leave a thumbs down because you didn't know what you were buying.) usually it would be to gain a level, slowly but surely, as they are notoriously hamster wheels with LOOOOOONG grinds to level cap in korea. like, years. and by that time, if you are lucky, you'll have 5 minutes before they release the next xpac and 20 levels that take 1.5 years even if u were afk leveling 24 hours a day.   and this would be no exception. well, i dont think there is a cap. there is a point where you question what the hell u are doing with your life. - ur grinding mobs endlessly  to place on an actual leaderboard for money made  by trash items per hour and occasionally gain .1 gear score. and when you get bored you can hunt animals which i would never do in real life but in a video game it's super fun. or fish or do all kinds of sandbox economy things. there are l eaderboards for just about everything which is great. i want to be known as the best fisherman if im gonna click a rod over and over for years, lets be real. 

oh and it doesnt really make you quest for more than an hour or so, one time, no matter how many times you want to make an alt. athough the alt can only be geared and xp'd up with ur current character if u are willing to essentially kill your character and allow him or her (and no, in a korean mmo you do not get to choose your gender. it is locked to class) to skip the entire life ur guardian had and harvest his soul. years he gave to you and spent with you. and you sacrificed him to the fotm new anime girl class who's buttcheeks you can kind of see the bottom of. seek help.

10/10

Combat, visuals/graphics and character customization is TOP TIER. (Even tho classes er gender locked).

Is it super grindy? Is it RNG heavy? Yes and yes. Does the combat and the visuals make up for that? Yes.
End game is only reached through heavy, HEAVY grinding but seems to be worth it. 

However, the possibilities in this game when it comes to life skilling is remarkable. Breeding horses and pets is something I've never touched before in an MMORPG in addition to your usual gathering, crafting, cooking etc etc.

Great and fluid combat. That's about it. They have improved the game a lot over the years but the gear treadmill and sheer amount of grind and RNG needed to make even small amounts of progress is boggling. The devs know it too. They periodically literally hand out end game gear to the players because otherwise most will never even be able to play all the new content they want to add just due to scaling.

Its not really p2w anymore either because even a whale would balk at the amount you would have to spend to make a dent.

Its a grind simulator. If you don't like hours of repetitive grinding this game is not for you. It's not for me either but sunk cost fallacy and all. It took me a few hundred hours of trying to realize it and now I feel like I've come too far to give up.

good

Fun game, best combat I've seen in an MMO, fun solo, its pretty good. Only complaint is that classes are gender-locked for some reason, which I think is pretty stupid, but other than that it's a pretty good MMO.

There is a core good game here. Having played many RPGs and MMORPGs I can say that it has all the core features there. This game is a bit grindy but I accept that, and enjoy the implementation of the knowledge mechanic that rewards grinding interactions with the world (including NPC kills).

I don't like how they've monetized it. Also, the number of menus and submenus is ridiculous. The core game is draped in so many stupid little monetization schemes that the central gameplay isn't fun for me. I don't play a game to buy inventory slots and gamble on loot boxes. It detracts from the play experience to the point I won't bother levelling a character. Unfortunately it's impossible to just turn off all the extra interface mechanics to play the game.
I've just created a character and started into the game and I am already blown away. I can't wait to dive deeper into BDO.

I give this a positive review due to the combat system and the very many missions. However, there is no tutoring for things like trade, nodes, buying a house (why?), etc. I never felt they were worth the research online to learn about them. One major negative for an MMORPG is that, though there are often too many people on the servers (which can cause mission start points to not spawn), there is no interaction with them. Other games of this genre allow random players to take down a boss together or even show acts of kindness by helping a lower level player overcome a swarm of monsters. 
Another negative for me is what I call the Asian sense of aesthetics. Games from Japan, Korea, and China all depict characters as adolescents: 16 year old girls and 19 year old boys. No matter how I tried when I created my character, I could not make him look older than his twenties.
The story line is barely there, which makes me lose interest in the game eventually. I play these games for their stories. That's what makes me feel engaged. One other very annoying thing is the little black spirit that accompanies one through the game. At least I have not met any stupid puzzles (yet). Not sure if I'll continue. 60/100

This is not a multiplayer game. This is a solo grind, with limited economy. You can visually see many players and entities, but you cannot interact with them besides typed chat and emotes. Resources cannot be shared and are tied to your account. It advertises as an MMO. but it's not. It's a singe-player campaign with muliplayer assets. Their business model revolves around a time vs money practice, much like WAR-THUNDER. After 10 years of playing it... It has only sunk further into debauchery. I'd rather do acid and play dungeons and dragons in real life with my friends than play this, because in this MMO I can't even play with my friends!

This game seems interesting, but there are just too many issues. The camera is often in an awkward position when you log in, or during cutscenes. I thought something was wrong because the screen was all white when I logged in, but it turns out the camera was in my horse. Mounts are frustratingly slow until you realize that you have to spam shift to get them to get going. Otherwise they walk slower than your character. Getting a horse to stop is obnoxious and I often go past, or through, whatever I was trying to get to. It's tough to tell the difference between characters and NPCs, so I find that I have to slowly walk around reading all the many, many lines of tiny text above everyone's head to try to figure out who is an NPC, and that's made worse by everyone having their horses all over the place. During cutscenes, character models will shake rapidly, sometimes hover above the ground, and parts of NPC bodies are always going through other objects. It's like they spent a lot of time on the skins and very little time on the models and hit detection.

I don't really care for the combat in this game. In most MMOs, when you are really low level things will die in a hit or two. Not this game. You'll hit something over and over and over and the HP bar won't move. The same goes for enemy attacks. Normal enemies in the field can hit you over and over and you'll stay at full health. The result is that you spend a lot of time trying to kill all the enemies you need for a quest. Attacking is done through key combos, and combo attacks are done by stringing together multiple key combos in a row. It's exhausting. After unleashing everything I had on a single mob and still only getting it down to half health, I noticed I still needed to kill over a dozen more for the quest, which was going to take ages, so I just ran back to town and exited the game.

Interacting with NPCs is basically just spamming R to get through all the conversation, start and end quests, etc. Just keep pressing R until it doesn't do anything anymore. It can be difficult to tell which NPC you're going to talk to when approach them and hit R. Unlike other games where you select objects with the mouse, this game takes over the mouse, using it for moving the camera, and everything is done through the keyboard. I often find myself hitting R, realizing it was the wrong NPC, hit escape, move my character a little bit, try again, until I get the right one, which can be very hard to find if there are other players and their horses around.

Overall I don't really see myself playing this game much. It's a weird combination of needing to figure things out myself and tutorials that walk you through every single aspect of something, but sometimes well after you needed it. I had a pet for many levels before I got the tutorial telling me what they are for and how to use them. I guess I had been missing out on a lot of loot since I have no idea how to pick up loot (other than having a pet do it for you), or what mobs may have been dropping things.

Black Desert Online, in my opinion is the current best MMORPG in the market. 

Classes:
You have 27 classes to choose from, each class has a unique combat style, and set of weapons. I think BDO does a fantastic job at combat, special effects, and visual effects related to combat. They more recently started putting out class trailers, the Shai trailer being the coolest IMO. I hope they start putting more effort into the Class trailers and wish they would revamp/create a trailer for each class.

Character Building and Customization:
One of the most engaging parts of BDO is the customization range of the classes. Whatever you can dream of or fantasize about your character looking like, you can create it! Or, if you're not creatively inclined you can choose from the thousands of templates created by other people. 

Questing:
PA Dev's have made many improvements to the quest lines in BDO. Instead of spamming R to get through them all, you are pulled into the story with cut scenes, some you are able to interact with, and many quest lines to adventure down in. They are expanding regions which offer more quest lines and a new range of quest lines, monster zones or grinding, or nodes to gather/excavate items. I am personally someone who enjoys lore, and BDO has very in depth and interesting lore. 

Combat:
While this is a PVP/PVE game, I more so enjoy PVE at this time in order to farm silver to improve my gear. The gear system in BDO for some may be a pain if you're an enhancer, but if you're a buyer there are many boss gears to choose from and very very very expensive ones if you're PVP focused.

Overall:
If you are looking for a time sink MMO game that you can play at your own pace and your own way, then I recommend Black Desert Online.

Here's your Semi-TLDR review of BDO aka Black Desert Online care of "this guy right here". I may write more in the future (possibly a guide), but here's my general findings after many years playing and interacting with the community.

[h2]Is this game for you?[/h2] If you like MMORPG gameplay, sandbox adventure/exploration, and like things such as questing, gathering, looting, crafting, player houses, fishing, farming, etc, and creating a unique character, then you will enjoy this game!

There's a little something for everyone in BDO... while it may not be as story heavy as some RPGMMOs such as guildwars, and may not have the typical raids etc some are used to in other games, what is there is enjoyable and there is a lot of room for carving your own adventure. 
The game continues to improve with each update, with the Mountain of Eternal Winter expansion bringing you not just a new character class and a whole new region packed full of adventure, but a rather likeable companion for the duration of the main quest arc brought to life by a famous voice actor. While the Land of Morning Light brings you a fairly authentic Korean Mythological experience, two new character classes, a whole new boss battle/conquest experience, and a veritable smorgasbord of delight for any life skill enthusiasts.

[h2]Value for money:[/h2] 10/10 at standard price, 11/10 when on sale.
On sale it's less than a pound at £0.89, AND... ALL THE GAME UPDATES AND EXPANSIONS ARE [b]100% FREE[/b]!

[h2]P2W?[/h2]
[b]Just NO[/b]... there is a cash shop, but buying items from it does not enable you to win, they're mostly cosmetic, and slightly quality of life at best. Meanwhile the BDO team has actually limited the rate at which you can sell things like outfits on the in game market for in game currency.
The reality is it would take you hundreds-thousands of IRL currency and literal years to make the same amount of money you could make in a week or two worth of grinding/actually playing the game.
Only noobs who have taken one look in the pearl shop and not understood what they are looking at say it's P2W, but never do any research to back up their assumption. *rolls eyes*

[h2]Loot:[/h2] 10/10 Daily log-ins, events, free codes, quests, drops, watching twitch streams, season, holiday events, random gifts from the devs, etc, shower you with all kinds of loot including items/pets/outfits/mounts/furniture... all worth IRL money in the cash shop.

[h2]Life Span:[/h2] Black Desert has been "Online" from around 2014 which makes it nearly a decade old now, and since then the game has continued to be updated, expanded, improved. 
2019 saw the launch of the game on the popular console platforms, and recently the game's player base has grown such that the BDO team have significantly expanded the number of available game world servers... it's safe to say the game will be here the next time you log in which isn't always the case for many MMOs.

[h2]Graphics:[/h2] 9.5/10 for the remastered and ultra settings.
Anything from a Nvidia 980Ti upwards can expect pretty pretty graphics. It even has up-scaling for lower powered systems, or energy bill savings.
The truly [i]frugal[/i] can take further advantage of the "Lowest/optimal" graphics option for AFK game elements such as horse training or fishing and this can be combined with the power-savings gained by "minimising to tray", where the game goes into an already super optimised power-saving mode.
On an additional note: It's also nice that the game runs fine and doesn't fry your expensive graphics card, which you'd expect to be a given... [b]I'm looking at you New World[/b].

[h2]UI:[/h2] 3/10 when you first use the game. 9/10 once you set everything up yourself.
Why? Because when you first jump into the game world you will be hit with a poo-nami of hurty hurty "[i]Oww [b]my eyes[/b], the pain, why won't it stop![/i]" popup notifications about literally everything happening in the game including what your neighbour just did in the bathroom... [b]Fear not[/b] my friend, with a few minutes spent in the options menu you can easily turn off all the annoying notifications, reduce all the clutter, and can even fully customise most of your UI which is pretty neat.

[h2]Character Customisation:[/h2] 9/10. For an MMORPG it's fair to say this has one of the most comprehensive and in-depth character creators out there offering a wide range of customisation.
Pre-made templates are available for those with the artistic prowess of a house brick.

[h2]Class Selection:[/h2] 8.5/10 The class selection over all is pretty diverse. There are a range of male and female characters, many of which play quite differently to the rest, and they are interesting enough to make you want to try out most of them. It's worth exploring the full range to discover your favourites.

[h2]Combat:[/h2] 9/10 As far as RPGMMOs go, the combat is actually pretty damn good. I give it a 9 because there is room for improvement, but it feels more enjoyable than [strike]Lost[/strike] [i]Thurst[/i] Ark, and makes the control style of other games like Guildwars 2 etc feel rather dated/clunky.
Many who start and quit before giving it a real go might assume the combat is just a case of clicking the left mouse button to make monsters disappear... these people would be highly mistaken, and some of those would be irredeemable halfwits (but that's another story).
Combat tends to show its true colours by level 61 when you have unlocked all your skills, chosen the Awakening or Succession path, unlocked your Awakening weapon, and equipped suitable skill add-ons.

Farming drops will often be a one skill and rush on process which is the efficiency you want for this kind of task, but higher monsters and boss monsters will require thought, technique, understanding of your skills, setting your skills up properly for your class, and even learning some skill combos.
You can really go down the rabbit hole and learn more complex combos, part casts, skill cancellations, and even immunity frames if you crave the hand executed "Uber Macro" times of bygone days, it also plays a big role in PvP if you like PvP.

[h2]Community:[/h2] 8/10 There's actually a pretty good community surrounding BDO... every game has its curmudgeons, salty behotches, and toxy the toxic avengers, but providing you don't stand afk or fish outside of a safe zone, you'll likely not get greifed by a [i]kill happy[/i] pre-teen. Plus if you look around on discord, you'll be able to find a guild that speaks your native language. There are even communities for specific character classes and life skills like horse training/breeding, all of which can be an absolute goldmine of useful information... so have a look.

[h2]Final thoughts...[/h2] You can't decide if you truly like the game until you've completed a season character play-through, reached level 61 and started to actually get into the main game content. The same can be said for trying just one class, try a few over time, and don't get over-saturated by the game. If you're getting tired, take a break, it's not going anywhere, and a new update has taken the time constraints of season away, so you can play season at your own pace...
"[i]feels smooth like silka[/i]".
You'll enjoy the holiday events... there's usually some daft fun or little quests to do around Easter, Summer, Halloween, Autumn, Thanks Giving, Christmas, New Year, Eastern New Year, etc, and the game world generally has an excitable bustle to it due to everyone logged in around these times.
There are live streams, and events held by the BDO team which may or may not be of interest. Some are good, others can be dull/cringe, it entirely depends on what you like.
They even hold music events/contests where people compose music in game with the available instruments and play mini concerts... daft but cute fun and you may even witness some true talent.

I got this for 99 cents and I'm getting a refund on principle. It's that bad. 

The character creator is so mind bogglingly terrible that I can't even get myself to the point where I'm actually playing the game. Each class has a set gender and body type, within which you have many sliders you can move that all have a narrow range that will basically make all characters of any class look more or less the same. The multitude of sliders tries to trick you into thinking you have a meaningful measure of control over your character's appearance. Alas, this just results in having many many sliders you must manipulate to try and see if you can make, for example, a more fem looking Sage (a class only allowed to be a man with a hulking jawline) but you will fail because whoever made this has decreed that all characters must either look like a cookie cutter supermodel with bouncing boobs and a developer mandated thigh gap or a dehydrated gym bro.

Character appearance is very important to me and I hate having my character look like a person who fits beauty standards so perfectly that it would be physically impossible for them to exist. If you're a girl character your boob armor will boing-oing-oing even though your bikini is made of metal. This whole thing reeks of gender. Awful.
Its alot to take in, but im sure once you actually put the effort in to learn the system its good.

Spent close to a thousand hours in Black Desert Online, and let's just say my character got lost in the digital ether because I forgot to transfer it! Lesson learned: don't forget to transfer your character, or they might just decide to stay in their virtual paradise forever!

As much as I really wanted to like this game, I could not bring myself to find enjoyment like others have over the years. I am no stranger to the MMO(RPG) and open world. 

I have played many of the AAA titles like World of Warcraft, Final Fantasy XIV, ESO, New World, GW2 and many others like Rift, Tera, GTA V, even ArcheAge Unchained, just to list a few titles of the many I have played over the years. 

I enjoyed all of those other games for both the PVE and PVP experiences they offer. But there is something that I cannot seem to grasp with BDO. I played it when it first came out and you had to grind all day, bringing me back to my old school days of Runescape and Thang Online for some of the other old farts that may remember that old game. 

BDO is praised by so many for the combat, which ironically is the part that I cannot find enjoyment in. I'm sure many call me crazy for saying that, which is fine. To me, it feel like skills casting animations are problematic, at least for my style and expectation with action combat. I am of the belief that if the game promotes itself as a fast paced action combat system, then skills need to fall into line. 

Games like GW2, which is what I would argue is a hybrid of tab target with a small touch of action, still makes skills feel great, even World of Warcraft makes skills feel fluid and responsive. ESO is fine, not my top pick out of all the great combat systems out there, but still feels way more intuitive. Or take Monster Hunter, that combat system would feel amazing in BDO. I am not against a complex rotations or even simple combat systems. A good example of a very simple straight forward combat system is offered in New World, and it is one of the best feeling combat systems I have found to date for archery builds.

Graphics on the other hand are still top notch for the age of the game. I know that my issue with the game resonates with a small group of people, so if you are still wondering if you should try BDD, the short answer is, yes you should see if you find enjoyment. The long answer just my personal opinion for the way I play games and does not reflect others play-styles.

If you want to indulge in a B-tier fantasy world, this is it. Jokes aside, gameplay is deep and vast you can easily not get bored for hundreds or even thousands of hours. Map is massive and very fun to explore. Character customization is probably the best I've ever seen. Bad points: Story is weak, world feels sub-par compared to other big MMOs like TES or WOW. Region locking with NO way to swap regions. And paid outfits look jarring to the eye (not as bad as TERA though) Community is toxic but eh- it's an online game afterall. If you're into MMOs you should at least give it a try.

Black Desert has probably the worst starting UI I've seen to date, and I've tried Arc: Survival evolved.

There's no way back to the main menu to change your settings like volume. Once you've entered the server selection, you're locked in buddy.

Character creation is extremely clunky, with a hard to maneuver camera, not to mention the fact that the character constantly looks at the camera when you want to view other angles.

Sure, you can fully sculpt the face, there's no denying there's loads of creativity to be had there, but I simply cannot overlook the rest of the issues when it comes to the UI upon entering the game.

I don't feel the necessity to talk about the gender locked classes and the whole debacle about each of them, largely because I haven't played any of them at the time of writing.

As far as I can decipher, this game is more of a hero beat 'em up, akin to the likes of Warframe.

However, I cannot recommend this game with good consciousness while the UI is as clunky as it is.

(I may also be a little salty because the game crashed during character creation, but that should be fairly understandable lol.)

This game is a blast. Everything I wanted it to be (an MMO with lots of quests, skills, and beautiful graphics).

The combat in this game is so satisfying and keeps me coming back to it time and time again. I read somewhere that BDO is better described as a marathon rather than a sprint, and I think that is definitely true. The developers have made so many great changes in the recent years to improve accessibility, but this game really does a great job at moving you through the early game well and then basically letting you decide how you want to play and continue to gear up. Obviously some ways are better than others, but at the end of the day I can enjoy exploring, grinding, fishing, creating an empire of workers who enable me to craft trade goods, or farming. Would definitely recommend.

New Player experience is terrible...

You are playing a menu clicking simulator for about 5 hours.
You then realize you get 10x the exp/currency clicking thru menus for quests then actually playing the game....
WAY to many systems stacks on systems.
Extreme amounts of inventory bloat.
Graphics are great. But a tremendous amount of pop in/out graphics, lots of times your standing in the right spot just waiting for a NPC to spawn.

Combat and classes are amazing. But again very unclear and confusing for new players. 
I know my hours dont reflect... I played for a few hundred outside of steam.

Endgame is just about currency... farm for days/weeks/months generating currency. to RNG click for upgrades. or buy better gear flat out... to then be slightly better at grinding more currency. Rinse Repeat... Bosses are fun... the first time... although sorta glitchy... but again clearing harder difficulties comes down to the cycle mentioned above... 

Combo system for characters is great... but very poorly explained... game has too many buttons and to few buttons at the same time.

If you have played hundreds of hours before you know what to expect... if you have never played... pass this one over... Game does not respect your time at all... you have to invest hundreds of hours for very small gains or actual losses some times...

The game doesn't play well.

Immediately as I started the game, it doesn't let me play, I am forced to watch a 10 minute video where I can press W and click once. After that I am introduced into a world where I have no idea what is going on. Then the combat starts...the skill animations are nice, I can't deny that, however, using skills and combos is a nightmare. You have a constant window up which always displays the combos that you can make but you have to use S, Shift, F, W, both clicks, and the combination between them is like learning to play the piano. Too bad that the combat implementation is so bad. You have no idea how much damage you deal with the combos because they don't show that, the monster HP sometimes drops, sometimes they just get hit until they die. The UI is cluttered and useless. You have the option to modify the UI but only after reaching level 10. REALLY? Honestly, the game had me quit from the 10 minute unskippable movie/cutscene but I decided to give it a shot anyway but I couldn't go further than completing 3 quests.
Uninstalling will solve all your in game problems.

My previous review was a 10/10 and I was in love with the game. This has unfortunately changed over the past two years and I am here to update my review. 

The quality of this game has changed very much. I would no longer recommend it. The development direction of the game has gone to cater to casuals and those who don't have time to play. And while that sounds great the application is pretty bad. Essentially they increased silver gain so much with the idea of making end game grind more rewarding. Instead it just created inflation (obviously)

Additionally all of the items that used to be true accomplishments like treasures and higher gear are now given away for free through in game events with minimal effort. Most of the rare items are no longer rare or untradable. Infinite potions can be traded and obtained thru daily quests now. Many treasures that had value and took a great deal of effort are now obtainable with mindless minimal efforts. 

Some people enjoy these changes. And if you are one of them power to you. If you are like me though, and like real sense of accomplishment for achievements including rare items and gear progression this game is no longer of interest. Its been a great ride black desert. Thanks for the memories. 

Overall rating now: 4/10

Pros:

- immersive 
- large world
- complex and deep systems
- regular updates
- recent updates have made lifeskilling and trades much more profitable and this game is now a good option for those who are less interested in combat
- great time sink if you have too much free time
- most paid items can be bought for in game currency however it can take extremely long time to get one on pre order. Sometimes weeks sometimes months. 

Cons:

- no real sense of accomplishment
- too many freebies and give aways
- gender locked classes with not enough male options (at time of writing the past 5 classes over 4 years have all been female, which is nice to look at and the classes are good just inconsistent)
- to play comfortably and not spend hours managing items and storage subscriptions are a must, and to have an optimal experience a few hundred dollars in purchases+ subscription is required
- class balancing doesn't happen frequently enough so older classes often fall behind in power and clear speed. While every class is playable and relevant for most or all content there are clear advantages to choosing newer classes. This is not unlike other mmos though. And is fairly standard in the genre. New content takes time to balance with old content. 
- open world pvp can now be completely circumvented. This was one of the major things that made black desert appealing to being with was that you could open world pvp anyone anywhere, while this is still possible private worlds can now be used to prevent pvp encounters and fighting over grind spots.

Black Desert is a game plagued with numerous bugs and glitches that hinder gameplay. From quest breaking issues to character animation problems, these bugs make it difficult and annoying to do a lot of shit.

The game's mechanics seem to be in a constant state of disarray. Combat feels unresponsive sometimes, and the lack of polish is evident in various aspects of gameplay. It's sad to see a game with so much potential fail to deliver on basic mechanics.

Black Desert also has an excessively grindy progression system. While some grind is expected in MMOs, the level of repetition required in this game is excessive. It feels more like a chore than an enjoyable gaming experience. I shouldn't have to spend hours everyday grinding for a little bit of a gear boost.

The UI and overall user experience are awful. Navigating menus is a cumbersome task, and basic functions like editing the UI is locked behind leveling up.

The game's performance is awful, even on mid to high-end systems. Frame rate drops and inconsistent graphics make it clear that the game lacks proper optimization, impacting the overall gameplay.

In conclusion, Black Desert falls short of expectations due to its numerous bugs, broken mechanics, excessive grind, lack of player-friendly features, and poor optimization.

I hope the developers take note of these issues and work towards improving the overall quality of the game in future updates.

Embarking on a six-year journey with Black Desert has been a rollercoaster of highs and lows, with countless hours invested and numerous characters explored. Through the ups and downs, one thing remains certain – the time spent was far from regrettable and I always come back to this game.


Black Desert's unique blend of repetitive tasks has a strange allure that captivates players, myself included. The joy derived from battling monsters, even in a seemingly monotonous loop, is hard to put into words. The game allows you to switch off mentally, creating a space where you can unwind while engaging in enjoyable activities. Whether it's grinding mobs or enhancing gear, the gameplay loop somehow manages to stay entertaining.


Having witnessed the game's evolution over six years, it's apparent that Black Desert has come a long way. Recent changes have significantly improved the overall quality of life for players, catering to both returning and new enthusiasts. These adjustments not only streamlined the experience but also added layers of enjoyment for current players. The developers' commitment to enhancing the player experience deserves recognition.


An unavoidable aspect of Black Desert that divides the player base is the notorious RNG, particularly within the enchantment system. However, on a personal note, the RNG gods have smiled upon me. While some may complain about its unpredictability, I find the enchantment system adds an extra layer of excitement and unpredictability to the game.


One of Black Desert's standout features is its diverse range of systems, creating an experience akin to playing multiple games within one. Whether it's trading, fishing, or engaging in player-versus-player content, there's always something for everyone. This versatility keeps the game feeling fresh and ensures players can find aspects they genuinely enjoy.


Despite the game's strengths, a noticeable flaw lies in its optimization. Even on a high-end system, Black Desert struggles to maintain consistent frame rates, often succumbing to stutters and other performance issues. Addressing this optimization challenge should be a top priority for the developers, as it currently detracts from an otherwise immersive experience.


Six years into the Black Desert universe, and the journey continues to be a fulfilling one. The game's ability to evolve, provide diverse activities, and maintain an engaging experience is commendable. While RNG may be a contentious issue, the overall enjoyment derived from the enchantment system and varied gameplay systems overshadows these concerns. However, the plea for improved optimization remains, as it stands as a notable blemish on an otherwise outstanding gaming experience.

[h2][b]🎮 Introduction[/b][/h2]
I recommend trying out [b]Black Desert Online[/b] for yourself to see if it aligns with your gaming tastes. With Steam, you can get a refund under certain conditions, so it's a risk-free trial!

Black Desert Online is a sprawling MMO filled with a variety of content and features. It’s a world that beckons with adventure and possibilities! 

[h2][b]✅ Pros[/b][/h2]
[b]💰 Affordable:[/b] Not too expensive (10 euros, 1 euro on sale).
[b]🌟 Diverse Content:[/b] Offers a wide array of activities and features.
[b]👥 Large Player Base:[/b] Ensures a lively and dynamic world.
[b]🎨 Stunning Graphics:[/b] Visually impressive and immersive.
[b]🛠️ Weekly Maintenance:[/b] Regular updates every Wednesday.
[b]⚔️ Combat System:[/b] Incredible and visually stunning combat.
[b]🏹 Variety of Classes:[/b] 17 different classes to choose from.
[b]🎣 Life Skills:[/b] 10 different life skills like fishing, cooking, and more.
[b]🔄 Item Flexibility:[/b] Items are mostly family-bound, not character-bound.
[b]⚖️ No Level Cap on Items:[/b] Easy to transfer gear to level new characters.
[b]🎉 Frequent Events:[/b] Keeps the game fresh and engaging.
[b]💎 Marketplace Sniping:[/b] Pearl items available for in-game currency.
[b]👷 Worker System:[/b] Adds depth to gameplay.
[b]📚 Knowledge System:[/b] Rich lore and knowledge to explore.
[b]🌐 Contribution Points:[/b] Used for creating a worker empire.
[b]👾 Variety of Mobs:[/b] Lots of different enemies to encounter.
[b]📍 Grinding Spots:[/b] Numerous locations for grinding.
[b]🎭 Character Customization:[/b] Highly detailed and versatile.
[b]🚫 No Real-World Trading:[/b] Ensures fair play.
[b]🎣 AFK Progress:[/b] Ability to progress in certain skills while AFK.
[b]🌌 Open World:[/b] Expansive and seamless exploration.
[b]🗺️ Huge Map:[/b] Large world with diverse environments.
[b]🔄 Seamless Play:[/b] No loading screens, smooth gameplay.
[b]🔋 Low CPU Usage Mode:[/b] Handy for multitasking.


[h2][b]❌ Cons[/b][/h2]
[b]🔄 Grindy Gameplay:[/b] Can feel repetitive and grindy.
[b]🐾 Pets Necessary:[/b] Essential for looting, will probably cost you money to max out.
[b]⚔️ Unbalanced PvP:[/b] Challenging for players with low gear scores.
[b]💸 Pay-to-Win Elements:[/b] Some items almost necessary for full enjoyment.
[b]🎲 RNG Enhancing:[/b] Random enhancement system can be frustrating.
[b]📈 Slow High-Level Progress:[/b] Leveling at high levels takes a lot of time.
[b]🚫 Limited Trading:[/b] Very restricted player-to-player trade.
[b]🏆 No Steam Achievements:[/b] Lacks this rewarding element.

[h2][b]📚 Overall Impression[/b][/h2]
Black Desert Online is a captivating game with lots to offer. I’ve had a great time playing and plan to continue for the foreseeable future! 

[h2][b]📘 Bonus[/b][/h2]
Want to try Black Desert Online? Check out my guides for a smoother start!

I have around 2800 hours including hours from my other account before the game was released on Steam.

I’ll try and keep this review short and concise, the game is great fun if you’re a new player, you get given lots of items to start off with and the game does a great job of explaining many of the mechanics to you through side quests, tutorial and the story. The game has a vast open-world and while its not as big as other MMORPGs its way denser with content and feels alive. There are also lots of things to do if you do not want to just grind by killing monsters, you can always just life skill and have a profession. The main issue I have with this game as I played it from the release before Steam till now is that gear progression is expensive and heavily luck dependant. This is because the change to get a successful enchantment can go from 20% all the way down to 3% last time I checked and every time you fail you must increase the durability using memory fragments. Another big issue is grinding in the game efficiently, its essential to have a costume and at least 3 pets to automatically pick up loot for you. This along with gear progression takes a lot time and is expensive.

Pros:
- Beautiful Graphics.
- Vast areas to explore and travel 
- Fluid Combat.
- Unique classes
- In-depth character creation

Cons:
- Grinding efficiently requires a costume, at least 3 pets with decent enchantments
- Not enough PVE endgame content aside from World Bosses
- Very grindy (although expected since this is a Korean MMORPG)
- Gear progression through enchanting is very expensive and luck dependant.
- There are notifications that you cannot turn off in the settings

In short, this game in its current state is great if you want to have some fun, but if you ever want to catch up and be competitive in PVP/PVE your going to have to spend at least £70 on the game.

This game is fun...when it works. Every single time I disconnect it won't open again without giving me a large headache. It loves to freeze on the splash screen.  Sometimes changing UAC settings will get it to run.  Sometimes reinstalling EAC (Easy Anti Cheat) will work.  Sometimes closing random tasks in the task manager will work.  Sometimes verifying the integrity of the files will work (which isn't quick).  Sometimes restarting the computer will help.  Sometimes deleting the cache folder will help.  Sometimes messing with the .pae and .exe files work.  The point is, there are so many solutions I've read up on, and it seems I have to do every single one every time, and even then it doesn't always work.

But....

When it does run it's a fun game.  I'm not a hardcore MMO enthusiast so all I can say is that the game is a fun time-waster with lots of things to do.  You probably don't want me to join your guild because I don't play every day.  But for a solo experience, I think it's a great game.  I just wish it didn't take me 30 minutes to an hour of troubleshooting to get it started every time.  Maybe you'll have better luck than I do.

The only aspects I will miss about the game are the character creation and the combat. The game itself has so much potential but it is all lost on things being way too complicated. The upgrade system is relentless and while they have tried to make up for people getting tired of the game with countless free rewards it only makes your effort thus far pointless. While this is not the most toxic game I have played it is definitely not known for being friendly. It is extremely unfriendly to new players and any player you try to invite gets tired of me having to explain so many things. A game should just fall into place after a while of playing it but this game never does. Too many things to learn/do too many risks to level up/upgrade. The season character system made it better but like I said for people who worked really hard for their gear it is now discouraging for people to just get similar gear after just a day or two of farming. There was so much potential but not enough guidance and it just kind of falls off. The questing is atrocious. But you have to do quests. It will give you a migraine trying to figure them out at times unless you've done them before and know where to go. I have had friends just quit the game because the questing was just too difficult or hard to understand.  I have loved and hated this game but lately I have stopped playing it. I will forever miss my tamer/wizard. I enjoyed the combat a lot but that is about it.

A game that marked my mmo rpg journey for the better.
Easy to learn, hard to master.

Micro transactions whales don't mean they're stronger but whales overload the game for sure.

Great narrative and world, a lot of mechanics to learn and stuff to try. Lots of classes, great customization and amazing scenarios.

Everything are good in my opinion:
The combat are great kinda like Street Fighter but with 3D perspective (I talk about combos or sequential of attacking, pulling, kiting, dodging, moving, buffing, debuffing etc). 
The world and character is so beautiful (but gender lock).
Many thing to do aside from killing millions of same species of monster to progress your gear.
You can also killing another millions of same species to grind treasure items(Infinite Pots, Merchant Ring, Compass, Maps, Telescope etc) or something like Lifeskilling, train your loli to play instrument, getting bigger ship.

BUT 

If you appreciate your time. Don't! You must be ready to wasting your precious time and coping with losing resources. You can lose your sweaty grind progress by keep gambling on enhancing equipment and If you died while grinding, it might end up with crystal lose which usually cost 30 mins - 2 hrs of your efficient grind (This might big turnoff for new player) 

Too many different items with different categories that fills your inventory that are either useless forever, useless for you now or only useful when its event and with you are having a limited storage (Can increase it by P2W or keep playing the game) and your slaves put the their works too into the same storage, it is so messy. I'm remind you, don't trying to sort it, you better play any storage simulator games. It is make Minecraft sorting like a child play.

The Progress system is one of the worst.
It is like,
your checkpoint for each progression 8-12-15-30-55-7000-125000
your silver gain per progression 6-7-8-8-9-10-15
and you are either spend 70 hours to just progress single things or you can gambling to 50/50 of either go to moon or hours of your life taken.

This is one of the core of the game, the games encourage you to do this or the system is based on this.
The game is full with [according to a set of probability] and 
events with 
1) chances to drop something.
2) chances for something to appear.
3) chances to get a box that comes with a probability to get something.
3) chances to drop a materials that are a part to craft something that needed to do a chances of something.

I already touch about chances of enhancing and I don't want to talk about chances to drop something while grinding.
Basically, if you have no luck, this game isn't for you. You are just hurting yourself.


Lets talk about P2W,
First of all, you need 
1) Campsite (You will hate grinding without this)
2) Horse Trumpet for horse calling (You will hate moving around the world without this)
3) Pets (You can get 1b/hr in some spots but you got 500m only? you think you suck but you stop to loot because your pet suck)
For point 3, middle finger to people said "You can get pets just by playing, I play this game and all of my pet already max without spending a cent". 4) Maids and Weight (Both are annoying if you just start the game, but not too significant as points above)
5) Value Pack (Think this like a subscription, but you won't feel it till reaching mid-game, you know how bad storage system? without this, even worst)

You might doing something wrong that will lose you a billions of silvers or getting a wrong progressing gear or wrong class to play but if you already started to play and enjoy it currently. After aditional 20kHours here's my final take:
A Masterpiece of Frustration - Black Desert Online

Oh, where do I begin with the enchanting experience that is Black Desert Online? It's truly a game that leaves you speechless, and not always in a good way.

Firstly, let me commend the developers for their dedication to creating a visually stunning world. The graphics are so breathtaking that you might find yourself forgetting about the numerous other aspects of the game that fall short. It's almost as if they wanted to distract you from the fact that the gameplay is about as smooth as sandpaper.

The enchanting mechanics are a real treat, providing a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment, you're on cloud nine after successfully enhancing your gear; the next, you're left wondering if the RNG gods have forsaken you. It's like a casino, but instead of winning money, you gain the privilege of not smashing your keyboard in frustration.

And let's not forget the joy of navigating the game's user interface – a labyrinthine masterpiece of confusion. It's like the developers decided to make a game within a game, challenging players to decipher the mysteries of the inventory system while juggling a circus of poorly explained features.

The PvE content is equally riveting. The grind is so exhilarating that you might find yourself questioning the very meaning of progress. Who needs a sense of accomplishment when you can mindlessly slaughter hordes of generic enemies for hours on end?

But fear not, as the game's community is there to lift your spirits. You'll be welcomed with open arms by players who are more than happy to share their wisdom about the ins and outs of the game. Just kidding – expect a toxic cesspool of elitism and condescension that rivals the depth of the game's lore.

In conclusion, Black Desert Online is a one-of-a-kind experience that will leave you wondering if you've accidentally stumbled into a parallel universe where game design conventions are mere suggestions. Bravo to the developers for crafting a game that truly tests your patience, resilience, and ability to resist the urge to uninstall. It's an experience you won't soon forget, whether you want to or not.

This game used to be very immersive and offered a free and exciting open world.  However, during these past two years the developers have been going in directions that are ruining the reasons why I love this game.  The lore is amazing, but the story is poorly written and implemented.  The combat is amazing, but once you get through mid-game level and gear, you hit an end-game wall take takes years to slowly overcome.  Excitement can quickly fade.  End-game rush mechanics are permanently in place, and you can get to the end-game wall in very little time.  Immersion is secondary to grinding as rushing to end-game.  The community is fractured due to the nature of the game being hyper-competitive, and the developers trying to heal the breach by not fixing the essential competitiveness by creating good cooperative mechanics.  They take it out on the PvP community and are forcing them into clunky, poorly designed, inorganic PvP modes.  The free, open world of this game is under assault, and players are forced to play the way the devs want them to, instead of being free to play as they wanted to, as they have been able to do for years.  Decisions made by developers are arbitrary and ppor planned, poorly implemented and trust down our throats, and if a change is unpopular, it's almost never addressed.  The beautiful soundtrack of this game was ruined two years ago, and is now a poorly implemented mess, with music playing in areas and situations that are incongruous.  Immersion is ruined by the music half the time.  In conclusion, this game is ok for players wanting to dabble in it for a few months, but once you hit the end-game wall, unless there's some reason to stay, like knowing how great this game used to be, and the hope that it can be returned to it's glory, there is little to look forward to aside from years of grinding for little purpose.   I love this game, but it is going in the wrong direction.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

Review:

"Black Desert" stands as a testament to the sheer grandeur and immersive quality that an MMORPG can offer. My journey in this expansive world has been nothing short of extraordinary, and the joy of playing alongside friends has elevated the experience to new heights.

Visually, "Black Desert" is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in character design, landscapes, and the overall environment is breathtaking. The seamless transitions between day and night, weather changes, and the dynamic world events contribute to a living, breathing virtual realm that feels truly alive. Whether delving into dungeons, engaging in epic battles, or simply exploring the vast open world, every moment is a visual feast.

The character customization in "Black Desert" is unparalleled. The level of detail you can achieve in sculpting your character's appearance is astonishing, allowing for a level of personalization that is rarely seen in other games. It adds a layer of immersion and uniqueness to the MMO experience.

The combat system is a standout feature, offering a fast-paced and skill-based approach that keeps engagements exciting. Each class feels distinct, with a variety of combos and abilities that demand practice and mastery. It's a refreshing departure from traditional tab-targeting systems, adding a layer of action-oriented gameplay that keeps encounters dynamic and engaging.

The inclusion of life skills and crafting adds depth to the game, offering a variety of activities beyond combat. Whether it's fishing, trading, or participating in the player-driven economy, there's always something to do for players who enjoy a more relaxed, non-combat aspect of MMOs.

The cooperative aspects of "Black Desert" are where the game truly shines. Questing, trading, and engaging in massive guild wars are just a few examples of the collaborative experiences that make playing with friends so enjoyable. The vast world encourages exploration and discovery, and the sense of camaraderie that comes with tackling challenges together is immensely satisfying.

In conclusion, "Black Desert" is a monumental achievement in the MMORPG genre. Its stunning visuals, engaging combat system, and wealth of activities make it a standout title. However, it's the shared experiences with friends that truly make this game shine. Whether embarking on epic quests, building trade empires, or engaging in intense battles, "Black Desert" is a journey that becomes exponentially more enjoyable when shared with friends. It's a must-play for MMO enthusiasts seeking a rich and vibrant virtual world to explore together.
