my review might sound a bit pessimistically, however I still recommend BDO IF u are looking for great graphics and second-to-none action combat.

final fantasy got story, WoW got.. I dunno tbh, BDO got graphics and a great action combat system.

BDO does have a story and a bunch of quests, but u'll end up skipping everything eventually (which BDO luckely allows for the most part)

there have been a bunch of QoL changes like: 
-players get a bunch of shop items from playing and events nowadays and the p2w aspect has been reduced dramatically (personally never felt that it's p2w but as a reference; when I started I spent about 50$ after a short time, if I would start today, I'd spend 27$ for the tent on discount, the rest of the items I would get for free after max 1 month)
-being able to use every storage anywhere.
-easily get mid-range gear so u can enjoy most of the available content after 1 week of relaxed playing.
-teleportation is finally a thing (altho the fee is high enough to kill any veteran if used too often)
-the progression in general has been made easier over the past few years to the point where a casual player can progress without feeling dead inside.
-overall improved minor details which are noticeable to a veteran, but can't rly specify what they are.

the game can get repetitive considering it's main gameplay is some type of grinding (mobs, gathering, weekly/daily quests, etc) so for anyone interested in an MMO, I'd say u would only come to BDO for the graphics and it's phenomenal action combat (altho PvP fights are usually just 5 seconds long and it's just about who lands their stun first)

I have definitely gotten my moneys worth considering my playtime, but at this point I'm just a casual player who stays because I love the graphic and there's not rly any other game out there that has the same type of action combat when it comes to PvE as BDO.

just be warned in case u wish to get the best gear there is; it seems that the devs main strategy has become to create new gear pieces to grind for on a regular basis, they do give options to change ur old gear into the new one so u can continue enhancing rather then having to restart, but u will most likely never get the best gear out there as they will make a new piece once u get close (or right after u finally got it).

there are a bunch of active players, but everyone tends to keep to themselves. there are some guilds that try to be social, but I have gotten more socialisation out of the "chat group" chat, then I have from any guilds (PvP guilds are more active internally)

Navigating Black Desert Online proved challenging due to the unintuitive controls and cluttered GUI. The game overwhelms players with excessive information on the screen, making it difficult to locate essential elements. The quest system's complexity adds to the confusion, requiring improvement for a more user-friendly experience.

Frequent freezes during map transitions disrupt the flow of both combat and non-combat activities. This technical issue hampers the overall gaming experience, demanding optimization to ensure seamless transitions and uninterrupted gameplay.

Controlling horses in Black Desert Online pose a challenge, sometimes horses start drifting and literally end up colliding with walls and fences, the horse riding mechanics are a bit clunky sometimes.

The lack of visible models for gear some items, such as helmets, diminishes the immersive quality of the MMO. Enhancing the visual representation of equipment is essential to create a more engaging and satisfying experience for players who value character customization and aesthetics.

In conclusion, Black Desert Online offers a visually stunning world with a rich array of features, but its shortcomings in controls, technical performance, and gear visibility hinder the overall gaming experience. Addressing these issues would significantly contribute to making Black Desert Online a more accessible and enjoyable MMO.

Played for years, Hate the new changes, most unnecessary changes I have seen in an mmo to date. To me the selling point of BDO was open world Immersion with the PVP elements. All of that has seemingly disappeared. It has become something akin to WOW in that all aspects of PVP are now regulated and the developers are forcing people into the instanced 3v3 or battleground scenario just like WOW. In WOW that is ok because there is actually PVE content to do, but in BDO all you do is run circles; you run circles to get better gear to run circles in higher grind spots because even most NodeWars and Sieges are gear capped. On top of all this they implemented the marni realm system and made it so you can grind 12 hours out of the day uninterrupted. The game is basically a single player game that limits interaction with players and caters to the nomadic gamer who only comes back for updates while simultaneously alienating and pushing out the loyal base of the game. All the hours and grinding for gear to be competitive lost to a company that caved. Gear is meaningless now in the game except for some of the high end grind spots. Hell you really don't even need gear if you just 3v3 or do the weekly bosses.
Even for 99 cents, this is the worst MMO I have ever played.

I have been playing BDO for about  3 years now, and am really enjoying it! I have played many MMORPGs in my days so I can say Im an experienced player of the style. None are perfect, but if you are going to play an MMORPG give this 1 a try! 
Pros:  Great combat, very smooth and well illustrated!
True sandbox and open world
New quest line is interesting and gives good xp
UI interface is adjustable, and has a clean design
This game is visually Beautiful
Life skills give you plenty to do while also giving income
Lots of bosses and mobs for PVE, duels, raids and node wars for PVP.
Seasonal Servers make it really fast to hit soft cap
All the free stuff you could Ever want, including Pets, horses, inventory space, costumes, ect.
Cons: When you first start playing, can be a bit overwhelming. Need to watch lots of YouTube for this !!
The questing  is sometimes to much talk and fetch, cook, ect.
First time you fight boss you cant see the health bar of that boss. this is because you dont have the knowledge of the boss yet
Choosing the life skills you want  to level up can take time, and can be very costly.
The RNG upgrades of the boss armor n weapons can be  frustration Start with a Season charter and you get free gear that after you graduate you will be able to exchange for  better gear. Again, watching YouTube vids will be a big help. 

 Is game P2W? I would have to say yes and no. in the past maybe, but in the last month game has given away even more free stuff, including a Dream Horse with gear, the Tent winch make grinding a lot easier, and so much more.  Even extra inventory for storing all the free stuff. 
If you have every wanted to play BDO, now is the time,!
I hope you decide to play BDO an enjoy the game as much as I do!

Notable reasons I gave this game a negative review.

Can expect to spam quests for first 5-6 hours of gameplay, skipping loads of dialogue and progressing though a mundane storyline that is neither challenging nor interesting.

In MMORPGs, you generally want to be able to get various sets of armor, loot dungeons, and so on.   There are just two sets of armor in this game... Naru (beginner armor) and Tuvala (non-beginner armor).   They look identical to eachother.   You will be wearing this set of gear for basically the whole game.  When i found this out, I decided to log off and never play again.

The majority of this game is mounting up onto your horse, auto-travelling to next location, spamming quest, and maybe killing 100-150 monsters to complete the quest.   The combat is very basic, just spam your attacks.   Hold down left mouse for basic attacks and then spam your skills when their cooldown is ready.  Really nothing more to it.   Extremely disappointed in this game.

Has kept my quite engaged compared to other MMOs. Many different ways to play and things to focus on that makes almost every player's experience unique which is one thing many of the MMOs today lack in. Overall for a dollar on sale, or ten without a discount, you do not really lose a lot. Always worth trying out, especially if you are looking for a game to keep you invested in it off and on long-term. You can take weeks worth of breaks from this game and still come back without having the feeling of being too far behind compared to other players. I really enjoy it.

This game holds a special place in my heart. There are a lot of great things about it, BUT there are also some not so great things..

Starting with the good:

The Combat system is absolutely fantastic. The attacks flow together so smoothly and leads a very satisfying experience.

The Graphics are some of the best I've seen in gaming, definitely the best of all the MMOs I've played.

The Map, and the traversal around the world is very fun, and a pretty different take compared to its competitors.

The Contribution Point system (that I will not try to explain in this review) is great.

The bad: 

The Pay2Win. If you're reading this, you've probably heard of it. They have toned it down A LOT in recent time, but the monetization is still not in an amazing spot. 

Starting Late. Starting BDO at this current moment is probably the most accessible to newer players it's ever been, but if you go into the game expecting to become one of the top PvP players without spending money at this point, BDO is probably not the game for you.

Progression Pacing. It's a marathon, not a sprint. The reason you will see people have several thousands of hours played on this game, and not gotten all that far is because the progression is incredibly slow-paced (for better or worse). They do add a lot of catch-up mechanics to the game though, so if you're a newer player you get caught up to a certain point pretty quickly.

Content Drought. This game is a Korean MMO. And they cater towards the korean playerbase first and foremost. So if you're playing in a region other than KR, you WILL have to wait a long time for the new content updates to reach your server (we're talking expansions dropping like 6 months later in some cases) because they do not take the time to prepare the content drop for worldwide. 


All in all, this game is not for everybody, and I feel a little bad about recommending it. But, if you read all this and still feel intrigued to try out the game, I say go for it. The strengths of this game are (in my opinion) so extreme that they outweigh the cons.

Updated: November 25th 2023:
Got back into BDO recently after catching up on all the latest Warframe content. Black Desert is still an excellent option when you want an open world MMO that remains to be the best combat of any mmorpg out there. Its actually better now. My first gripe about this game is the classes are gender-locked! Now, after trying this game again, which I had gotten completely free, I was appalled by the fact I could NOT change my UI till level 10, like....WHY?! I mean, every other game in literal existence allows me to change my UI but I need to be level 10 to make it so I can actually see everything im doing? What is this trashy game design? Like my gosh, that NEEDS to change, it is a huge no. However, I did power through it and did get to lvl 10 to adjust the UI. After I was actually able to start playing the game properly without everything in my way, I did have fun with the PvE combat. So far I have not encountered forced open world PvP which is a plus but I am not sure since I am in the beginning of the game. It would be a major killer for me if there is, since the combat is so nice.

So, where to even begin. I guess the most important thing here is that this is certainly not the MMO for everybody. This MMO manages to pack in something for every kind of player out there, but that actually doesn't mean it will appeal to everyone

Pros (+):
- Beautiful graphics and scenery
- Incredibly extensive character creator
- Events in which you can receive for nothing, among other things: pet
- Increasing the number of slots in your eq by doing main missions
- Ability to create your trading empire by hiring workers
- Very many ways to play: trading, grinding, gathering, cooking, alchemy, etc.
- Dynamic combat system that is focused on different combos
- No items in the item shop that give bonuses like: attack damage, etc.
- Expanded guild system (payout system, wars for territories, guild skils).
- Wars at sea involving cannons and pirates
- A showcase world map
- Economy is controlled by players (but prices mostly stick close to a certain amount)
- Items from is can sometimes be found at the market at affordable prices, but very rarely

Cons (-):
- No pay2win, but pets strongly facilitate the game in a later phase by collecting loot for us.
- It takes some time to learn everything, what and how etc.
- From time to time there are small lags on servers
- Lack of dungeons we know from other games of this type
- Lack of fast travel options (there is a traveler's map, but it has a big cooldown, and besides, you need to own it)
- Quite high prices of is items
- No exchange directly with players, in most cases
- Too much RNG (randomness)

Overall rating: 9/10

This game has its ups and downs. I like this game a lot and I think the pros outweigh the cons when it comes to PvE and PVP. 

If you are a PvE focused player this game is great, and offers an almost endless progression where YOU choose what to do next. The gear progression is pretty rough at times and RNG plays heavy in enhancements. The fact you can play with friends and grind to get upgrades has kept me around with the hope that PVP gets fixed.

If you're a PvP enthusiast this games combat and the different classes provide you a way to show off your skills, but at the same time will find that the developer hates this part of the community as it constantly tries to limit the PVP content because they think this is what is desired. The main PVP content used to be open world but now very limited to Node war.

I think if you enjoy PvE with a side of organized PVP this game is perfect. If you are only here for PVP it can be rough for you due to the developer.

Overall rating - [8/10] - The game has massive potential to be a game you enjoy if you can get past the garbage new player experience.

_______________________________
_____________Pros______________
-You can cop it for like 5$ on sales or even for free
-Good graphics
-Best combat system out of any mmo hands down
-Open world with great scenery
-There's forced PvP (you can flag up and attack anyone above lvl 56 outside of safe zone)
-There is quite a lot to do in the game*
-20+ classes with play styles ranging from one handed boomer to cracked out zoomer
-The game is much more new player friendly allowing someone to gear up in seasonal in under a week and make competitive money compared to end game grindspots*
______________________________
_____________Cons______________
-There is quite a lot to do in the game*
-Cash shop is pretty incentivized but its not that overpowered, basically buy a 50$ item from shop + the game for 5$ on sale and u have a 55$ price tag
-A good bit of the content is surface level, or forgotten about and obsolete
-There seems to be a large disconnect between the developers and the NA/EU community (even though NA/EU is the majority of Pearl Abyss' income)
-In game if your fps is around 200, you move faster and your animations go off faster than if you were at 60fps, thus allowing more overall dps by just having a superior PC
-This game has hella spaghetti code that allows for two players with 14 ping to still experience desync
-Even though u can gear up quick the new player experience is horrible*

Glad I tried this game out. This is my new MMORPG. Not nearly as P2W as it once was long ago. Now its pay for appearance and convenience items. Buffs on paid items are rather negligible and wont affect game-play. Fantastic looking graphics, though it could use some polish when it comes to apparel clipping through stuff. Season servers / Novice servers are NOT PvP and the rest of the servers ARE PvP. Your season character is locked to a certain extent of gear progression and you may only have 1 Season character. You aren't required to ever "graduate" your character and remain on season servers for as long as you wish. Also: you can freely change servers at any time with the exception of non-season characters not being allowed to hop over to Season servers. I have been thoroughly enjoying this Open world MMORPG in the 4 months I've been playing!

Edit: Most of the free player leaved the game due to the heavy grinding mechanic (at least this is what i think, based on the server chat) so now the game is mostly back to normal, except for the daily/weekly mass PvP (nodewar/siege) on which you can experience the same lag as before.
Long story short, I'll make some examples to make you understand the situation: on 4/05/2020 nodewar servers were totally offline, the day after the nodewar server were so laggy that doing PvP was not possible and no one got the victory, on saturday (Siege day) PvP started an hour late because people kept disconnecting..

2023 - youp, my old review (below) still stands.
---
So, I've played a bit and I think that I'm ready to finally post a short 'review' of the game.

In BDO you will never be bored. Never-ever. There's always something to do, either improve your equipment or sail the endless horizon, or discover new locations or train your mounts or get into one of many professions (life skill) and try out one of hundreds of recipes for your [i]magic blue potion[/i] or ...there's too much to list here.

This game is very addictive and [b]very[/b] heavy on your wallet (especially if you do not earn in USD or EUR). I would not say that it is P2W, as I was invested around 800h of game play before I decided to use my wallet and I was managing just fine.

[b]STORY (LORE):[/b]
If you're familiar with Lineage II story - it's not that good. If you're familiar with BnS story - you'll see some similarities, yet it's quite different.
Is it any good ? - I'd say 'yes'. It's not a masterpiece in any means, but it's quite catchy and the script is pretty good written (even though there are some cliche').
Is it long ? - the main quest line took me 5 days (18h per day) on my season character, with a side quest here and there ;) It was not a speed run and I was reading / watching every cut scene and treating it mostly like an interactive book than a game.

The side quests are pretty awesome, they will give you more insight into what was really going on in the background of main events and sometimes even they'd present you with crucial info. that'd help you making your decisions later. Yes - you can choose your own path (to some extend ofc.)
I'll be honest - I find the side questing and side story-lines more enjoyable than the main one; especially in case of few NPC's that I feel like I've made bond with (I know how that sounds lol).

[b]GAMEPLAY:[/b]
You can be whoever you want to be. You can do whatever you want to do.
...yea, basically that'd sum it up.

[b]GRAPHICS:[/b]
Remastered. That's your aim.
It still looks pretty decent on lower settings, but to get the most of the beautiful and breathtaking scenery - you'll need to be able to run it on Remastered. Absolutely gorgeous.

[b]CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION:[/b]
As some of you already know - I'm a junkie for a good editor.
Black Desert offers one of the best ones out there. It still does lack in regard to the hair customization and the hair physics are broken, but you can't have everything, right ? ;)

Oh, the servers should be up by now, so let's wrap it up with a...
[b]SUMMARY:[/b]
It's one of the best MMORPG out there, and even though it have its own issues - it is definitely worth to try.

Black Desert Online is an immersive MMORPG renowned for its stunning graphics and dynamic combat system. Its open-world exploration offers endless adventure, complemented by unparalleled character customization that allows players to leave their mark in this vast, living world. The game offers a plethora of activities, from intense battles to mastering life skills like fishing and trading, ensuring constant excitement. A vibrant community enhances the social experience, while consistent updates from the developers keep the gameplay fresh. For those in search of a rich and engaging MMORPG, Black Desert Online is a gem waiting to be discovered.

Pros:
- Stunning Graphics: Black Desert Online boasts breathtaking visuals, creating a visually immersive gaming experience.

- Dynamic Combat System: The game features an action-oriented combat system that adds excitement and skill-based gameplay to encounters.

- Open-World Exploration: The vast and detailed open world provides a sense of adventure, with numerous locations to explore and discover.

- Extensive Character Customization: Players can create highly detailed and unique characters, allowing for a personalized gaming experience.

- Diverse Activities: From intense battles against monsters and other players to life skills like fishing, trading, and crafting, there's a wide range of activities to engage in.

- Active Community: A vibrant player community contributes to the social aspect of the game, providing opportunities for cooperation and competition.

- Regular Updates: Developers consistently release updates, ensuring that the game stays fresh with new content and improvements.

Cons:
- Learning Curve: The game can have a steep learning curve, especially for newcomers, due to its complex systems and features.

- Grind-heavy Gameplay: Some players may find the leveling and progression system to be grind-intensive, requiring time and effort to advance.

- Performance Demands: The game's high-quality graphics may pose performance challenges for some computers, requiring good hardware for optimal gameplay.

- PvP Imbalance: The PvP aspect of the game can be challenging for newcomers, and there may be perceived imbalances in certain encounters.

[h2]Dynamic World: 🌞🌧️[/h2]
The world of Black Desert feels alive with its day-night cycle, dynamic weather, and a variety of activities to pursue. Black Dessert is one of the deepest and most complex games that I have ever seen. There are countless things that you can do, and there are even hundreds/thousands of hours worth of things to do if you don't want to do the PvE grind or even the PvP. You can play however you want, and you can try all sorts of different systems. The biggest issue with this is the lack of many tutorials which makes the overwhelming flood of information pretty insane, but Pearl Abyss has been doing an excellent job of making QoL changes since other MMORPGs like FF14 started to dominate the market. FF14 was the best thing to happen to BDO. To make up for the overwhelming amount of stuff, watch the plethora of helpful people on Youtube, but take care of toxic MMO players that can really rip noobs a new one. 

Because BDO can be played at your own speed, there doesn't feel like there are any problems with taking long breaks if you get bored. But with the constant changing seasons with expedited progression, new items, new ways to progress your gear, events, and the upcoming class reworks, it keeps the game fresh and inviting,

Edit: 300 hours later and while I don't play as often, the game still draws me back every so often.
Time well spent

After playing thousands of hours, being through most of the games content through out the years, i can only say this:
If you're looking for "MMORPG" in which u mostly do everything solo, the game is for you.
The game used to have alot of decent pvp aspects like going in negative karma, declaring wars to guilds to fight them(now its gone), alot of open world pvp (now its completely dead). For end game you have absolutely nothing to do as a pvp player, Sieges are purely politics (ppl choose who to fight so you have 1v1's only). Your gear doesnt matter much anymore because most instanced pvp's have caps to ap/dp. 
Pve in this game consists of endless grinding in one circle. Every new MAJOR update is just dead after 1-2 weeks because its mostly just a new grindspot to run around circles once again. 
For lifeskills u might find the game a bit better than pve/pvp, theres a bit more different to do for lifeskilling.
For years we've been trying to give feedback to the developers and they just dont CARE. The only region they listen feedback from is korea.

Updating my review now that I have 9000 hours in this game. It's still great and getting even better. The old review below is still relevant. 

---

I am updating my review on this game due to how much the game has changed. The game used to be playable for easily over 1000 hours before you hit any pay to win elements. They have removed a ton of that, if not all. They have seasons now that let new players catch up to veterans pretty fast. You can reach "nearly end game" quality gear from a season, but still left with room to advance if you are chasing combat power. The in game shop only sells things for convenience, and nowadays they offer in game methods to acquire all the same items. The in game methods are not extreme in any way and are very easily obtainable. The only people really spending money on the in game shop are those who want a special cosmetic, or those too impatient to wait a week or two to get the item for free in game. The items I am referring to are things like a tent to repair your armor on the go, pets to pick up loot or provide very small buffs, a horn to call your horse from further away and so on. None of the items are game breaking and are all obtainable in game also. 

They give TONS of stuff away for free. Just having an account and checking in every so often ensures your account piles up with free stuff waiting for when you come back from a break. They even sometimes give the entire game away for free when it's not already just 5 dollars to buy. At some point they have given me just about every in game shop item for free and some of them I've received dozens. My account received so many free paid for cosmetic outfits that I actually destroyed a lot of them to get the materials. I currently have over 120 days worth of the free VIP account buffs like traveler's pack and old moon book all received for free. 

Moving on, a lot of people who do not like this game are not used to open sandbox games. The game is split into Combat and Life skill. People who focus on combat and nothing else will find the gameplay loop gets repetitive fast. If you go farm for money to work on gear upgrades you may end up farming the same 1 spot repeatedly for hours because it's the best spot YOU can do currently. It can take weeks to get enough to finish 1 upgrade. You upgrade combat gear to go to a harder spot in the future or for pvp. To most people it doesn't seem rewarding. That's because it's only a small part of what you are supposed to be doing. 

The entire game is very quickly accessible by everyone so people get lost on what they are "supposed to do". You are supposed to do nothing, but you GET to do anything There are in game systems to let you run essentially a company or empire of npcs who gather resources for you, intricate life skill systems for breeding better mounts, fishing, cooking, alchemy, house decorating, sailing, bartering between islands, transporting and trading goods, and especially combat and pvp. If you are not interested in dabbling or playing a bit in all aspects then you may find your gameplay loop repetitive. It really is sort of a slice of life game where you get to decide how to play and co-exist in a world where other people are doing the same. 

The game is absolutely beautiful and to this day may be the best mmo out in terms of graphics. In terms of combat, there is no other game that is still active at the time of this review that even compares to the combat system that BDO offers. It's incredibly smooth and very satisfying. All characters/classes are viable and you really can just choose which one feels best to you with no worries. The game is incredibly immersive and if you play other mmo's you may be shocked how so many little things make the world feel so much better. Rotted wood texture in fishing towns, running through water or puddles gets your boots wet but not your shirt, rain wetting the road and your clothes, snow piling up on your horse saddle, so many other well down subtle aspects make it great to explore the world and find all the hidden areas. The desert and open ocean have their own struggles to navigate which makes traveling have more weight to your decisions. You see someone somewhere remote and know they had a similar experience and struggle to get there. 

Overall the game is great and it's way better now than it ever was before now.

Let's update this shall we? So. Black Desert. 

 At face value the game can be daunting. It's completely open world, different combat zones, pvp, and life skills to do, without a real point in a direction. You gotta figure it out yourself. BUT! The game is amazing. For all the hours I've put in, I've never really put the game down. You can buy cosmetics you can sell in the in-game market for silver, but don't let that get you thinking it's Pay 2 Win. It's not. Black Desert can be played at YOUR PACE without having to spend a dime. From graduating the new permanent season to tapping your first PEN boss gear the game is a blast. 10/10 would recommend. Black Desert Online

9.2/10 MMORPG

I used to play this game for the first time back in 2014 in KR Closed Beta.
I managed to play in EU closed beta and after like 1 year in EU and 2 years from KR I might say is one of the TOP-BEST played MMORPG's i ever played.

World
At the first sights is alive and so close to a real edge of the world, game used to happen in a fantasy Europe in XVII century.

Gameplay
As an MMORPG it has quest,combat,skills,gear and many more...
Introducing life skilling... what this actually means?
Gathering,Processing,Cooking,Alchemy,Training,Fishing,Hunting,Trading,Farming,Sailing and soon Wall Climbing and many more sport-adventure based coming in the next big expansions.

Combat
Fast-paced smooth,lots of effects and feels so nice and such a pleasure.
Combat with mobs is not target based is free-based like an hack and slash.

Characters (Costumization + Own persoanllity wannabe)
A feature that's actually one of the bests inside the game..... also is the only game in the world i might say that has such a vast costumization.

Community
Here comes a bit sad abou but depends of you mostly... I'm an EU veteran and i used to play in KR,NA.
EU = helpfull people but also trolls and savage ones..
NA = well anybody could help you..
KR = helpfull and also.. if lvl 60+ most of the people are just tryharding because KR.. but still good..

Graphics
Amazing and is so near the reality... no more words..
But some anti aliasing + some more effects and some Very High textures won't hurt anyone right?

B2P and P2W?
Is worth to buy the game to support development besiedes that in KR is free to play but for others outside KR, you will need to pay 10E/$ to buy an acc so... no reasons...

P2W?
No way in EU/NA but in KR P2W it seems ok for them so..
Is not P2W in EU ?
Yep i played for a lot of time so i assure you ...
Why?
Pearl shop sellers could sell only 35 pearl items and max value in market is 355 mil 355x35 = 12.B l not a huge amount of money i assure you dear players..
But that 12 Bil ...?
And what ? Everyboy has a chance to get that pearl shop items i assure you, I own over 35+ outfits on and also 3 value packs + lots of dyes... (I spent over 950 mil on all of those from marketplace) yeah you spent hours/days but is worth..

Classes 
Actually this MMORPG has 20 awesome classes all being pretty well balanced and owning a pretty nice persoanllity & lore.

Warrior: Longsword + Shield + an Awakening Weapon: Greatsword
Ranger: Bow + Dagger + an Awakening Weapon: Kamasylven Sword
Sorceress: Amulet + Talisman + an Awakening Weapon: Scythe
Berserker: Double axe + Knot + an Awakening Weapong: Iron Buster (Hand Canon)
Tamer:
Valkyrie
Musa
Maehwa
Ninja
Kunoichi
Wizzard
Witch
Dark Knight
Striker
Lahn
Archer
Shai
Guardian
Hashashin

Skills & Gear

Lots of skills which are on categorized in 2 types:
Normal and Awakening
There is a new feature of 2020 called "Succession" an upgraded version of Pre-Awakening or (Normal) mostly made up for PvE
Also this game requiers lots of knowledge in knowing other classes combos+skills and also to learn some very critical combos on your main classes.

Gear is mostly a main thing in this game as others RPG's.
Is based by 4 colors/rank-quality color.
White/None = Common
Green = Uncomon
Blue = Mid-rare
Yellow = Rare
Orange/Red = Legendary 

Game World & Exapansions

At first around 2016 game came up with the expansion up to only Calpheon, later on around Spring end of 2016 there was Mediah Expansion released, alongside in the end of summer was Valencia Expansion and Awakening until the end of December 2016 also in november 2016 there was the first phase of ocean content, called Margoria.
In 2017 there were many other changes, Kamasylve is released just at the begging of October 2017, around that in November we get the Vell Expansion.

2018 Comes just strong as is releasing in just November the Drieghan release alongside Archer class.

2019 May to July comes with 2 medium size expansions one at the month, Sycaria and Black Star (Star's End) also Shai is released.

In 2020, 7 October we are going to get the O'dyllita expansion one of the biggest and hardest content produced for now in BDO at the time of 2020.

As of 2023, I went casually but game greatly impoved in terms of P2W, classes, balance and content, we even had dungeons something that in 2017 I have not even pictured but imaginated.

BDO is... the definition of quantity over quality.

There is an incredible amount of content in this game, the only thing is that there are also an incredible number of bugs, some of which have existed for years.

Example: The Maegu class was released, but this class was so broken and OP that they had to nerv it, but that wasn't possible because otherwise it would cause a game breakink bug...
so they had to buff ALL the other 25 classes, so that everyone is up again...

Unfinished and broken content is constantly being released, some of which will be completed/fixed years later (T10 Doom, PVP area in Odraxxia, Ship content, Elvia realm, etc.)

Sounds ridiculous, but that's BDO, beautiful and shiny on the outside but behind the scenes a pile of rubbish.

P2W: Yes it is, kind of like Lost Ark just in a different way!

Would I recommend it....

Yes, but only if you don't have an addiction problem with gambling.

There is a ton of free content in this game.
You can have fun for weeks/months, but you should be VERY careful with the cash shop and don't look too closely behind the scenes of the game, because there you will find a pile stuck together with glue and nails!

PLay it for some hours, have fun and move on when the cash shop kicks in!

[h1] I wish my friends would get into this game. [h1]
[h2] PROS: [h2]
[list]
[*]Amazing character creator.
[*]Good graphics for an MMO
[*]Boob sliders. Errybody likes boobies.
[*]A ton of different classes each with 2 specs that you can swap between to get the playstyle you prefer.
[*]Amazing action combat akin to a hack and slash game mixed with fighting game mechanics. Combos are KING.
[*]Great Screenshot mode with control over the time of day, filters, depth of field, camera zoom and tilt, even character poses! Very nice for the screenshot enjoyers out there like myself!
[*]Massive map to explore and enjoy. Even an Ocean which you can sail over and fight sea monsters with ships!
[*]Group dungeons/ Grind zones where you can go as sweaty or chill as you want.
[*]You get a good start on the game with seasonal characters which you get to keep when you max out their gear and keep going on regular gear/servers. Season characters don't wipe like other games traditional seasons.
[*]Player driven economy/market.
[*]Gathering/ Cooking/ Alchemy/ Horse Training/ Other "lifeskills" all play into the market/economy in their own ways.
[*]You can make passive income through AFK activities so if you work a lot you can still make progress. Its not as much as actively playing but its still nice.
[*]Offers a Battle Arena to go and practice your characters skills and combos against training dummies or real players. Be warned though people in there can be kinda... big headed I'll say. Thick skin recommended.
[*]Tons of help out there online for this game.
[*]The best autorun/pathing system. You right click a quest or a place on the map screen, press T and your character will ride/ run there automatically. Its SO convenient!
[*]A fully customizable UI. You can hide so much crap with Customize UI its great! You can even add to the clutter by tracking skill cooldowns, or if you're really feeling devious you can drag everything into a corner overlaying them on top of each other so you can't tell what the hell is going on over there. Its up to you!
[*]Tons of support options through the settings menus. Don't like the crazy screen shake? Turn it down in the camera settings for example.
[*]No sub Just 10$ once and that's it. Free to play viable. Not optimal, but viable.
[*]The gear matched PvP Arena is coming back soon and becoming permanent.
[/list]

[h2] CONS: [h2]
[list]
[*]Endgame gear progression is very slow or luck based. KR MMO very grindy who would've guessed it
[*]It gets lonely doing solo grinding all the time.
[*]Its a pro and a con, but there is a lot to learn and it can be easy to get overwhelmed on what the heck to do early on.
[*]The devs made changes to absolutely kill open world PvP outside of the Arsha Server, and also made it so that you can no longer place a guild war on a person who is being an annoying idiot trying to take your mobs at a grind zone. They can just decline the war so you have to switch servers, go negative karma which has all kinds of bad possibilities attached to it, or ignore them and hope they get bored and go away.
[*]The siege wars are very laggy, not just client side, but the server itself. When everyone gets to the castle its rubberband city.
[*]I cant get an Elten Piece :(
[*]The devs don't know how to buff Kunoichi properly :(

[h3] [i] All in all I like this game a lot and I think the pros outweigh the cons. If you are a PvE focused player this game is great, and offers an almost endless progression where YOU choose what to do next. If you're a PvP enthusiast you will LOVE this games combat and the different outlets they provide for you to show off your skills or just laugh it up in discord with some buddies. It really is something special to me because of all the people I've met through the games' community and the memories we have made. [h3] [i]

It's a very bland, linear grind repetition game with a very well done but ultimately shallow and meaningless repetition combat system, while all the classes look like they're out of a high fantasy ecchi. More thought and effort goes into their cosmetic MTX items than the rest of the game.

The best MMORPG on the market if all you wanna do is grind imo. 

The game has so much stuff to grind, its mindblowing. 
The only downsides are that the game has the worst beginner experience ever. you either need very thick skin or someone to guide you through the game., and it doesnt really offer good raiding content like Lost ark or FF14 does.

BDO is insanely complex, It is basically Path of exile on crack. 

Its also a sandbox mmorpg, meaning u can play at your own pace and it offers way more freedom than themepark mmorpgs.
In this game you choose however you want to play. want to grind mobs in circles for 10 hours in a row? no problem at all. 
want to lifeskill all day and gather mats, then cook them or craft other stuff with it? also no problem.
you can also go out and hunt animals with a matchlock or sail and do many other things. 
Everything gets leveled and becomes more profitable over time.
The more active play something requires, the more profit it will net you generally speaking. 
It goes to the point of being completely afk like fishing which gives u few amounts of money, but its basically an idle game at that point and you can play something else while still progressing in BDO. 

Also worth mentioning is how lifeskilling also has its own level and gear progression, which is on a similar level as the combat gear progression. 

No matter how you wanna grind, BDO will offer something for you.
If you dont wanna grind, then stay away, but if you are into grinding, then i recommend you to get through the miserable beginner experience and learn how the game works. only then you can judge this game. it may end up being your favorite

Only MMO since Guild Wars that's kept me playing and enjoying my time while doing so. BDO is a long form progression game, so if you're someone who needs instant gratification, it won't be for you. But if you're someone who likes having lots of stuff to do and enjoys the process, you'll have a great time.

Nowadays, Pay to Win is almost completely dead and non existent in this game, so anyone still telling you the game is P2W is either lying or hasn't played in years. The devs have been making massive and actually positive changes to the game for the last couple years now and show no sign of stopping. You never have to pay for the new classes when they release, nor do you have to pay for the new expansions to the map when those release. The game does a good enough job of being a good game that I didn't feel bad about buying myself some cosmetics from the shop, but they give those same cosmetics away for free during events all the time, so you really don't even have to pay for those either. 

All in all, it's a fun game that I'm willing to pour even more hours into. Would recommend.

I'm honestly not a huge fan, but before going into it's flaws I'll talk about the few good things. First and foremost- the effects. Truthfully, I've never seen a game that had abilities and moves that look as cool or as fun as they do in this game. Second- the moves. Each character has a ridiculous amount of moves they can do that are exclusive to their class, there are a lot of moves and therefor a lot of controls to memorize which something I personally enjoy. Third- the price. This game is usually only $10 but goes on sale for less than that quite frequently, meaning that it's a good game to maybe dump and hour or two into every once in a while if you're bored and don't have anything else to play. These are (in my opinion) the only redeeming qualities of this game.
      I've personally always thought the idea of fighting with your fists and training nothing but your body was a cool concept. And I was delighted when I found out that there was a character that allowed me to do precisely that. But he sucks, his fighting style is clunky and in his awakening, he starts to rely on magic which completely ruins the whole point of being a pugilist and just fighting with your fists. Learning how badly they fumbled him crushed me to no end, they took something I love, destroyed what I love most about it, and made him so bad that he isn't even a viable character.
      Despite the combat and abilities looking cool and fun, they are not. The game's too easy, the mobs die in seconds and most of the time they don't even get the chance to hit you, and in the off chance they do manage to get close and hit you, it hardly does any damage. Some people like to play games that make you feel overpowered, but this game doesn't even do that- You hit something a few times and it dies, but you don't feel powerful. Killing an enemy is tedious and doesn't feel rewarding in any way.
      The combat isn't fun, I've tried 4 different characters and none of them had combat that kept the game interesting for more than the time it took me to learn the moves. When you hit something, it doesn't even feel like you hit it. When you fight using melee characters, it's hard to land moves consecutively because the moves themselves move your character too much and you need to completely stop your attacks in order to reposition you character so you can actually hit them.
As for the story, there really isn't one. You run around doing other people's jobs while coincidentally progressing the main story even though you literally haven't done anything remotely related to what your characters "objective" is. The voice acting is atrocious and the the mouths of the NPCs move randomly. There's no rhyme or reason behind the body language used by the NPCs in conversation either, just senseless flailing.
      The combat in this game is what I hate the most, but right after that are the characters themselves- more specifically, the gender lock. I prefer to play male character in most games, but this game doesn't give me that choice. If there's a character you like, then you're stuck playing that character as whatever gender the game decided to make them. Some characters have a male and a female counterpart that you can choose from, but even then it's not the same because the only thing they share is general character idea. Take the pugilist I love for example, there's both a male and a female pugilist, but practically none of there moves are the same. They have great customization in every other regard, but they are sorely lacking in the one of the most basic and important forms of character creation.
      The game looks cool and had the potential to be good, but they fumbled in almost every way imaginable. I find myself coming back to this game from time to time because I think of what it could have been, and every time I'm met with disappointment.

The heart of Black Desert Online is its ability to immerse you in its world. Whether you're engaging in breathtaking horseback rides across sprawling landscapes, participating in breathtaking castle sieges, or trading in bustling marketplaces, the world feels alive and real. The day-night cycle and weather effects add a layer of immersion, and the NPC AI routines make the world feel dynamic and lived-in.

Considering the MMO market is rather small: is this game good? Yes it is. The combat is still awesome. Graphics are still amazing. Character customization is still really good. Game is still Pay2Win (with significant diminishing returns 'this is coming from a Raid Shadow Legends player'). 
Probably the main reason to play this game is the world chat. It still has that chaos, stupid, braindead Barren's chat. And God i miss those days.
Probably the biggest problem with this game is sometimes you might ask yourself "why am I grinding for hours?" The answer may be hard to find.
Combat is still one of the best in the entire Genre.

It's very pretty, and voice acting isn't bad, but it's so confusing.  Every time something new happens, I had to google to figure out how to do it.  The only tutorial is how to move (WASD).  Everything else is sink or swim.  I've made it to level 20, which I know isn't very far, but I STILL don't know how to efficiently do combat.  I know a lot of people play, and I know a lot of people love the game, it's just not for me.
If you have a lot of free time, then go for it when its on sale. If no, avoid it.

I use to really hate this, I tried it when it first launched and it was terrible the way not only it was monetized but how it overall rewarded your time. Now the game still has problems. Tons of currencies and stuff which comes with games structured like this to extract cash from you that the game really doesn't deserve. 

All that being said, you can have a lot of fun in BDO. If they streamlined it and removed a lot of the currencies and stuff this would be much more successful. But the grind for some of these items and feeling like you have to use the cash shop really puts a damper on a lot of players sticking around. Now BDO has changed a lot for the better. I love it for that. It's a beautiful game with a community that is pretty neat. I love that there is personal housing and you can buy anywhere you want. That is amazing and the farming. I really like being a profession person. I like running around on my SHAI and gathering everything up and crafting. The node system could be used in way more games and the sailing is pretty refreshing and cool. as well. I wish more games did stuff like this. However this doesn't appeal to the more casual side. But you can be casual in here. There are many guides on it.

So I gave this game a shot. A week worth of play. I have to say it is overwhelming to come into 7 years of game out of the blue. I wanted to customize a cool character and that was played out pretty quickly. One thing they must fix for that is the EYE color palates. One of the main eye colors you can't scroll down and see all the colors. Very irritating. But I still made a good looking character and started to play. As for the game itself. The story was interesting at first. But very quickly it gets played out. You just press R for every quest. No matter what you are doing besides random fights where you kill everything in one hit you just press R, everywhere you go R R R R. By the time I cleared the first continent I was around lvl 43. Then it basically stops telling you where to go and when you figure out how to teleport to the new area, everything is way lower level than you are. Even if I run all the way over to where mobs are my level, I kill them in 1 hit, there is no challenge. No quests in those areas. It feels like a mobile game that was slapped onto the computer, which players in game tell me it is. One thing that I do like about this game is the auto run feature though. They did a great job with navigating to quests when you have them and being able to watch a show or something on another screen while it runs. I really do like that they did that. It helps a lot. I would never have played this long if it didn't have that. Seems to be a helpful community and plenty of people playing. The chat is full of random conversations that are interesting. But very quickly this game burned me out. There just isn't enough involvement in the actual game to get into it. If you decide to play this game, I recommend joining a guild right off the bat, and joining a discord and having them help you with questions. There is just too much content in the game for me to figure out what everything is or try to search every last little item and it's function to warrant the time investment. Cool game, but I'm giving this one a pass. Didn't Die ONCE. Not even close.

Ah, where do I even begin? It's like a never-ending rollercoaster ride that only goes downhill, and not in a good way. If you're looking for a game that will consume your life, drain your wallet, and make you question your life choices, then look no further – Black Desert is here to ruin your day!

Let's talk about character creation, shall we? It's so detailed that you'll spend hours perfecting your virtual alter ego's nose hair, only to realize that you'll be wearing a helmet most of the time. Who needs facial features anyway, right? But hey, if you ever decide to take off that helmet, you'll have the most magnificent nose hairs in all of the gaming world.

Now, let's not forget the joy of grinding in Black Desert. You can spend weeks tirelessly slaughtering thousands of the same mobs, just to progress slightly in the game. It's like Groundhog Day, but instead of Bill Murray, you have your character endlessly slaughtering poor defenseless critters. I'm sure your character will need some serious therapy by the time you're done.

And the quest system, oh boy! You'll be asked to kill 10,000 wolves, gather a gazillion herbs, or retrieve your neighbor's lost sock – all while the NPCs drone on with their never-ending dialogues. I swear, even my cat lost interest in their tales of woe.

Let's not forget about the pearl shop, where you can buy virtual items that are more expensive than your first car. Want to look like a cool ninja? Better get ready to fork over your rent money for some virtual costume pieces.

And if you think you can just hop in for some casual PVP fun, think again. You'll be obliterated by players who have spent their entire lives in the game, achieving the level of power only rivaled by Marvel superheroes. Good luck surviving those encounters!

Black Desert MMO is like that bad relationship you just can't quit. You'll keep coming back, hoping things will get better, but they won't. It's a game that will make you question your life choices, your sanity, and your financial responsibility.

In conclusion, Black Desert MMO is a game that's guaranteed to suck the joy out of your life, drain your wallet, and turn you into a virtual nose hair perfectionist. But hey, at least it's good for a laugh... as long as you're not the one playing it.

Overall, Black Desert Online was an incredibly entertaining game "in its time," but many players feel that the imbalance in grinding, pay-to-win elements, and a lack of content development have made the gameplay experience feel boring in the current year
1.Excessive Grind: The game is notorious for its high grind, where players must spend a significant amount of time performing repetitive, routine tasks. This can make the experience feel monotonous and dull.
2.Pay-to-Win Elements: While the game was not originally pay-to-win, over the years, more pay-to-win elements have been introduced, such as stat-boosting items that can be purchased with real money, potentially disrupting game balance.
3.Lack of Content Development: Despite the variety of content offered, some players feel that the developers have not given enough attention to existing content and have been more focused on monetizing the game.

Rewriting this since I started playing again. Been playing for a couple of months now and liking it again.

Positive
- Big open world with no loading screens, which is expanded on a yearly basis or so
- You can keep progressing over time starting with your gear progression and then later on you can grind for various QoL perks like infinite potions and permanent market place tax reduction.
- Open world PvP (not for new players/season instances). Chase people away from your PvE spot by flagging up and whacking them over their fucking head!
- They are currently improving and implementing permanent sPvP.
- Devs play the game themselves and listen to the community (not that they always hit home with their changes, but at least they try)
- Very wide range of ways to play and enjoy this game everything from lifeskilling (sailing, horse training, alchemy, hunting, fishing, lumbering, gathering, farming), enhancing, PvP, PvE.
- Sandbox like large scale PvP where players fight for nodes and regions to obtain guild-wide buffs for a period of time.
- Endgame where you can grind for what you feel like and get good at what you want.
- Fighting-game-like inputs for combat

Cons / Reasons I quit last time:
- Had a very slow job that took a lot of time and didn't feel like spending my remaining time grinding. I now have a job with more action and find it nice to chill with BDO after work.
- Flavor of the year classes, some classes clearly remain superior for a long time. Feels bad when you know the class you enjoy is a dumpster fire and everyone else can grind faster with less actions per minute than you.
-  Power creep and catch-up mechanics are a natural part of this game for better or for worse.

while boasting stunning graphics and an immersive open world, sadly falls short in several key aspects, primarily due to its toxic community. My journey in this game has been a rollercoaster of frustration, thanks to the less-than-welcoming player base.

The in-game world is breathtaking, with a level of detail that is truly awe-inspiring. The character customization options are unparalleled, and the combat system offers a satisfying blend of action and strategy. Yet, beneath this beautiful veneer lies a community that has made my gaming experience more bitter than sweet.

Toxicity among players is unfortunately not an uncommon sight in Black Desert Online. Whether you're a new player trying to find your footing or a seasoned veteran seeking help, you may encounter a barrage of unsolicited insults, elitism, and condescension from others. This hostility can be discouraging for newcomers, making it difficult for them to enjoy the game and progress.

The in-game chat channels are rife with derogatory comments, and it's not uncommon to witness players arguing over trivial matters. It's disheartening that the toxic behavior isn't confined to one particular aspect of the game but is instead pervasive across various channels, from general chat to guild interactions.

While I understand that online gaming communities can be challenging, the level of toxicity in Black Desert Online often surpasses what one might expect. Rather than fostering a welcoming environment that encourages new players to explore and enjoy the game, this community does the opposite. It perpetuates a hostile atmosphere that can detract from the enjoyment of the game itself.

In conclusion, Black Desert Online is a visually stunning and immersive MMORPG that is marred by the negative aspects of its player community. While the game itself has much to offer, it's essential to consider the impact of the toxic community on your overall gaming experience. If you can overlook the community and focus solely on the game's content, you may still find enjoyment here, but be prepared to navigate the minefield of negativity that often surrounds it.

Being one of the seemingly more popular MMOs on the market I decided to give Black Desert Online a try because I've been looking for a game to scratch the high fantasy itch I have right now. After spending three hours trying to play through an absolutely boring, rambling quest line I finally gave up trying because by then it became clear that BDO is not what I'm looking for. The character creation is alright but honestly not quite as amazing as hyped. There are a lot of little details to edit but it's not worth the trouble because anything beyond the defaults start looking disproportionate and uncanny real quick. BDO's combat is also highly praised but from my experience it's just a matter of mashing different keys to perform various attacks that look cool but have no real strategy to them from a gameplay perspective. Ultimately I may have been able to overlook/get used to some of these criticisms if the main quest line wasn't such an uninteresting slog.

This game is great if you're the kind of person who enjoys the power fantasy of stuff like Dragonball and just mowing through enemy after enemy, and it's the best at what it does because the power fantasy is pure dopamine. Currently, the game is experiencing a resurgence bigger than ever before due to two newer classes a long-anticipated region, and southern mediah on its way. The black desert map is almost completely filled thus entering new territory likely thereafter. If you've been hesitant to try the game I can fully recommend this game now as it's in much better hands than it was many years ago with a positive stream of updates and more passion shown to it in recent years than it has ever seen in it's lifetime. As someone who enjoys both FFXIV and Runescape, this game ticks that third box as a strong third alternative. Simply put bdo is the best in class at what it aims to do, and that is be a flashy action combat MMORPG where you mow down hordes of enemies. If this is something that appeals to you then you won't be disappointed.

I have 10k hours so that's a thing...
The game is a korean grinder with a somewhat aggressive cash shop, so depends if you know your limits or not.

Game is not a theme park mmo, so as soon as you are done with the tutorial story you need to decide what you want to do, this is a problem for some since they need to be led about.

This game is a completely open world mmo so you can actually pick a direction and go there, you don't need to finish all the story to unlock different areas of the map, although you may get walloped :D
Following the black spirit quest line as a new player is the best idea, with a season character.

However there is an overwhelming amount of stuff to do and grind for, as the veterans always say BDO is a marathon not a sprint.

The main thing that first attracted me to BDO was the horse training which is surprisingly complicated, the horse animations and skills are very satisfying to use. The mounts also don't spawn out of your characters butt like in most games, when you dismount they are still there in the world, which I think is wonderfully immersive. 
There is also all the other usual lifeskills such as gathering, farming, cooking, alchemy, sailing, fishing, hunting, trading and bartering.

Gaming the economy is not really a thing in this game since max and min price of things is managed by the developers, there is also no player trading so don't expect it to be like EVE or ARCHEAGE in this respect.
BDO also has a pretty good housing system with lots of choices of house locations for convenience, roleplay or simple looks reasons and lots of choices when it comes to furniture items. 
Also there is no large inital cost or lack of housing, and no loss of said house/houses when you have a break from the game, everything is how you left it when you return.
Almost all the cash shop furniture can now be crafted for free now, which is amazing.

The action combat is first rate, I think of all the mmos I have played only TERA has better combat, BDO's mob grinding is better though. 
Which is just as well since grinding mobs is a huge part of the game and can be a decider as to whether you will like the game or not. (nothing like putting on some music and killing thousands of critters)

This game doesn't do dungeons like most mmos do, it has only 3 which are parts of the same dungeon.
Visually they are lovely but I think mechanically they are clunky and the reliance on having to use guides is a problem.
If you have played WOW, Final fantasy or Destiny 2 you will find these raids disappointing in comparison.

BDO has never been known for its story and it still isn't, some of the newest story content is fully voiced and is quite good, however unfortunately some of the earliest story/tutorial is a real slog.

Also the quality of life in this game is through the roof, every option you can think of for turning stuff off or on, or adjusting UI. 
Search bars for items/npcs and all items have a proper description and will have a auto path to the npc they need to go to, on a right click.
The autopathing is a pleasure, the knowledge system is great and contributes to your entire account. 
All of your alts have access to almost everything on your account; storage/mounts/pets, its just one big Family, which is very convenient.

Gearing is actually way easier than it was when I started playing in 2017; with the season servers, its almost obscene how much easier it is now, with benefits new and old players alike, a very good change. 
The upgrading of gear and the system of doing it are pretty complicated and much complained about but the season servers really do act as a great tutorial for how to works and if you'd prefer to just avoid it and just grind and buy what you want from the marketplace.

Cosmetics are some of the best and most detailed in any mmo however the best of them are in the cashshop, so be aware of that if it bothers you. 
The game is very cheap to buy or often free to try with no subscription requirement I don't think its a big deal, there is also ones you can get with a loyalty system/giveaways if you can be patient.
The dye system is extremely good and has many slots to achieve that specific look and is one of the main reasons its nice to have the optional subscription; The value pack.
If you are going to play the value pack is definitely worth having and has a lot of convenience. 
However the game has no required subscription, so you can just login whenever you feel like it.

The character creation is still one of the best in any mmo or even more modern games, which is kinda crazy and you can completely change your characters face or hair if you get sick of it, provided you have the value pack.

BDO is probably the best most complete open world/seamless mmo on the market, only New world looks better graphically.
The areas of the map look like they fit together naturally like they would in real life, some of the cities are actually modelled off real cities.

One thing I like is there is a distinct style as well, they don't try to do everything; horses are the primary mount, very little fast travel; so mounts are actually useful, and no true flying mounts either just gliding. 
The amount of crazy MMO stuff isn't outrageous either, no crazy mounts; flying cars/robots/giraffe monstrosities or ridiculous outfits like final fantasy/Tera. just some usual mmo suspects, battle lingerie being the main culprit, which i'm not opposed to ;)

BDO is one of those games either you love it or hate it, or its a bit of both and you are waiting for a new mmo that never arrives...

I played enough to experience a bit of every part of the game, my biggest complain by far is the p2w aspect, the community is incredibly full of copium about this.

Let me say that i invested some money into the game to see for myself the difference it makes, i understand devs needs to make money somehow but this beyond acceptable, some of the p2w aspects are:

- You get a tent wich gives you a dmg  or lifeskill buff + increased drop rate + repair where you want + a bit of extra inventory space, the tent is huge no matter if you're a mob grinder or lifeskill character (those who make stuff and sell on the market).

- You get enough pets to upgrade all of them to T4 wich in some places doubles your item pickup rate, i tried playing with T1 pets (free ones) and the difference is massive.

- Some pets give lifeskill bonuses like the hedgedog, at T4 that's 50% chance to get double loot from gathering lifeskill, it's broken.

- You can't sell without a valuepack unless you want to get 30% less money, you can buy this item for loyalty points but only about twice per month, this means that you can't sell in the market everyday wich sucks bad if you're a trader since some items have amount cap for selling, for example i make accesories and cant place a buy order bigger than 10 at a time and cant renew my order often since i dont have the valuepack.

- If you decide to whale there's smart whaling wich is insanely profitable (wont mention how to prevent promoting it) and dumb whaling wich is buying stuff from the cash shop and selling it on the market.

- Aside from all this you can directly buy from the cash shop a large amount of items wich might be expensive but doesn't mean it's not p2w.

This is simply unnaceptable, it got the pay once for convinience like PoE wich would be reasonable to a point but on top the game keeps giving you reasons to invest regularly giving a obvios advantage.

Putting all the p2w aside the game is pure grind but has that sense of progression wich keeps you hooked, the main goal would be to make pvp when your gear is good enough but i can already see problems with pvp due to the game design, wont go into full detail but these are: 

1 - Too much damage, from what i've seen 1 cc = 1 kill.
2 - Every skill has super armor (immune to most cc)
3 - Flashy skill spamming all day until you get lucky gameplay, this is due to low skill cooldowns.
4 - Game speed is too fast to react and skills are hard to identify in that short time all gets even worse thanks to effect spam, in consequence people usually just try to guess the opponent next move at best or just spam their rotation.

It's been few years since I first started my adventure in BDO and a lot of hours spent at playing.

The game itself played huge role in MMO scene by taking every possible aspect to another level.
Gameplay is smooth and enjoyable. Combat is fast, challenging and there's a lot to learn about timing and unleashing full potential of your character. Talking about chars we got plenty of those- every single one different and fun to play. As for the world- it is huge, well designed and filled with cosmic amount of possible interactions. I won't talk about graphics, it's something to be experienced personally to trully enjoy such creation.

The most valuable thing is definitely type of gameplay you can choose to participate in. You can either grind, gear up and train yourself at combat or stay calm and enjoy preparing things, selling them and trading for fair cash. You choose your path, your approach to the game and there's nothing standing in your way to achieve certain goals.

As much as people complain about amount of grinding required to achieve something and kinda bad management of Item shop I still think it's for now one of the best titles from MMO category.
Remember the fact that BDO is purely korean game which makes it more grindy. Once again it's not something to be worrying about since at the end of the day only the amount of fun you gained matters.

alright

[h1] MAIN AND SIDE STORY QUESTS ARE GOOD? [/h1]
This game had a pretty good main story for an MMO, yes ''had'' because especially after half of the main questline it becomes unnecessarily complicated and it becomes kind of a big pile of text throwing your way.


[h1] LETS DO THIS! LEROOOOOY JENKINS! [/h1]
This game takes you a lot of time from your life and in return, it gives you big freedom. We have quests and they can easily help you to reach the highest levels but you are free, you can just kill monsters to level up or level up with lifeskilling. You can fight with world BOSS'es every day, they have their own schedule so you can know the exact position and hour they will appear. You can make PVP, fight in little matches or you can join a clan and fight in Clan Wars. You can do trade business. You can become a farmer. You can become a chemist. Wanna chill a little bit? Crate lower-level characters, jump your ship, and go fishing. You wanna do a different thing than a normal MMO burden? But not just chilling, do you want to do some adventurous things as well? Take your high-level character, go fishing, and face lots of PVP players who use highly weaponized ships. Or maybe you want to produce your own horses? Then go hunt wild horses and mate them for new amazing horses. And if you do right all of these things going to give you a lot of in-game money. So while losing lots of time and doing interesting things; you can gain money and use this freedom. But yeah after some time even these things became boring like other MMOs.


[h1] WAIT WAIT WAIT... WHAT DO YOU MEAN BY THIS GAME HAS THE BEST MMO COMBAT?! [/h1]
That's not even questionable... This game has the best MMO action combat. It's literally dominating all MMOs with action combat out there with how well action combat is. And weirdly enough even in 2023 no game has managed to top this action combat, which is a shame, I would love to see that kind of game.


[h1] SKILL TREE AND CLASSES [/h1]
First of all, creating characters in this game is pretty neat. You have lots of amazing options and you can create literally whatever you want. As for classes we have 26 different classes and we are getting new classes every year. Their skill trees are well-made as well with a lot of meaningful and unique skills.


[h1] BIG QUESTION, IS THIS GAME PAY TO WIN?[/h1]
I can't say it's fully P2W and probably the only real P2W thing is the P2W Tent you buy from Pearl Market, but aside from that there is no P2W stuff, but... The game is very harsh, it takes too much time to get things people can get easily with real money. People can buy pearl items with real money, and then sell them on the game market, while these items help F2P players (Like buying Value Packs or Costumes without paying zero bucks and with in-game money) same time it hurts them. Costumes sell for around 1-1.5b and depending on your family's fame you can sell up to 5-35 costumes every week, so that means without spending any hour ingame you can earn around 35-50b in-game money every week and that's equivalent average grinder 35-65 hour of grinding and it's too much... This game gives you very little reward for actually playing and it's harsh, and weirdly enough it wasn't always like this, but with the latest updates increasing cron, memory fragment, and pearl items you sell on the in-game market by 97% and things became quite bad, and timing was quite bad as well, these updates all happened after BDO gained popularity because of some known YouTubers making videos by saying ''BDO is not P2W anymore!'' I guess PA took those comments personally and wanted to prove them they are wrong...


[h1] HOW ABOUT OUR OPEN WORLD? HOW BIG AND WELL MADE? [/h1]
Honestly, it's quite big. We have lots of cities, enemy territories you can grind, lots of islands you can explore, etc... It's not big enough like ESO or WOW (if I'm not wrong) but still it's not a game with a little or middle open world. This game has a pretty big open world to explore.


[h1] WHAT IS THIS SEASON THING? [/h1]
Season basically gives you access to the season server, free special season gears, a lot of good rewards, and some pearl rewards, outfits, etc. It's one of the most new player-friendly things I have seen in any MMO and helps players a lot to get decent gear and stuff.


[h1] HOW ABOUT GRAPHIC QUALITY? [/h1]
I'm not sure if it's best or not but this game's graphic quality looks damn fine! It's one of the most amazing MMO graphic quality you can see and the designs are pretty good as well. World design, house materials, BOSS and enemy details, NPC's, etc... All of them look amazing.


[h1] OUTCOME EVALUATION [/h1]
In the end, this is a pretty good MMO game, it has some problems and PA seems taking things in a worse direction than a couple of months ago, but it's still a pretty good game and has the best MMO action combat. So if you are an MMO lover you should definitely play/try BDO. I'm pretty sure you are going to like it. It's not perfect and after some time it can be quite boring but it still gives you lots of content as MMO and until doing them for a long time they are pretty enjoyable as well.


[h1] RATINGS [/h1]
[*]Story Quests And Story Telling Quality = 6
[*]Gameplay Mechanics = 10
[*]Claesses and Their Skill Tree's = 8
[*]BOSS Fights And Enemy Variety = 7
[*]Item & Gear Variety = 7
[*]Area And World Designs = 8
[*]Graphic Quality = 8


[*]General Rating = 7.7

Update October 2023:

Since PA took over the publishing the game has become less and less "pay to win". It is still very sketchy as far as "pay for convenience" goes... The only really way to enhance your gear is to spend money, not everything is available in game that is in the store... 

My biggest gripe with BDO (Black Desert Online) is the enhancement system. It is terribly hard to enhance and its a science of RNG that you have to be in it for the "Long haul" in order to enhance things (especially accessories which make up most of your gear). Accessories if you fail at any stage of enhancement "blow up" and if you use the convenience feature of "Cron Stones" there is a chance of it downgrading instead of blowing up entirely. In short, if RNG is not in your favor you could loose 400 hours of grinding time in the in game currency "Silver" for it downgrading, or even more if you do not use the protection Cron Stone's and the entire thing blows up... 

Everything is tied to the cash shop though, from marketplace discount so you can actually sell things you find by grinding to your energy recovery by another item to being able to change your skills... with yet another item bought for real life money... 


The long and short, its getting better but they need to pick what they want to charge people for and not have so many different things they charge for... To run the game efficiently then expect to spend at bare minimum 100 USD a month... Fun game? Yes.... Expensive and worth it? Most likely not...

I'm not a very experienced gamer and this was among the first few RPGs that I've played. However, I personally found this game to be a lot of fun. The world itself is pretty huge and you could easily spend hours wandering around finding all the cities and collecting all the plants and items found out in the wild. The life skills is pretty extensive to the point where I find it overwhelming. The combat itself is pretty simple at first, but once you start to level up and get new moves, you can easily stack them. I also find it cool that certain moves can only be triggered in succession to others. Graphically, I found it quite beautiful, especially the player models themselves, which you can very extensively customize. The environments are gorgeous and vary in look. There is always something to do. You can even go sailing in this game, which I find fun to do, especially with how pretty the water and far out islands can look.
My biggest gripes with the game are the fact that, in my personal experience, it is easy to get stuck on some on the 3rd models in the environment. Since the world is so big, sometimes going off the paths cuts down transportation time, which takes forever if you haven't completed the Magnus questline. There is no fast travel in the game until you do so, unless you want to wait 20 minutes. The same goes for the cities themselves which are a pain to navigate with all the connecting paths that also lead to dead ends, making transportation even longer. I have to rely very heavily on the auto-navigate feature. I'm also not fond of the double layered in-game currency bought with real money. In order to buy one currency, you have to buy another. When you add this up, it can cost $30 to buy an outfit. Now, of course, this is only cosmetics and I completely understand that Pearl Abyss needs this money to keep the game up along with their company. They also do hand out outfit boxes for events, usually around holidays, but they're not often. Again, this is just one of my pets peeves. It's really not that big of a deal, especially considering buying the game upfront is only $10. And for only $10, you get a lot.
I apologize for this lengthy review, but I had a lot to say. I sounded negative at the end, but those are only minor inconveniences and don't take away the overall experience which is really fun. I would absolutely recommend giving it a try.
