This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

TL;DR One of those games where the first 5 minutes will decide whether you'll like it or not. 

Pros:
1) Combat - There are so many classes with different playstyles, so chances are that there's something for everyone.
2) Lots to do - As with any MMO, there are years and years worth of content to chew through, so in theory everyone can find something to do. Starting with typical PVP and PVE and ending with farming , sailing, hunting, fishing, often with their own minigames.
3) Lots of chase items - There are a ton of (QoL) items that take months or even years to work towards if you feel like you are bored with nothing to do.
4) Gearing is vertical at first, but becomes horizontal after a certain point. You can quit for 2 years and still be near the same power level as before.

Cons:
1) New player experience is horrific, it almost beats Destiny 2 and Warframe on the level of confusion.
* UI is messy and won't make any sense for the first few days.
* You will be showered with 150 different items that you won't know what to do anything with, which is especially bad because inventory size is super limited at first.

2) Questing is a whole another topic and probably needs an overhaul with the permanent seasonal server update. 
*Questing is somehow split between the questing window (Keybind O), actual NPC's and your personal annoying little black cockroach that loves to give you quests as well. 
*To make things worse, you are often unable to claim questing rewards unless you talk to the NPC's again for no apparent reason, so every quest that has rewards has you effectively spam ESC to get out of the conversation just so you could start talking to them again to claim the rewards.

Neutral/Controversial:
1) There are more and more updates that favor PVE over PVP. 
PVE: More activities, bosses and dungeons are added, "Marni*, a "safe realm" can be used for half a day which allows you to dodge any PVPers should any still exist in this game.
PVP: One sided non consequential PVP was basically removed and/or is heavily punished.
2) This game has no monthly subscription, so you can expect microtransactions to be shoved in your face, sometimes rather aggressively.

This game is a quite the unique experience compared to other MMORPG games. And the depth is quite fascinating, you could spend thousands of hours and still have a bunch of things to learn. There's life skills like gathering, fishing, hunting, trading and many more which gives you an alternative path instead of going the "classic" monster farming route. Another great factor is that you get to explore a really huge map with differnet territories going by foot, horse, wagon, balloon or even boat.

When you first start to play the game you get overwhelmed by information, it can be hard to play a game when there's so much to learn. That said, if you do enjoy the basic mechanics and have the patience I do recommend to stay around, else it might not be for you.

If you are buying this game, patience is key and take time to learn the basics. Be prepared to spam the "R" button if you don't enjoy the quest dialogues, most quests in my opinion aren't that great (however there are many good questlines as well). Another thing to be prepared for is late game gear enhancing, which will be really time consuming. By the time you reach this point however you will already have several hundred hours.  Enjoy your adventure if you do decide to try it! :D

I thoroughly enjoyed the perspective and feel of the combat in the game. The OST was brilliant and fitting in almost every situation, and the classes give you plenty to chose from so that there is one fit for you. There are a few perchases to make the game more convenient late game, but nothing 100% needed. 

Im in love with the world and the freedom with solo play. But one saddening thing is that it is is so darn hard to LFG. So if you can get some friends together and make a guild to play regularly that would be the most ideal situation possible. 

Now be careful, one thing I don’t like is how cosmetics are BOUND to the character you put them on the first time. So make sure at least for 10 hours of playing that character that that is the one. I have made a few purchases for cosmetics early on thinking I could just switch them over not reading (assuming it was like most games) that I could just move over the cosmetics to a new character of the same class, but no dice.

 Now another ick I have is that early on, there is too much running and talking, and later on there is like none. Now I just think it should be spread out a little more  as people early game can get bored very easily if they don’t see the results fast enough since they are not fighting, and late game can leave thinking they have done it all after awakening. The game is much larger than that, but it doesn’t say it explicitly.

Now, some RECOMMENDATIONS.
     If you are a lore junkie with and want to know everything anyone in the game says, start with the first spawn point, the one recommended for novices, you start of nice and slow. Also you get the beginning intros and all that junk. 

Now if you want to rush levels and skip 200 years of just reading and listening to people, go to the second spawn point, I think it has the fastest leveling through story and the least amount of talking (<3 lando) . 

Now if you want that nice city feel with the beautiful landscape and pretty women and Japanese feel (any weeb/otaku or person who picks ninja/kunoichi class) the third spawn point is your pick. It’s a little slower, but you get all that beauty you want in a realistic game. 

Now weapon crafting is something I am still looking into, I’m not a pro or anything, so bear with my personal opinions please.
 
Now, Classes

Not too much I can say about this, as I have not tried all of them yet, but excitement with them all, as they all have a different feel. You may despise how it feels to play one character type and then love the next. There is no one class fits all, like most games where you have “warrior,mage, and tank” (example please don’t get angry) so don’t give up on the game just because you picked an unfitting class to you. It’s like food with seasoning. You are eating the same food, but one seasoning may make you lose your appetite, and another will
Make you eat it faster than I can say “Black desert.” 

Overall I love the game, and even with how I worded this, I still have MUCH to learn about the game and plan to play it much much more. 
Hope this helped! 
(P.S. newer players don’t buy cosmetics until you awaken your first character please)

There is so much depth to this game that you'll need to spend a large amount of time outside of the game researching and looking at guides. 

Pros: 
Immersive
Vast depth of game mechanics / features / skills / options / classes / just loads of variety in general! 
Best combat in the genre easily
No subscription and low buy in cost, I'd like to thank the whales for funding the developers and allowing us F2P players remain F2P
New(ish) seasonal servers allow new players to catch up and get into the mid game easily
Graphics
Universe design
PvP

Cons:
Cash shop is very expensive
There's a cash shop
Game is EXTREMELY grindy (but if you like games like Runescape this is more of a pro for you then a con)
Quests / mechanics / features / etc are often not explained well and you'll need to do research outside of the game
Story telling mostly sucks, it's getting better but meh, spam that R key

In summary I recommend anyone try this game, there's little to risk as the game is only $13 and often on sale for half of that. There is thousands of hours of gameplay on offer. For the sweaty grinders there's tens of thousands of hours. If you've heard the game is pay 2 win that's mostly untrue, although possible the conversion rate of real money to in game silver is simply not worth it to all but the fattest of whales. The best way to sum up BDO is majority of the content is similar to a MARATHON and NOT a SPRINT! To be competitive you will need to invest thousands of hours but if you don't want to be competitive the game still has plenty of things to do for the casual player.

BDO is what you get when nerds that discussed good-sounding-on-paper way-too-in-depth systems get to actually make them, but are also forced to slap much-hated Eastern MMO industry staples and monetization onto it. 

Most all of my time with it has been between a spellbound Tomstare and SpongeGar, or Danny DeVito Art Critic. It's got tons of great and promising aspects, marred by periodic dealbreakers. Combat would be good, if it wasn't a complete desync-fest on anything more protracted than mob grinding, and the Eastern RNG-based upgrade system is extremely unappetizing to Western audiences. These two things make it hard to recommend in clear conscience for anything more serious than tourism for a season.
If you are a masochistic mmorpg player who loves to grind, this game is for you.
grindy

The problem with BDO reviews is no one spends enough time in the game to give it a fair review due to the scope of the game and the fact it's an MMO that gets better over time. 

There is an incredibly long list of things PA has done to decrease monetization over the years while adding [u]nothing[/u] to increase it. They literally power crept their "P2W" store. Grinding beats swiping because of constant inflation, which is good and needed for the economy.
And yet you see in every review how PA is "Arbitrarily inconveniencing the players." Or it's a "Money sink, where you have to pay for everything." Or it's just "P2W". But these reviewers wouldn't know this because they didn't play the game.
Watch the "700 GS in 60 days" series, its eye opening. 

You can't even win in this game in a traditional sense since PVP isn't a significant part of it unless you join a guild specifically for wars, or maybe you like the absolute mayhem of Red Battlefield. The bad thing about these game modes is that even if the gear was capped, it would still be a blender simulator with no precision or way to improve your PVP skills.
The much more fun game mode is Arena of Solar. It's equal gear and 3v3, so you can improve your 1v1 skills. 

It's hard to find negative things about the game these days. I highly recommend EvilDoUsHarm on YouTube, Garmoth.com, and bdocodex.com. Also, complete all the main quest lines and the important adventure journals. It will solve a lot of headaches.

I blow past the system requirements of this game. Why is the popin so bad? I run around and NPCs almost require me touching them to load in properly and players seem to jump across space and time. The player character model is amazing and environmental detail is gorgeous but I can't feel invested in a world where black shadows replace NPCs at a distance or the game just pops them in when you're super close. I spent a good few hours trying to fix that issue but it's persistant. 

If you do get into this game, do yourself a favor and turn off notifications on other player activities. This game (by default) was letting me know when anyone was crafting (and failing.) Basically another player can crack wind and the game will notify you. I suggest saving your sanity on that one.

As for clothing customization... there is none. Everything worth having is locked behind a paywal, including your choice of underwear (When in your home) or Underwear and some thigh-highs for an equal price. The default outfit of the sorceress is super cool but I could only find subtle gear changes which made it feel like the game very uninspired. 

I really love the combat of the sorceress and this is literally the first game ever that has a character with my facial markings and a combat style I love. As well as a subtle detail that made my artist heart gush was the detailing of the models. My character blasting dark balls of energy actually looked like my character had to tense her muscles to launch the next ball of dark energy.

In closing I say this is a game 'I really want to love, however just can't due to technical issues in the game'

The only good thing about this game is the combat. And I would say that it's not really that good. It's sloppy. And the movement is awful. Everything else in this game is infected with Korean MMO systems. Not only that but the game feels cheap, tacky and shallow. There's no substance to the game at all. And I don't even know why they would turn this into an MMO. As a single player game, it's actually pretty great (minus the energy system).

 - The energy system is awful and it's awful in every single game that implements it. There's people defending it, and it's because they're delusional if they think it's an acceptable system. Gating gathering behind an energy system has to be the most ridiculous system in an MMO. The effort gathering is what should be worth the silver selling it, not energy. It basically cheapens your efforts to the point that it makes you believe your effort is not important. It's the energy system. What a joke.

- No player trading. Probably the most ridiculous restriction in this game. There's already little incentive to group up. But grinding for specific items with other people is completely pointless. And so is grinding with someone.

- North Korea marketplace. You basically have no say what to sell the items you spend your time and effort crafting. None. Like the Epheria Sailboat. At the time of this review you can only sell the tfor 530 mil silver. 530 mil silver is nothing. For 20 days of dailies, plus the amount of time it takes to construct. A ridiculous amount of time gathering logs (which you can only gather physically) which guess what? You can't even gather because there's an energy system preventing you form doing so!

- Player driven economy is a lie. There is no player driven economy. The marketplace is a joke. Nothing is for sale. And you get hit with a 35% sales fee to remove ANY incentive for margin trading.

- Enchanting system. Of course it's a Korean MMO. There's going to be an enchanting system. They are all awful RNG gambling money sinks.

Summary: This game is basically an abusive relationship and you're a drug addict that is delusional and thinks this game is somehow fun. This game should be sued for false advertising for claiming it's a multiplayer game. It's not. It's a Massively Online Role Playing Game. There is no multiplayer. Except GvG PvP. It blows my mind how people can't see how awful this game is or how deceptively manipulative these systems are.

if your looking for a stunning character creator and a battle hungry grind of an MMO. THIS IS THE GAME. its gorgeous and perfect for role play. like any MMO its very quest line and reading oriented, so if you don't like reading then maybe it's not for you. The world is built up vast and rich with people, good and bad. The fighting style is honestly one of the best if ever experienced in an MMO, not turn based back and forth, you can actually dodge and run around creatures and still give fluid attacks. The attack animations are honestly sick and you can do flips and twirls, the abilities are beautiful and colorful, i really enjoy fighting in this game, and you have to because you fight A LOT. Like massacring whole armies of goblins and orcs and various creatures, taking out their outposts or supplies, ect ect. The cute shadow you wake up with becomes more and more ominous and it really fleshes out the story to see him grow and change. The world is a bit detailed, like training your horse/donkey to level them up. Same with your animal companions that you have to keep fed and well. Nothing too difficult but still an immersive feature that some people may find bothersome. lots of different things you can do may get confusing but you can always find guides online and its really not to difficult once you learn. The outfits are super cute and you can change their colors and customize your character. Its not a pay to win, you can pay for fancy clothes and like cool items to change your mount or animals, but you cant pay for levels or like good gear, the pearl store is mostly cosmetic and convenience purchases. Overall i always revisit this game when i can and enjoy it thoroughly. Worth every penny imo.

Black Desert Online is an absolute masterpiece in the world of online gaming. I've been immersed in this captivating virtual realm for quite some time, and it continues to amaze me with its stunning graphics, intricate gameplay, and boundless opportunities.

First and foremost, the graphics are nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in this game is mind-blowing. From the lush landscapes to the intricately designed characters and creatures, every aspect is a visual treat. It's truly a testament to the developers' dedication to creating a visually stunning world.

The gameplay is equally impressive. The open-world sandbox environment allows for endless exploration and adventure. Whether I'm engaging in thrilling combat, crafting, trading, or simply enjoying the beauty of the game world, there's always something new and exciting to discover. The combat system is both challenging and rewarding, making battles a real adrenaline rush.

One of the standout features is the character customization. The level of detail and options available to create a unique avatar is unparalleled. It's incredibly satisfying to see your character evolve and grow as you progress through the game.

The community aspect of Black Desert Online is also noteworthy. Joining guilds, participating in events, and interacting with other players adds a whole new layer of fun to the game. The community is vibrant and welcoming, making it easy to find friends and allies in this vast virtual world.

Furthermore, the game is constantly evolving with regular updates and new content, ensuring that players always have something to look forward to. The developers are attentive to player feedback, which enhances the overall experience.

In summary, Black Desert Online is a gaming gem that continues to captivate and engage players like me. Its stunning visuals, immersive gameplay, and thriving community make it an unparalleled online gaming experience. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or new to the genre, I highly recommend diving into the enchanting world of Black Desert Online – you won't be disappointed!

Over the years the game has gotten far better than it used to be, but I would still say its in a pretty rough spot overall. The old problems that plagued this game years ago still rear their ugly heads, albeit further down the line of progression than the days old. Whether your enjoyment comes from PVE content or PVP content, there is on single truth in the world of BDO: Grinding, like taxes, is inevitable and perpetual. There will never come a point where you will simply have the "best" gear. The hard caps are so unreachable, so unattainable, that they are simply out of reach for normal contributing members of society, and just barely in reach for those that make this game their life. 

No one plays MMOs for their story so lets jump towards what players are working for: PVP. To be fair though, the devs have added a lot of content for endgame PVE over the years, but it isnt enough to fully enjoy once you near the top rung of that ladder. PVP really still is the only thing endgame players strive for, and it honestly isnt all that amazing. BDO is widely touted as having the most skill based and in depth combat system on the market, but in most pvp situations whoever gets the first knockdown will win 99% of the time regardless of skill. That is in a fair fight, which for most of your BDO playtime you will be at a disadvantage. A characters strength is determined by gear score, which is increased by attaining better gear. The problem is this gear becomes so hard to get that you'll eventually spend weeks, and eventually months just to get a few point increase. The reason its so hard to get is due to the chance based enchantment system in the game. It starts off with reasonable rates like 50% but can get as low as 0.001% chance. Yes there are systems in place to increase that % chance, but only slightly. A 5% chance at successfully enhancing an endgame piece of gear is considered mind-blowingly amazing, and each attempt will run you several hours of grinding just to be able to take another chance at the wheel so to speak. You'll spend this time getting bullied by higher gear score (GS) people, dreaming of the day where you get to hand their abuse back to them. Then, one day you'll become somewhat strong. You'll finally be able to defend your grindspots from being taken by higher GS assholes, only to realize there isnt any death penalty. then comes little tuvala timmy gearlet bombing your rotation goading you into attacking him... but you cant, because of the karma system. You see, even though you're stronger than little timmy here, the karma system protects him as he refuses to leave your rotation. Openworld PVP was designed so you can remove this little gearlet because you've invested more time into the game, except you cant otherwise you'll go red, get ganked by his friends, and lose billions just trying to defend your rotation. This will be your main pvp experience from then on out. The only redeeming qualities of this system is guild v guild combat, node wars, and arena of arsha are all super fun, except 2/3 requires you to go through this years long period upgrading your gear, forcing you to go through the aforementioned.

I have 4x this hours on console as well and would recommend playing this game. Combat is arguably the best of any mmo. Plenty of things to do solo and with a party. BDO has slowly improved over time, to the point where it is a reasonable game application to spend your time player.  It is a very large world MMO, that is a lot less pay to win than it used to be, a lot less than it's reputation suggests, and a lot less than my previous ranty review stated.

It's an action combat game with deep life skilling, and a very large progression ramp.  You can PvP, or AFK fish, or buy Mansions, or engage in Sea Combat with NPC monsters or other players.  The items in the game are traded between with a central market, so there's a whole economy, and effort based progression system.
Lots of depth and great game play. Wish there was a resource available to understand this game and the intricacies more.

If you have a Job, BDO is not for you. It will take you forever to get things done in this game, especially if you can only play an hour a day maybe 2. I first started on a seasonal character and everything was fine, until, they announced that the seasonal servers were going to end. Little to my knowledge they extended it!!! WOW!! So now i'm stuck on a regular server doing everything in my power to progress with no hope. Furthermore, let's not talk about the price for this game. Yes, the game is ONLY 7$, however, if you want to progress without it being tedious there is an additional price tag of 60$ you MUST spend. Yeah.. yeah .. yeah. you don't have too, but if you don't, everything take longer to do. I only recommend this game if you  have nothing else to play.


P.S. If you're looking for a game to play with friends, this is not the right game to play. I came on playing with my friend, but most of time we can't do anything together because they penalize you with XP, money, and anything else you can think of.

This game has a pretty good number of positive things going for it. It looks pretty, the world it builds feels huge and has many different systems to learn and interact with, the sandbox nature let's you set your own goals and it has, by far, the most fun combat I've played in an MMO yet.

Unfortunately the game has too many other bad things going for it to ignore. The PvE is fundamentally the same whether you're level 10 or level 60. You run around grinding mobs, forever. There are some world bosses, but they didn't seem very special to me. Their hard versions have some fun mechanics, but they would be considered middle of the road in other games. There are a grand total of 3 dungeons, which I didn't even get to do as they seem quite unpopular.

Life skilling can be an enjoyable break from the action, but can involve significant amounts of afk activity. You are expected to keep the game running forever while your character fishes or cooks 3000 dishes in a row.

The game flatout has annoying popups that I'd expect in shady sites that lead you to malware. I'll get annoyed every day and match in Arena with a stupid ass popup I have to cancel every single day. Everything is monetized and the game wants you to know it. The game is infamous as both a no lifer grinder and P2W fiasco and in my opinion it's absolutely true.

I could deal with all of those things but what really did it for me is the PvP. Open world you will get literally 1 tapped by no lifers, so your fun might vary significantly. Most of the guys actually running around in confidence looking for fights know they have the gear to back it up. But even if you find an equally geared opponent there are other problems with the combat.

There is something else that annoys me the most about PvP. The real issue is that the combat is good, and it has depth, but either the engine or their servers fundamentally can't handle the fast pace of the action. Characters will desync and you'll get grabbed from 20 feet away, or your super armor won't work and you'll get stunned through no fault of your own. On top of that, there are stats that can make it so enemies will randomly resist a cc attempt or autododge attacks.

I cannot comprehend how a game with so much PvP in its life can actually have so many horrible things that ruin the PvP on a foundational level. If it actually worked, it would probably be one of, if not the, best MMO PvP there is. Instead, I found myself longing to go back to tab targetters. At least there the CC I applied actually does its job.

BDO a game about Stockholm effect.

After about 3k+ hours (it used to have another launcher for Black Desert SA, so it does not show my correct game time) I just don't wanna play this game anymore, every day that I log in I feel like a fool, out of the 3k hours i'd say I only played about 1k hours the other 2k are just afk fishing, afk alchemy, and afk cooking. 

TL DR: So what is this game actually about? AFK activities, RNG, micro-transactions, gambling, gambling, gambling. Oh! And more gambling. There is nothing here beyond that.

Sure the combat is the best in any action MMORPG but is it really worth your time? Every aspect of the game is plagued with low chance RNGs and gambling. After a certain point in the game (just after you graduate from season) your progress as a new player halts almost to a stop, then you have realistically 2 choices:

RNG enhancement:
For RNG enhancement, lets just say that during season they make it feel like its easy, but let me show you the real deal: The base chance for a successful upgrade from a Blackstar TET to PEN is 0,2%, sure black star PEN is the best weapon in the game, are you mortal human, some day gonna have one? No. But how much does it cost anyway? About 150 billion silver, which I can't even put it in terms of grind hours cause I've never even got past 30 billion silver without tearing my hair out and shoving a dick up my ass, its one of those things that it is better to not even know. 

Okay so lets bring this to post season characters, Base chance for a boss armor TET to PEN: 0.3%. Oh yeah but I forgot to mention the difference between clicking a BS PEN and a Boss Armor PEN, do you know what happens when you fail an enhance? downgrade, what prevents a downgrade? Cron stones, how much does it cost for 1 cron stone, 2 million silver (3m depending on your region, yeah they fuck your ass differently depending from where you are playing the game), how many cron do you need for ONE safe click? Blackstar TET to PEN: 3.6k cron stones. Boss Armour TET to PEN: about 1k - 2k cron, do the math and see how much it costs just for one attempt at enhancing. 
But here is the catch, my account is 8 years old so I have at least 3 to 30 of every type of Valks Advice possible (its an item that enhances your chance for a successful upgrade) If I have the Cron, I can click what ever the fuck I want, but you dear newbie, you are fucked, you get a handful and that's it, login again tomorrow or for 3 days strait to get another one, or go spend your money building up fails stacks. 

But hey!!! Here is a random event box full of goodies that has 99.5% chance of giving you 10 - 20 Cron stones that you can't even sell back to the NPC for extra money.

Grind:
For buying a gear upgrade you are looking at least 10 hours+ of grinding, when you finish season, for your next upgrade, you need about 5 billion silver which is one boss armor at PEN, then do that another 5 times and congrats!!! You have just entered early-mid game and can now actually play the game (don't try PVP though, you won't understand shit about what you are doing and the opponent will just teleport around your screen and 1 hit kill you, maybe try Solare Arena if you don't mind getting flaked for being newbie). In the Gear Score Bracket I am I'd say its about 100+ hours of grinding for one measly upgrade, something like +2 of AP (assuming I grind sweaty with high APM).

What about the Jettina dailies for a PEN accessory? 
Yeah good luck to you on logging in every day for 2 months strait and killing 3k mobs every day, I did it, was not fun, it TOOK ME A FUCKING YEAR TO FINISH IT. 

BUT WAIT, THERE IS MORE!! You want a PEN boss armor? Well, for your first weapon and armor we have a really good promotion its just half the price plus 2 - 3 weeks of dailies!!!! oh what? you want another? its double the original price of the item in the market plus 2 - 3 weeks of dailies, what a great system we made that helps newbies!!!!!

Magnus questline? Ok you can have a PEN boss gear for free! do you know what you need to do? Just do this quest-line that takes up a hole day to finish and the only thing you do is trash and buggy minigames, YAY!!! (Pick the PEN Urugon Boots, you will thank me later)

"Oh but you don't need to touch RNG in this game, you can buy everything" incorrect, for gear that maybe the case, but for everything else you are forced in to the game's RNG. Every event nowadays is just some RNG box with the slimiest possibility to get something actually good. 

Let me illustrate: There was an event where you put your worker to gather some goodies sacks and after 6 - 8 hours (depending on your worker) you had a chance to get 1 of the 3 types of sacks (2 of them complete shit, 1 good), I left my worker the entire event (about 2 weeks of event), let me tell you how many I got: About 40+ sacks of shit and 6 sacks with the POSSIBILITY of good items. After the event ended I opened them all, wanna know what I got? Shits and turds. 

Oh did I mention your worker only works when you are online? so do the math 46 bags multiplied by 6 hours for each bag = 276 hours, 276 hours divided by 24 = 11.5 days online out of 14 days, yeah I could have mined bitcoin and injected the money in the game and I would have had more ROI.

Next event: stay online for about 2 hours a day and open 2 - 3 box of possible goodies, I have opened about 12 boxes, wanna know what I got? ANOTHER RNG BOX! And again more shits and turds, what will I get till the end of the event? Probably more shits and turds and maybe, but just maybe ANOTHER RNG BOX!!!!
And that just goes on for every "event", until you actually manage to drop something good and go "wow! this event is really good, PA is such a good developer, giving cash items for free, I love them!!".

So what am I trying to say? That I have Bad RNG? No its not that, its that just the game likes to make a fool out of you, they are going to put RNG box inside of another RNG box in everything and shove it down your throat, and you know what the problem is with gambling? The house almost always wins.... 

Here in BDO they use every possible tactic in psychology books, to get you hooked, to give you the illusion of progression, to make you spend money, but when you stop for a second and think on what they are doing and how you are responding to it, you are either gonna feel like a fool, or a guinea pig.

And you know what part is worst? Its that the community loves being made a fool of by the devs, they are going to defend PA with teeth, tooth and nails, its like some kind of Stockholm effect. They are going to say "no man this game was a lot worse, PA devs have listened and made things better for players" yeah... they actually haven't, sure they made some things less atrocious, but then again its that same tactic where you create a problem and give the solution, thing is the solution is 99% in favor of the devs and 1% in your favor, but the way they do it and communicate it, it always feels like they are doing this for you, for your better game experience, to help you out. But its not, its just to inflate steam-charts with active users and make you spend more money. 

"Oh boy they gave me a J's hammer now I have 1 FREE try to get that Black Star TET to PEN with 5% chance!!!!!!"

"Hey! here is a free legendary T9 horse!!! Good for you, we are such good devs, now go and click it to T10, here is a shit ton materials for you to try to click it! Oh it din't go T10? To bad, stay online every day and I'll give you more materials or go and grind your ass out"

Yeah sure, I would much rather PA slapped me in the face and called me a bitch. 

Will I continue playing this shit? Probably, I invested to much to simply fuck off, i'm a bitch, but you my friend, you don't have to be, stay away from this "game"....

This is a good game, just do be aware it is a grinding game.
The main quest is okay, but weak, it gives you a story and a general reason to be doing what your doing, but to gain levels, your there to grind.
There is a item that helps make questing an alternative its called the Chenga tomb and it works well for a while.
Some say in game and out this is a P2W game, and yes it can be that I suppose if you make it such.
But if your not impatient, or if your cool just letting things come to you at there own pace, there is nothing you MUST buy to progress from the in game store.
I admit I have bought things because LOL sometimes im NOT patient, and there are outfits I had to have but those are mainly for looks.
Graphics are great, high end computers will excel, mid range GPUs will struggle in crowded areas, but in most cases turning things down will alleviate most problems, and even that doesn't turn the graphics ugly.
Many MANY classes to choose from, I havent played half of them, but those I have, I have enjoyed.
Would recommend looking up class guides to find out what your into, but just picking something isnt a bad option either.
Combat is generally fast paced and all the classes make it very varied.
Lifeskills or Tradeskills also provide a leveling path, and all are valid, and some as in any game are more profitable then others.

(2 LAYER CAKE) Simple Chocolate Birthday Cake with Whipped Chocolate Buttercream.

cook time: 25 MINUTES

total time: 1 HOUR

yields: ONE 2 LAYER CAKE

Cake For 2 Layers 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar 1 cup unsweetened cocoa powder 1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder 1 teaspoon salt 2 eggs, at room temperature* 3/4 cup buttermilk 1/4 cup plain greek yogurt 1/2 cup canola oil 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 3/4 cup strong brewed coffee, hot 1/2 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips (optional)

Whipped Chocolate Buttercream For 2 Layers 3 (1 1/2 cups) sticks salted butter, softened to room temperature 3 cups powdered sugar 3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder 2 teaspoons vanilla extract 3-4 tablespoons heavy whipping cream Instructions

For the cake: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grease 2 8-inch round cake pans. Line with parchment paper, then butter/spray with cooking spray.In a medium size bowl combine the flour, sugar, unsweetened cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder and salt. Set aside.In the bowl of a stand mixer (or use a hand held mixer) beat together the eggs, buttermilk, greek yogurt, canola oil and vanilla until smooth.Slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients with the mixer on low until there are no longer any clumps of flour. Add the hot coffee and mix until combined. Batter should be pourable, but not super thin. Stir in the chocolate chips, if using.Pour the batter among the 2 cake pans and bake 20 to 25 minutes, until the tops are just set and no longer wiggly in the center. Remove and let cool five minutes, then run a knife around the edges of the pan. Grab 2 large flat plates, line them with wax or parchment paper and invert the cakes onto the paper lined plates. Cover and let the cakes cool completely before frosting.For the Frosting: Add the butter and powdered sugar to the bowl of a stand mixer (or use a hand held mixer). Beat the butter and powdered sugar together until the butter is light and fluffy, about 4 minutes. Add the cocoa powder and vanilla and beat, scrapping down the sides as needed another 2 minutes or until there are no streaks of white. Add 3 tablespoons of the heavy cream and whip the frosting for 2-4 minutes or until light and fluffy. If desired add the remaining tablespoon of the heavy cream (I normally do) and whip until combined. Taste the frosting and add more powdered sugar if you like a sweeter or thicker frosting.Place 1 layer, flat side up, on a plate or cake stand. With a knife or offset spatula, spread the top with frosting. Place the second layer on top, rounded side up, and spread the frosting evenly on the top and sides of the cake. Decorate with sprinkles, chocolate curls or whatever your heart desires. *To quickly bring eggs to room temperature place them in a bowl and fill with warm water. Let them sit five minutes.

TL;DR: It's a gacha game where players who pay thrive. But still offers quite a bit of content at a very cheap price. I wouldn't expect to get into late game without hundreds of hours or hundreds of dollars. 

Yikes, this game is something. Black Desert has a metric fuck ton of content to offer. But the main issue is that as a new player it is kind of shoved in your face. It can feel overwhelming and it's easy to feel lost. Black Desert also suffers from chronic Gacha game syndrome. This game is very "Buy your way to this!" "Don't want to farm? Spend your money!" Especially with the awful Cron Stone rates farming for PEN V gear can be a pain. I really only can recommend this game to die hard fans of RPG. I've put plenty of hours into it but I don't really feel like I've accomplished all that much. It's very pretty, the sights are great. But it really does feel like F2P players are doomed to fail.

Does this game have great PvP or PvE gameplay? Don't know. I played for maybe 3 hours and levelling up to maybe lvl 13. If I'd played longer I probably would have gotten used to the really weird UI, maybe. It was the "cutscenes" that made me give up. The cutscenes are long, boring and look like the characters are in weird short emote loop that if your lucky fit together even remotly with the really embarassing voice acting. So was the game worth 3€? Maybe, I am sure not gonna waste time finding out.

[b]A Praying Mantis Wrapped in Coupons[/b]
I pity every soul fallen prey to this snare. Black Desert is rife with tactics to make you spend money, keep you engaged and eager to log back in. No matter how many *free* samples you get, there is always some deficiency. There is always something new to have—something shiny and tempting continuously shoved into your face. Sometimes it is flashy gear or home décor, other times a server prompt of someone else’s success, so that the more competitive players feel motivated to measure up.

And how is it that you measure up? Black Desert lulls you with a sense of accomplishment; it has you believe you can earn everything through hard and honest work—rote slavery that robs you of tens and hundreds of hours. Do you not want to grind? Do you not want to lag behind? Well, then you have to speed things up! When it comes to upgrading gear, you have to spend an inordinate amount of both time and currency (real or in-game) to gain the best possible results. In this process, your precious item can downgrade or become destroyed. Lo and behold, even money does not guarantee success while upgrading. You can, of course, obtain gear or cosmetics through auction. But *someone* has to put that item up. Someone has to open their wallet.

Gambling and chance are Black Desert's bread and butter: either through extremely rare drops or mini-games that have you throwing dice for worthless and coveted items alike. If you pay up, you may get another try or increase your luck. You may even win a discount coupon! All of that is wrapped in an aesthetically pleasing world to make you feel at home—to create emotional dependency.

Either you sacrifice money or time and fun. And for what? Pixels and numbers within a fake world you have to share with people you probably loathe but want to impress anyway.

This is first and for most a very detailed finely crafted experience, that being said it isn't for everyone. There is much to do that i don't even know of it all. The graphics are beautiful and the color pallet tends to go between somber and vibrant (which i enjoy the contrast), battle system is a little tricky at first but once you get the hang of it you will do great.

the reason i said this game isn't for everyone is because of the grinds. If you are impatient or prefer faster paced games, this is where you would initially decide it isn't your thing and thats ok, the first time i played in PS4 i quit after a couple hours because there was alot of information thrown at you from the get go, but after coming back to it, i find it very enjoyable and a bit more rewarding that other games for the effort you put in.

Ok final review;

Game is good, graphics are hella, fighting is amazing as fuck, but if you can't break free from your tab-targeting mindset, you're gonna have a bad time.

The cash shop is expensive as hell, $30 USD for an in-game outfit that can only be used on one character. Oh, and alts are definitely a thing in this game too. 

There are things that are absolutely necessary to the game-play like weight carrying capacity (everything you have on your character has a weight value, and some items stack infinitely) which is about $15 USD.... on sale.

For the most part, the current company that owns the rights to Black Desert regularly give out huge discounts and events that give  you vital stuff from the cash shop for free. If you play for a semi-consistent 6 months you'd have been given enough stuff to be relatively worth a couple hundred 'Murican Dollary-doo's.

Anyway, game is deeply confusing and many mechanics and game stats are obscured so if you plan on playing you should also strongly consider making the time investment to look up all the various guides. Of which, there are... many.

Allright guys!

I heard about a brandnew overhaul of Black Desert and so I paid my entry fee and tested it out a bit. Soon I understood everything is about Seasons now. You can create a char get some boosts and have fun, right? Nope! 
Soon another higher player with the same class appeared around me and he looks the same then me. That was odd. The other thing Ive noticed: His sword optics differ a bit from mine but all in all it was the same. No visually progression at all.

A bit later I found out that I dont like my class. The class I would love to play looked like a very very young girl. Thats a absolute no no for me. Sry. Not interested!

One minute later I picked another one and I got a system error allready. I had something in my inventory and I cant delete the other char, which I tried. Ive thrown away everything and still I had that said items in my inventory. My interest in browsing different forums about this very matter was below 0.

This quick explaination sums it up very well. This new Season overhaul is overly complicated and it looks like a brand new method to sell more season passes or battlepasses of some kind and either you pick whats free to pick or not you wont erase a not interesting class too easy.

No need to tell you about the pros and cons a lot more cuz you know them very well and yes the game looks amazing but it just has too much useless items for your inventory and not enough visual progression until you reach certain story milestones. (Absolute megaboring 2 me..)

If you like to get bored a lot with dozens of systems and gamemechanics that are overly complex to a degree where you get items for stuff you dont need until your level 50 at level 5 then you have my warm welcome. Otherwise, pass for this one I suggest!
Thanks for your time and

Cheers guys!

Played this game for about 2+ years, then deleted account.  Came back in summer of 2023, about 5 to 6 years later.  The game still favors p2w model, but it's now more generous with gifts during its many events.  Some of the freebies were once only purchasable (real life cash) items.  Quality of life improvements make the game less frustrating for new/casual players.  Seasons also ease new players into the game.  As a result the game is much friendlier than before.  

Yes, there are still components of p2w, which is the dominant fiscal model in the MMORPG genre, but it is now easier to avoid.  Especially if you don't aspire to have all the BiS gears and be on the top ranking lists.

The game is still the best graphics amongst current MMORPG games.  It still remains a sandbox, where the player can decide what their end game goals/activities will be.  This is what I find most appealing.

The concurrent daily active subs still rank in the top 8 MMORPGs, so the world of Black Desert is still very alive and kicking.

Black desert is a fun game with amazing combat and a must have if you are a fan of MMOs.

The Good:
- Fun and engaging combat - It's different from other MMOs and takes some getting used to but it's fun.
- Story is decent - regardless of what others say, it's not a bad story.
- Beautiful game - Really pretty game, lots to explore with stunning landscapes.
- Nice cosmetics - Cosmetics are really nice looking with flowing fabrics and vibrant colors. 

The Bad
- New player experience is a bit lacking.  I had to do a lot of Googling to understand some of the core systems.  Gearing is a perfect example, see below.
- Cut scenes can be really good or really jank.
- Value pack is pretty lame, would be better if they just offered a paid sub.
- Cosmetics are expensive and per character.

My advice to new players:

- Test classes before rolling a seasonal character - You can only have one seasonal character and the option to swap isn't until 56 which is a long run if you don't like the class.   I'd recommend creating one and goofing around with it a bit.   There's a imp area by the start that's great for testing skills.  There's also a preview feature but I haven't tested that.
- Use Seasonal - I made the mistake of making a seasonal char then testing other chars and getting really far with them.   See above, don't mess up.
- Enhancing - Learn this system, it's critical to gear progression. 
- Wait on cosmetics until you're sure you love the class.  As I said above, cosmetics are per char and not account.  
- The community says all classes are viable.  I think this is mostly true but some classes are definitely out performing.  I started with Witch and the Woosa is all around a better class.   As with most MMOs, balance is an on-going challenge.

I want to give a positive review for this game, but there are many fundamental issues with the game that I cannot. 
tl;dr: Don't play this game if you want a well-optimized game that respects your time and money as a player. Pretty lipstick doesn't fix foundational flaws. 

Pros:
- Many classes to choose from
- Skill animations are beautiful
- Outfits are detailed and beautiful 
- Many professions (life skill options)
- Interesting action combat that provides the opportunity for players to use both action bar skills and memorize letter inputs to flow skills together (i.e. pressing a+c is one unique ability, shift+q is another).
- Small scale PvP 1v1, 3v3 can be great fun with the action combat system.

Cons:
- The devs do not respect your time. At every turn, the game is designed to keep you playing longer even if it is while you're afk. Players are incentivized to leave their computers on and games open to afk fish/fight to continue to gain skill/combat exp or money.
- Following the above issue, players can spend hours even days farming gear enhancement materials only to fail the enhancement and either lose an enhancement level or LOSE (the process destroys it) the piece of gear.
- $$ Rules with baked in convenience items available in the shop that make one's experience far better in key gameplay aspects such as inventory management, buffs, character slots, pets, mounts, camps etc. 
- They have developed the game to hook you while you're learning and then leave you stranded without buffs that provide strong quality of life components. Subsequently, you have to either decide to suck it up or buy the buffs from the shop. For instance, the value pack is a buff that provides +16 storage slots to both personal and city storage. Once the buff disappears so do those storage slots and the player is left with little inventory space.
- The above problem is compounded by the game throwing numerous currencies, event and enhancement items, end game items, buffs, consumables, etc that you rapidly run out of storage. This problem is worsened  as you have to connect other town's storage locations through a long and tedious quest line, Magnus. 
- Even if you buy a convenience item with $, you are still left to take extra steps because the game hasn't explained what the item entails. For instance, buying a camp from the shop allows you to set it up in the world and buy buffs. However, without the account wide buff, Secret of the Old Moon, you have to send an alt to sit at a specific game location, spend in game currency, and then transfer a scroll to your main character using the tent in order to buy the buffs from the camp. 
- The story for the game is poorly written and difficult to follow. 
- The new player experience is awful. They have improved it considerably but they have to have numerous text windows, tips, warning, and external guides simply to help new players navigate the beginning stages. 
- PvP is unplayable compared to any other MMO because the game is so poorly optimized. In any large scale PvP, no effects are shown by ally or enemy players even with the correct game settings selected. The burden is put on the player to understand all 24+ unique classes in order to avoid incoming damage while seeing no effects go off. The killer is movement abilities cause players to look like they are lagging or glitching from one location to the next. 
- Because there are no effects, PvE is also quite bland.
- Life skilling, the node management/investment system, and worker systems are poorly explained in game.

Whatever you do, don't play this game.

Returning after 2 years, they literally improved only 2 things. TWO!

Studio has no idea how to predict and meet player expectations.

Every new system has glaring problems that not only don't get caught by their internal dev practices, but that never get addressed post-launch.

Waiting on animations is atrocious. It should never be faster to hit a movement key (to interrupt an animation) then hit your actual key to do what you wanted to do.

Sprinting, swimming, and many other movement systems forego their normal movement system and instead use tank controls.

Horizontal progression is way over done. Every new progression system is a parallel system to another that gets no player interaction - instead of fixing core systems, they tack on more half-assed systems to "complement" them.

They can't even get text input correct on dialogues.

Settings, notes, UI changes - pretty much everything that can be customized - doesn't save when you hit save: they only save once you properly exit the game. However, the game encourages you to stay logged in 24/7 and it crashes all the time. So, in practice, your settings only get saved when you consciously quit the game to specifically save them.

The QoL in this game is barely there. You have 4 + 6 + 3 equipment slots (plus more!), but the gear bag (their half-assed attempt at gear sets) only holds 8 items. It's absurdly unhelpful. This pattern is repeated virtually everywhere in the game. Then, as I said, instead of fixing the system, they will add on another that also doesn't fit the players needs.

This company is hopeless. They have no vision.

Best MMO I've ever played.

Black Desert Online has captured my attention and imagination like no other MMORPG. From the moment I stepped foot into its breathtaking world, I was hooked. The attention to detail is simply astonishing, making every corner of this universe feel alive and vibrant.

Character customization is nothing short of revolutionary. Crafting my avatar felt like molding a unique piece of art, ensuring that my journey started on a personal note. The combat system is where Black Desert truly shines. Fluid, intuitive, and visually stunning, battles feel like a dance of destruction, keeping me engaged and excited for every encounter.

But it's not just the gameplay that's exceptional. The world-building and storytelling are equally impressive. NPCs have distinct personalities and stories that make interactions more than just fetch quests. The main storyline is captivating, and the numerous side activities ensure there's always something to do, whether it's fishing, trading, or crafting.

The economy system is surprisingly engaging, and the seamless integration of player-driven trade and production truly immerses you in the world's economic fabric. The node system adds depth, encouraging exploration and strategic decision-making that keeps me invested in the long term.

While the game's visuals are stunning, they do require a powerful rig to fully appreciate. Optimization has improved over time, but occasional performance dips can still occur. Additionally, the game's learning curve might seem steep at first, but the rewarding sense of mastery is well worth the effort.

The developer's commitment to updates and community engagement is commendable. Events, patches, and expansions regularly breathe new life into the game, showing that the team is dedicated to enhancing the player experience.

In conclusion, Black Desert Online is a masterpiece that offers an unparalleled MMORPG experience. Its world, combat, and depth are mesmerizing, and the sense of immersion is second to none. While not without its minor flaws, the sheer wonder of exploring this vast fantasy realm keeps me coming back for more. If you're seeking an MMORPG that offers both beauty and substance, don't hesitate to dive into the world of Black Desert Online.

I find myself returning to this game periodically. No other MMO does combat like BDO. The world is massive and it feels "real", you can sense the scale of the map just going through the main story quest. Every update brings the game closer to the ideal state most players want, however, there are areas of focus for improvement that pearl abyss must continue to work on. Things have gotten better, yes, but there's a reason most people drop off the game after a few weeks of intense gaming. Ultimately, this game scratches the itch for action combat like no other MMO. The wide variety of activities aside from powering up your gear add more depth to the game and for those who don't have a large amount of time to actively play everyday there are many AFK activities available. Is it the best MMO out there? I don't know, probably not, depends on what you value most in an MMO. That being said, its a good game and a fun one, AND you don't need to spend a dime to enjoy yourself thoroughly.

I don't usually write reviews but I'll do one for this.

I personally LOVE black desert. Granted, I started playing it a few years ago, and I'll be honest it didn't click with me. My first class was the Musa, wasn't a big fan of it at first, then I realized I wasn't a big fan of the MMORPG elements to the game. I ended up uninstalling it. 

I think in July, I decided to redownload it to give it another go, maybe I would like it. Suffice to say I slowly started falling in love with the game. It's grindy of Course but it honestly doesn't bother me that much. Not only is this game a time killer for me when I have nothing else to do but it's genuinely fun for me. I ended up picking the ninja class to restart the game and it's super fun and love the sura katanas. I plan on trying to give guild wars and pvp a try, but I mainly spend time doing quests and getting better at the game. I'd give this game a 8/10. Fun, nice looking game, great music, open world, tons of content, nice customization, immersive, and not to mention cheap starting off, of course there are micro transactions for outfits and whatnot but for a game as huge as this I don't mind it at all. I know a lot of people will probably disagree with me in this, but I completely understand. It's not for everyone and it just clicks for some people, just like it clicked with me.

If you don't like grinding this game will NOT be for you at all. 
That being said If you like grinding you will love this game.
Some key point to know
- It's very easy to get mid game gear now through season characters. Will take you about 3 weeks if your new to get to lvl 61 with Pen Tuvala gear ( Basically TET boss gear ) Compared to when the game first came out it took months if not years.
- Don't try to get into every aspect of the game all at once, Their are a LOT of life skills and other various activities the game will throw at you all at once. Don't bother untill you have finished your season character.
- Find a good guild!! Theirs tons out their and will help you along the way. ( plus u get passive buffs just for joining!)
-You can trial all the chars in the game and find what you like best. All characters are viable in pve so pick what you want. And if you decide at the end you don't like your character you can re roll it on season servers for free!
- Pvp is mostly end game. Joining an RBF ( it's like tdm ) with season gear will make you want to quit.
- The game has many catch up mechanics now. You get 2 free tet boss gear pieces for just finishing your season character. 1 free pen armour for doing the magnus quest line. And a free pen accessory ( worth anything from 50-70mil) for doing about 30 of grinding per day for about a month

The main take away. Try it out for awhile, if you like it stick with it. The game goes on sale often. The amount of rewards they give you through events, daily log ins, etc is actually insane. You will hit a point where you will either need to grind 5+ hours a day for things or grind enough to buy them. When you reach this point you can either switch it up and do life skilling, like horse training, cooking or farming ( many others ) or simply just relax and take things slow!

Don't go after everything at once!!! You WILL get burnt out.

That being said I highly recommend this game for the combat, visuals and just overall feel of the game!

The only thing I think is truly good about this game, is the combat. It's intense, it's flashy, it's complicated and fast. It's so chaotic to pvp, and the combos each class can pull, if you are not quick and do not respond properly, you will absolutely get stomped. 

However, the rest of the game, is very redundant. It is repetitive to the point of being mindless. I often felt myself feeling the same way I felt a long time ago working at a factory 12 hours a day 7 days a week doing nothing but simple movements. Why would I want to play a game that feels like a job rather than a game? I love difficult games and challenging experiences, not mundane tasks that must be done over and over again for 30 years to get a decimal point on a bar. The game offers nothing enjoyable, and honestly, the best thing they could do to fix it would be to strip it away of everything it is and make it just combat arenas.

nearly 5,700 hours in, not happy with the lag now as it really affects endgame play. no oceanic server to speak of, important buffs like super armor and invulnerability during dodge dont work properly for oceanic, PvP is next level disgusting because skills do not land on other players and they appear to kill you almost instantly even in the 'equal gear' arena of solace, the PvE mobs and bosses will hit you even when you dodge well out of the attack usually knocking you down and finishing you. Annoying thing is this is not a PvP focused game but you have alot of trash players that think it is all about PvP, they will not go to the PvP server and they literally gank life skillers and players doing basic things thinking theyre pro, there are basically no penalties for this, they do not care if youre having a bad day, the dirty dogs will gank you hunting or taming horses and laugh about griefing, if this was such a life based imitation then maybe have guards in towns attack them and break their crystals so they get what drop-kicks deserve.
On top of the latency issue this game requires literally weeks at a minimum to get the meaningful things you try to achieve, upgrading to a carrack ship for example requires daily sailing back and forward at a snails pace for up to months, life skills are excessively difficult to level after a certain point, and worst of all is the enhancing system which can drain months of earned silver because even with high stacks youre lucky to have a 6% chance of success just to get to the expected AP/DP - it literally tells you % on the screen so not a random number. failure rates are very high.
Primarily ill never recommend this game to an oceanic player again until they give us a real chance at both PvE and especially PvP.
also while it doesnt really effect me, the store purchases that cost real money are very expensive, i dropped atleast $150 on it atleast twice just to improve my QoL ingame, i also paid about $5 before it was a free game but given the time on it i probably spent sensibly.

The 'real' endgame is Lifeskill Rankings , it's so thoroughfully constructed it's almost seems realistic. IF you are the kind of player that plays a couple of hours per day , do some grind today some lifeskilling tomorrow , be ready to spend  $$ every Wednesday after maintenance to their updated shop , a n d   not minding NEVER doing actual PROGRESS on anything  but rather just spent pointlessly your time, then this is really the game for you. 

 In any other case its NOT.

   Started as grinder . ended up as lifeskiller after get PK'ed 3-4 times in a grind zone that it was one the least rewarding lootwise and all - i still wonder WHO would have come in Cadry Ruins and kill a low gear at 5AM(no dfs not anything - three hitted no questions asked) . .. i was an early riser, doing some grind b4 going to work , lets 'assume' that he was an early riser too, at Cadry Ruins ..XD - 1st Coincidence

  Added on the above , i killed while overnight Training(horse) at Arehaza..!! played the game for - well u see how many hours - i've never seen a single player in that town. And yet , someone(again), killed me at deep of night  in the most remote town of the game because i hadn't calculated the exact loop and i was 4-5m in non safe area.. XD 2nd Coincidence
 
 After i climbed my way in Lifeskill Rankings i ended up 1st  in the server i was playing in three Lifeskills . At some point i joined  a guild but after a ton of 'suggestions' at every opportunity i left. One of the funniest things was when a  guildie writes in chat : ''i have some savings but thinking of spending some in game because i'll get a job next week..'' - so now you probably start figuring out some things. .. but hey, it doesn't mean anything , any1 can write whatev they want in chats etc.  or maybe yet another 'strange happenstance'. 

 And lastly, after i left that guild, my rankings started to backtrack - from 1st i turned up to be 2nd, 3rd and lower by ''others'' , coming in channel(server) EVERY day , and bearing a well known label of guild(s). It was like ''join us - or any guild for the matter, you cannot be 1st and have no guild''. This parody lasted for about 2 months , at that point i unistalled the game-for good this time. 

  All in all , in this game THEY don't want u to be dedicated , to make fast progress etc. Because if u achieve in a year what the majority achieves in lets say in triple that time.. well there is problem. Because, paid/subscription equivalent buffs for 3 years  >  said buffs for 1 year .. . shrewd eh..? ;P  I don't know what u make from all of the above but what I made was that too many coincidences always lead to one thing- u prob now what. Also, bear in mind that a very large portion of the 'players' that are in game are devs, gm's , staff , ambassadors , etc.
   So now you may easier make 2+2 . 

As a conclussion, because i respect my free time and my $$ in equal measure, there is NO CHANCE that i'll give this game another go.

  As for you, its your call.

I can't say enough good things about it. Nothing can touch this game as it is a next gen experience that is still being added to. ( new worlds/ monsters/ outfits/ gear/ hairstyles/ ETC) 10/10


    You can mod Skyrim to next-gen for 7 years like I did and not even come close to the depth and polish BDO has.  Best char gen. Best animations and combat combos. Best monster design, world, outfits, etc. No instances, if you see a castle tower you just walk inside and climb the stair case. Life skills, vaulting up hills. Animations for literally EVERYTHING.  You can be as strong as you want to be, or be a nobody. The game is a true fantasy RPG experience.  Infinite quests with an actual story. Evolution of characters. Mounts, training (new animations for mount skills). Very immersive. 
You can shut off all HUD or have all the HUD. play the game how you want, hardcore (survival) or Casual. 

-Do not let the pressure to be the strongest stop you. Do what ever you want and you will succeed. 
-Many outfits and cosmetics given away for free as events. no need to cash shop (option is there)
-Can craft in game rare outfits not available on cash shop
-Can craft weapons, many weapon models. SO many character classes.
-EZ mode season character system to reach endgame quickly.
-This is not some teenager game. For $10 prepare to be immersed in a deep complex world!

This is hardly a video game in the traditional meaning of the word, more like something you virtually substitute your life, your free time with. It's like its on a genre of its own and that genre is korean-mmo.

A lot of it is blatantly and aggressively set up to have you spend as much money on cash shop items as possible and most of the items you buy will be locked to a single character to make you buy it again. 
The game price is just an entry fee that you pay to willingly get sucked in and then milked dry. 

Atrocious menu design, with content-scarce and low effort wikis to boot. Situation might've improved since I last played but I doubt that. 

Forced PvP in PvE zones. Be ready to do your fairshare of slogging through several thousand hours in a game with an upgrade system locked behind RNG odds as good as winning the lottery before you'll be at equal footing. God forbid you pick a class that's not the handpicked meta one for pvp or one that gets rebalanced later. Diminishing all your time, your effort and money you might've thrown at it. 

it's an absolute shame to see black desert this pretty in its world, visual effects, character weapon and armor design be wasted on what otherwise amounts to a predatory lifeless husk of a game title.

if you still decide it's worth giving it a try, consider playing on the gamezbd private server as the only thing you'll waste there besides your sanity is time.
It's like a job you just dont get paid, requires a shit ton of hours of questing and grinding early to become at least enjoyable too not to metnion magnus bugs.

Best combat in any MMO, best lifeskilling of any MMO. Put on some good music and just grind your life away.

That being said...the longer you play, the more you realize the grind becomes more and more. Your first season character is a blast. By the 3rd, you realize you are at a HUGE disadvantage if you arent leaving your PC on all night/day. The game is CONSTANTLY playing, for energy and for passive income/lifeskilling.

The world is absolutely beautiful, insanely huge, the game is much more solo but it has the most active chat ive seen in an MMO (Along with tons of weirdos) but as ive reached the 3k mark (Around half if not more of that is AFKing) ive realized that I just cant take the grind anymore. After a long time you realize just how brutal the grind is, and after failing 4 attempts at BS PEN, I think my fun is over.

That being said, its a beautiful, beautiful game and PA deserves tons of love for turning the game much more casual. The P2W is still there, but its not nearly as bad as it used to be. Just...stay tf away from enhancing. The enhancing system is literally the lottery and you can lose weeks and weeks worth of mats just for nothing.

Also...id recommend you not have much of a life if youre going to play. This is a brutal, hardcore game that requires an insane amount of time to not only learn, but just play in general. I played this to death while i was nursing a broken foot. As ive gone back to normal work life, I find the game really isnt as attainable or fun with limited time at the stage I'm at. 

Still lots of fun, especially your first character. The combat is insanely good and other MMOs really should take after. Ive had my fun, recommended if you have alot of free time.

As a devoted player, my experience with Black Desert has been bittersweet, primarily due to the game's heavy reliance on RNG factors. While I appreciate the game's stunning graphics, immersive world, and engaging combat mechanics, the constant presence of randomness in crucial aspects like gear upgrading and obtaining rare items has been a major letdown for me.

Every time I attempt to enhance my gear or chase after elusive items, I find myself at the mercy of sheer luck. There is a lack of agency and control over my own progress, making it feel like a tedious gamble rather than a rewarding experience. This unpredictability often leads to frustration and feelings of helplessness, leaving me wondering whether my efforts and time investment are truly worthwhile.

In many ways, the RNG-heavy design feels like a barrier between me and the game's potential greatness. I understand that randomness can add excitement and variety, but when it becomes the primary determinant of success, it tends to overshadow skill and dedication. This design choice has made me question the fairness of the game's mechanics, and I can't help but wish for a more balanced approach that values player effort and skill as well.

As much as I enjoy exploring the beautiful landscapes and engaging in combat with other players, the persistent presence of RNG factors continues to be a significant drawback for me. I believe that Black Desert could truly flourish with adjustments to this aspect of the gameplay, providing a more rewarding and satisfying experience for players who invest their time and passion into the game.

With a hopeful heart, I bid farewell to Black Desert for now, in the anticipation that future updates might address these concerns and pave the way for a more enjoyable gaming experience.

Goodbye, Black Desert. Perhaps we shall meet again under different circumstances.

Started this game in 2016 with thousands of hours in. Unfortunately, I quit the game for a few years and didn't get the memo about your characters getting deleted so I started over. This game has mountains of content and if you can make it through the rough beginning as a new player, you will be rewarded. Black Desert Online is an expansive and visually stunning MMORPG that has captivated players worldwide since its release. Developed by Pearl Abyss, this game offers a seamless and immersive open-world experience, filled with numerous activities, breathtaking landscapes, and an impressive character customization system. Despite its many merits, there are a few minor cons that deserve attention. Let's delve into the positive aspects while highlighting some of its drawbacks.

Pros:

Mesmerizing Graphics: One of the standout features of Black Desert Online is its jaw-dropping visuals. The game boasts an incredibly detailed world, from lush forests and serene lakes to towering mountains and bustling cities. The attention to detail is unparalleled, making exploration a delight.

Deep Character Customization: The game sets a new standard for character customization. Players have an astonishing array of options, allowing them to create unique and personalized avatars that truly reflect their individuality. The level of control over facial features, hairstyles, and body proportions is impressive.

Engaging Combat System: Black Desert Online offers an action-packed combat system that is both fast-paced and skill-based. Players can execute combos and engage in epic battles, adding an exhilarating element to the gameplay.

Abundance of Content: The game is overflowing with activities to keep players entertained for hours on end. From traditional questing and dungeons to life skills, fishing, trading, and node management, Black Desert Online offers a diverse range of gameplay experiences.

Sandbox Gameplay: Black Desert Online embraces a sandbox approach, granting players significant freedom to shape their journey. The non-linear progression allows for diverse playstyles and encourages exploration and creativity.

Cons:

Steep Learning Curve: For newcomers, the game's complexity can be overwhelming. The plethora of mechanics, systems, and customization options may take some time to grasp fully, potentially alienating those seeking a more straightforward gaming experience.

Pay-to-Win Elements: While Black Desert Online is not purely pay-to-win, it does have microtransactions that can provide some advantages to paying players. This has been a point of contention among the community, as it may create an uneven playing field for those who prefer to avoid spending real money.

Grindy Progression: As with many MMORPGs, progression in Black Desert Online can become somewhat grindy. Some players might find the constant need to grind for resources or experience to be repetitive and time-consuming.

Server Issues: At times, the game has experienced server stability problems and occasional lag, which can be frustrating, especially during large-scale events or peak playing hours.

In conclusion, Black Desert Online is an incredibly immersive and visually stunning MMORPG that has set a high standard for character customization and open-world exploration. Its engaging combat and abundance of content provide endless entertainment for players seeking a diverse gaming experience. While there are a few drawbacks, such as a steep learning curve and pay-to-win elements, these minor shortcomings hardly detract from the overall enjoyment that Black Desert Online has to offer. For those willing to invest time and effort into mastering its intricacies, Black Desert Online promises a gratifying and unforgettable adventure.
