Keep in mind that the game is most *definitely* pay for convenience.  With that said, it's enjoyable once you get a handle on the 500 systems it uses.  This is a complicated game, but does actually have a lot of fun within it. Like most Korean MMO's, it's a total grind-fest, and you'll spend a lot of your time on repetitive tasks/fighting.  If that's your jam, then BDO is for you.  If you want a strong story-line or simplified game-play, best skip this title. 
For those who do enjoy a grind-fest, and who want to spend time learning systems off wikis more than within the game itself, there is a TON here to enjoy. Combat complexity with multiple combos, life-skills (crafting) complexity with production automation or manual operations - or both. I happen to enjoy that kind of game-play a lot myself, so I can say for others who like that, you will have fun.
The pay-for-convenience really is there, and while you can overcome most of the delays/gates with the cash shop, I found remarkably little that would be considered "pay-to-win" anywhere.  In theory you could go through the whole game without spending a dime, but in practice you will be picking up things like inventory space/weight increases and other things as you go to make life easier.  Not a gigantic money-sink, not entirely cash-shop free - somewhere in the middle.
I've recently returned to the game and with about 60 hours played I'm enjoying my time. Playing on a seasonal server really helps returning players and people that want to start a new character/alt.

The MMO has improved in a lot of ways, it seems the developers and the company is actually trying, which is a good sign, but the new issues is that there are too much for a player that is just starting, I feel overwhelmed with all the quest, even more bewildered by the amount of items they give you right at the beginning of the game, I don't know what one item does, let alone the 36 other items the game gave me, many of which aren't available for me to use until level 60, this is not good, and I implore the team to only gift items the players could use at the time the item was given, stop giving items that the player does not need or have purpose for until they have actually met the requirement to use the items. 

I wish to give this game another try, but I'll wait until the developers and the company could slow down on the item gifts, and allow me to delete the characters even when they have gifted items.

This game is well made, beautiful graphics, and an interesting world to just get dropped into. Unlike some other MMO's out there, this one gives you a certain freedom, but at the price of knowing what the end game is. You just have to play it for what it is, and how you want to.

The attacks feel so good, it's like that larger weapons have a thump to them when they hit, and the lighter weapons just stab and slice as you command. You also get that feel from the old dynasty warrior games of just mowing down groups without mercy. So satisfying.

They even made it to where you can use a controller to relax and kill with, but sadly it doesn't work well with the UI, not for me at least... I always go back to K&M, + the keybinds are easier for me that way with a 12 button mouse.

So much to say about it, as the game and everything you can do in it is huge. If your interested just try it.

I was one of those few who lost all of their data/purchases during my extended break from the game.
It was hard to come back to the game, having to re-grind, but I'm glad I did, for the most part.
The game is pretty, the combat is flashy, the game is very casual-friendly.
It's kinda like one of those MMOs you'd like to play when your main MMO is waiting on fresh content.
It's a p2w grindfest if you are into that thing, but nothing you can't get for free on your own.
The endgame is lacking a bit compared to other MMOs but it feels more like a sandbox like Runescape rather than traditional MMOs like WoW or FFXIV, so there is still lots to do and explore.
The community is arguably one of the most toxic I have seen, but you can enjoy the game if you ignore chat.

I will thumbs this product up because i have experienced the game before and after the KaKao exit from Pearl Abyss and the current state of the game is a pleasurable, fun & foremost relaxing experience for Solo casuals like myself.

I played about 80hours my first time before i stopped in 2021. The Reason i stopped was because of the grind for Awakening. I always wanted to be a sailor and had to get level 50 for the quest but never got to try it because of the immense grind and main quests being level-locked so mobgrinding was mandatory to progress.

Fast forward to today, 2023.

Now i started hearing a lot of new things, GOOD things about the game that peaked my interest. I have always felt that there was something underneath the rubble of grind that felt alluring.
I have so far as of this review played 90hours (so 10hours of exclusively new player experience) and want to go over the things i have felt so far has been great, and bad.

GOOD: Questing from the start was pleasant. This was something i never did before, just perma skipping cutscenes and dialog because i am too lazy to read. FAST FORWARD to now and they have added voice acting for the entire MSQ and ive learned things about the story i had no idea about before, things that are ACTUALLY interesting and have hooked me. Something only WoWs story in Legion previously had done and none after. Im finding myself constantly wanting to explore the world and find tidbits of interesting information that were revealed to me to have some sort of importance later on.

BAD: So far, some cutscenes experience popping of items / objects and sometimes dont load properly at all and just look like a wet clay figures without proportional faces speaking to me. (Although, sometimes added to the humour of their crazy dialogue)

Are you a returning player - Give it a go there are a lot of new content for PvE and PvP that i have yet to experience but is the main selling point currently

Are you a new player - Try it, it is a cheap game but beware that the return policy of steam is 2hrs gameplay time and you will likely spend 24hrs creating the perfect character so..
You can delete your life. Love it.
definitely reccomend, ive spent thousand of hours of fun on this game!

I restarted the game, changed game quality settings, forfeited the quest multiple times to no avail. Remove this shit questline and give us the rewards elsewhere. The whole experience with this questline is so frustrating that I quit the game. I hope there will be a day where this questline gets removed from the game.

Of course it's not a downvote. The game is very good, if you can manage to get over the truck load of information when you start the game, you will see it all makes sense and that this is an incredible game. Is it perfect? Hell no! Is it pay 2 win? yes it is, but, show me a good MMO similar to this one that is not monetized to a grave. This one at least is within reason, and the power aspect that you get with spending money is not that impactful as a lot might think... you can buy costumes, transform them into a "cron" items that help you level the gear, but it would cost you a ridiculous amount of money, talking here sums of 50k $ and up or way more to get the best of the best, and even then, you will still be crap at the game, cuz even then, someone that knows how to play his class can still kill you, not 1 shot you of course cuz you payed an entire house mortgage for that gear hehe would be insane, but by the second combo you will be dead.

As for new people that get into the game... try them all, don't focus on one thing or one activity, the game is very complex, you got enough content for years to try, to play, to perfect, grinding or PVP is just one of many things, and don't be afraid!

Hope you will find enjoyment in this game, even after 4.5 years, I still do.

I've decided to completely rewrite my review of black desert since I have put another 2700 hours into the game since then. How many of those are AFK cooking or fishing? Probably a lot. The game still fun? Yeah, it is. Let's talk.

This is still one of the most love/hate games I've ever played, and it's not subtle. Sometimes I love this game and wanna play nothing else just going between my characters, grinding my favorite spots, crafting, gathering, and pursuing the many different paths of progression. Sometimes I hate the game, everyone who plays it, and the people who made it. But I always come back, and I still recommend the game

THE GOOD: 

Graphics - This game can be very, very pretty if you have a machine that can handle some of the higher settings. The world is beautiful at times and even though I've seen practically every inch of the world many times over I still will pan over to watch a scenic view as I ride my horse around. The effects of the spells and abilities you throw out generally look impressive, though sometimes they kinda fill the screen. I like the little hit indicators signifying crits and back attacks. I can also say that the UI, though admittedly a bit for new players to get used to, is nice to look at. I don't think it really gets in the way and even if you think it does, it can be customized literally top to bottom in any way you can think of.

Combat - I love BDO's combat. This is one of the things that gets people to stay even if they have hangups about the game. It is very satisfying to learn the style of how everything fits together. If you've played fighting or other action games before, you will recognize some of these terms. Moves will have stuff such as forward guards, side guards, super armors, I-frames, knockdowns, knockups, and down smashes etc. You do extra damage when hitting an enemy in the back, and every class is very mobile compared to a lot of other MMO's out there. Abilities are activated with buttons like Q, E, Shift, left/right mouse buttons, and directional inputs to combo skills together. As you level up, you unlock flows, which can either extend a skill, give that ability a sort of clean up attack in between others, or add a sort of flourish on a skill if you hold down the input. Wizard's shift right click for example does a big water orb that explodes for damage and holding the right click to activate the flow causes him to snap his fingers and explode the area again. There are also a LOT of characters and more get added all the time. All the classes have something about them that's unique and none of them play quite the same. You can spend a lot of time learning the in's and out's of one you decide to invest some time into. You'll learn what's your best abilities are, get used to your cooldowns and resource management, what animations can be canceled, and generally achieve proficiency that's quite satisfying once you get the hang of it.

Crafting is viable - every single one of black deserts lifeskills could be a game all by themselves with their own track of meaningful progression and what's more is that they all have ways to make money which you can use to fund progression. Most everyone tends to do some form of gathering whether its mining, butchering meat, extracting blood or sap, farming, mining etc. And they do a really good job of tying into each other. While doing a lot of these lifeskills you'll receive byproducts and other items you can turn in for more goodies as well as byproducts that can be utilized in other aspects of the game. For example, cutting down trees will sometimes give you alchemy reagents. Mining gives you gems and different powders to craft with. Stuff like that. I could literally write thousands of words on just what I like to do for my cooking setup.

Freedom - the amount of things that you're allowed to do with this game blew my mind when I first started and makes you feel like your characters have a believable place in the world. You receive these things called contribution points when you complete quests. These can be spent to rent items like farm plots to plant things, invest in property, and in production/exploration nodes. They can also be withdrawn at any time and reinvested. You can just click on a town, click a building, and spend a couple points. Now you own a house. Now you can plop down some furniture, some cooking utensils/alchemy tools, maybe rent a storage chest to access your stash remotely. You can invest in those nodes I mentioned earlier and hire NPC workers to passively gather items for you. You can invest points into workshops, and use your workers to auto craft stuff for you over time. The amount of "do whatever you want" still feels great after all this time with the game.

THE BAD:

Very Beginner Unfriendly: For the first few days or even weeks you're playing the game you will be bombarded with complex intertwined systems and mechanics. Items that either aren't useful or seem important but don't have an apparent use to you. The game likes to throw a lot of items at you in login rewards and achievements and events and sometimes its a bit much. Pearl Abyss is trying over time to smooth this out and cut down on the amount of items in the game as well as do a better job of explaining what's going on to new and inexperienced players. That said, you will probably have to read some guides and watch some youtube or take some advice from a friend before you get into the swing

Sometimes there's jank: Sometimes I can't tell if the game is showing its age or if it's just a simple quality control thing or if it is intended. Sometimes you'll try to interact with something but your character needs to finish a movement skill animation so you have to just tap back to cancel it and then you can talk to the npc. Your horse can handle a bit wonky sometimes. The caution skill will literally bounce you backward off too steep an incline forcing you to either lock that skill or jump to keep riding your horse forward. There are a few literal hills in the game where this happens. Swimming is terrible. It's always been terrible. Don't try to swim anywhere. There used to be a ton of gear that gave you stats that weren't mentioned in the tooltip. There were food buffs that wouldn't give you the stats that they said they did. Said you got 20 accuracy, but you got 12, that kinda thing. Just weird, awkward stuff that should never happen. They do always fix these things but yeah, you play the game enough and you'll notice a bit of jank here and there.

Game really wants you to spend money: This has gotten a million times better since Kakao no longer is running the show and Pearl Abyss has stepped in after their contract with their publisher ran out. Before then, the game would throw a lot of inconveniences at you and dangle the option to swipe them away. Stuff like inventory spots, carry weight, a tent to repair your gear while not in town, maids to remotely send and retrieve things from storage. Stuff you didn't explicitly -need- but was so nice to have that you were very pressured to pay up. However, the pets were the worst. Pets pick up loot for you automatically when you kill monsters. And they were incredibly limited back in the day, practically forcing you to pay about ten dollars PER PET to get a team of five or be forced to double press R to pick up loot from each and every monster you killed. Its not that way anymore and you get a lot of stuff for free or they've changed the game to make these problems either disappear or not be nearly as much of a problem if you don't wanna spend more money. Big W.

I have tried numerous times to play and enjoy this game, and every time it has been a major letdown. The graphics look nice at the surface level, but between the pop-in issues, excessive bloom, and absurd amount of post-processing effects, it's hard to play more than an hour without getting a migraine. The quests/story are dull and uninspired, with poorly written dialogue and if arrows weren't on the ground pointing us where to go it would be so easy to be completely lost. The world design feels lifeless and fake. The user interface is by far one of the clunkiest and most overwhelmingly cluttered I have ever seen. The combat is just "okay". Since the developers have decided to try and make everything with the combat feel over-the-top and flashy, it all becomes meaningless very quickly. I found myself casting abilities that were massive, colorful, and loud, but they felt empty. I am convinced that the flood of positive reviews on this game are either bought or entirely fake. Don't waste your time with this game.

Black Desert este un joc remarcabil în multe feluri, cu o lume virtuală expansivă și o gamă largă de caracteristici captivante. Grafica sa uluitoare oferă peisaje impresionante, care te încântă de fiecare dată când explorezi noul teritoriu.

Sistemul de luptă dinamic este unul dintre cele mai plăcute aspecte ale jocului. Fiecare clasă are abilități unice și combinații variate, oferind o experiență de luptă diversificată și satisfăcătoare.

Interacțiunea cu comunitatea este intensă, iar colaborarea în bătălii masive și raiduri aduce o doză mare de adrenalină și distracție.

Sistemul de afaceri și economie este complex și implică diverse strategii pentru a obține profit și a progresa în joc.

De asemenea, Black Desert oferă o varietate de activități distractive și relaxante, cum ar fi crearea și gestionarea grădinilor sau pescuitul, pentru cei care doresc o experiență mai lejeră.

Pe scurt, Black Desert este un joc captivant și remarcabil, care oferă o mulțime de oportunități de aventură și explorare într-un univers virtual impresionant.

I didnt spend a single cent after my initial purchase and had a good time for the duration of my stay. So by all means, if you want to sink some time into a new game, this is a pretty easy entry and option to check it out.

Sadly the game falls into pay 2 win and pay 4 convenience traps. And to sell you the solution, the grind is painfully slow towards the late mid-endgame. Its a shame because the game is beautiful. Its easy to get lost in the world and enjoy the solid combat system. So by all means, if it interests you, get it or wait for a sale and give it a go. for 10(5)$ you can get more than enough bang for your buck.

Interested in seeing if BDO is for you? Take a few minutes to read this. (I use main client of game, not steam. I have thousands of hours into this and I'm well in to "End game" content)

First off lets get this out of the way. If you are looking for a cooperative based Raiding/Dungeon crawling game where you down bosses with a group for BiS gear, this is not the game for that. With that out of the way, keep reading.

-Are you a solo player primarily?
 
-Tired of having your gear you worked for become worthless in the next patch/expansion?

-Done with grouping with randoms in order to progress your level/gear?

-Want to relax and listen to music while grinding out countless enemies at your pace?

-Looking for large scale or small scale PvP fights?

-Don't want to even worry about doing any combat at all or just do minimal fighting?

-Are you someone who loves hitting leader boards? If not then no pressure.

-Want to chase after rare and unique collectibles such as mounts and treasures?

-Life have you busy with work/family/friends and so on but don't want to feel like you'll never get anywhere as a result?

-Looking to just relax with player owned houses, gorgeous scenery and character creation?

If you said yes to any or interested in finding out more about above, then Black Desert may have a place for you. Just keep an open mind and take the game at YOUR own pace. It is a marathon game and I cannot stress this enough. The game is far from perfect and holds its own flaws like any game out there but despite its flaws it still holds out to be an incredible experience if you are willing to take the time and learn all the depth behind it.

"Game is P2W" Yes this gets mentioned a lot. I've asked countless people on how they get their gear so strong. 99% of them have mentioned they just play the game over a long time or just get a lucky drop here and there. Yes P2W exists but its so rare to actually encounter someone who has and on top it hurts them to just walk up and kill you as a result due to the Karma system in game. There are items you can buy to increase storage and many other quality of life purchases but very few are actually needed since the devs constantly drop very generous sales, coupons and even give them away for free. By the time you'll even consider paying for such options, you'll have a better understanding of the game to make the decision if its worth buying or not. 

Pearl Abyss has made countless strides to make the game better and better over time and it keeps growing as a result. Black Desert has just been hit with very bad labels by early years or people with little to no understanding of how its many systems actually work. If you go in with an open mind and keep reminding yourself that it is a marathon and not a sprint, you may actually find your time worth while here. The gear YOU work for stays relevant for very long time. Some of the original items on release still hold up in very end game PvP/PvE to this day. Not many MMOs can say the same to that. 

While I can keep going on and on, I thought this should cover most of what I wanted to get across about Black Desert. Thank you for taking the time to read and feel free to comment on any questions or concerns.

Black Desert Online, developed by Pearl Abyss, is an ambitious MMORPG that successfully delivers on many fronts. With its stunning graphics, intricate gameplay mechanics, and immersive world-building, it manages to set itself apart in a genre teeming with competition.

One of the game's most compelling aspects is undoubtedly its deep character customization. You're provided with a myriad of options to craft your character's appearance and choose from a wide array of classes, each with their unique abilities, strengths, and weaknesses. This level of detail in customization truly makes your character feel like your own creation.

Visually, Black Desert Online is a feast for the eyes. The game's graphics are nothing short of stunning, with beautifully rendered environments, dynamic weather, and a day-night cycle that breathes life into the world. It's a pleasure to simply explore the expansive and diverse landscapes, from sprawling deserts to lush forests and bustling cities.

The combat in Black Desert Online is an exciting departure from many traditional MMORPGs. Instead of the usual point-and-click system, it incorporates active combat mechanics, including manual aiming, dodging, and combo-based attacks. This makes battles feel much more engaging and dynamic, ensuring that player skill is a significant factor in success.

Black Desert Online also offers a wealth of non-combat activities. Whether you're interested in crafting, trading, fishing, cooking, or even horse breeding, there are numerous professions and hobbies to engage with. These systems are surprisingly detailed, providing a welcome change of pace from battling monsters and completing quests.

However, Black Desert Online isn't without its flaws. The game can feel overwhelming for newcomers, with its complex systems and lack of clear direction at times. Also, while the game's PvP system offers a unique thrill, the potential for high-level players to engage lower-level players can sometimes lead to unbalanced encounters.

The storyline, while rich in lore and interesting concepts, can sometimes feel overshadowed by the breadth of other activities available. Also, the quests can often fall into the pattern of typical MMORPG fare with many focusing on grinding and fetch quests.

Despite these drawbacks, Black Desert Online stands out as a deep and engaging MMORPG with a stunning world to explore. Its commitment to complex systems and player freedom creates a highly immersive experience that will enthrall fans of the genre.

In conclusion, Black Desert Online offers a vast, visually stunning world filled with adventure, action, and a deep sense of immersion. It might be a bit daunting for beginners, but for those willing to delve into its complexities, it provides an incredibly rewarding experience.

This MMORPG has one very important advantage over other games in this genre, and that's the price. You get ALL available content in the game for a very cheap price. There are no expansions or subscription systems, which usually make me want to vomit. People call this game P2W, but there is only one thing you can get with money that you can't get without it, and it's the tent. The tent makes it possible to buy potions (which are useless in late-game) and repair gear anywhere you want. I don't think this item is necessary, but even if you're a bit of a tryhard it's still cheaper to get the tent than, e.g., all expansions in Guild Wars 2. You can also buy a lot of different stuff for money, but all of this is usually sold on the market, and you can buy it for in-game currency.
This game is VERY grindy. You will spend hundreds, if not thousands, of hours grinding for a part to a cool life-hacking tool. (e.g., Infinite potion) Even though this game requires you to grind, it's not that much of a burden because of the combat system. You have a lot of classes (probably around 20 atm) and every one of them has 2 skill sets, 2 completely different play styles, and 2 different weapons. Very fancy animations and skills make grinding a bit more satisfying. 
This game has probably the best character creation in any MMORPG, with its other competitors being FF14 and Lost Ark. Every class has tons of skins, some better, some worse, but the popular ones you can get from the marketplace. It's not a very efficient system because usually outfits are sold once every few months; it depends on the outfit's popularity. The scenario where you are waiting for a skin for more than a year is pretty possible.
The game has an enormous open world that isn't as boring as in other MMORPGs. The problem is that you will travel a lot, and if you don't have a good horse, you will take your time. Getting a "decent" horse is only really possible by buying it from another player. If you want to try catching, breeding, and training horses, there is no way you are going to make it efficient without spending real money.
One last thing I want to talk about is the community. I haven't met anyone in this game who is under 25yo. People playing this game are old(I guess MMORPGs in general have older communities, but I'm not sure).  I found this community very toxic, and that's really off-putting. 
This is still the MMORPG I enjoyed the most, and I played a lot of them. It's getting regular updates, and the game has become really welcoming to newer players with the season system. There are new classes every year, new events, and overall new stuff being added to the game up to this day.
I would recommend to solo players.

Played WOW, ESO, and FF14.  By far the best combat system I've experience.  Some stuff probably still needs work.  The UI and questing is a bit clunky.  Main story line is kinda boring. Some items in game lack clear explanation on its uses.  Storage for new players is pretty bad.  Took me a while to figure out that i can purchase residency at city location to purchase extra storage for my character.  

Despite some of these flaws, the positive features far outweigh the negatives.  The graphics are gorgeous.  The combat is very smooth and I'm excited to experience more of it on different characters.  And the online community is pretty awesome and helpful, which is a pleasant surprise.  The best part of an MMO is the community.  And when its fill with good people, it makes me want to stick around.  I'm still very new to the game but I'm definitely going to stick around for a while.  Hope this info is  helpful to anyone that is nostalgic for a pretty solid MMO.

Ever since I started playing this game back from 2020, the game has been improving by A LOT especially in p2w area. However even after all that, the game is far from perfect especially on other areas. Here are some of main problems I've with the game.

- Questing: This one is my biggest problem with the game. The game quests are VERY JANKY and the animations in cutscenes are off-putting whenever it glitches out and it does it A LOT. I know this is not an easy thing to fix since there's so much quests in this game that needs to be fixed, but I hope that PA keeps improving this especially in future contents. The fact that new players are going to experience these janky quests firstly is the reason why many are going to be disappointed and may instantly stop playing.

- Grinding spots: Now that the game is getting more players, it's really hard to find a free grind spots. Whenever I go to for example at Elvia Orcs or Star's End (some popular grind spots), there's always players who comes crashing/requesting DFS after just few mins of me starting to grind there. This is annoying and it usually ends up me stop playing the game for rest of the day. On bright side there's 1h 05min daily private instances in Elvia Realms, which I really hope that it gets extended to 3h which would let me grind it peace. Tbh they just should bring daily timed privated instances to every grind spots outside of Elvia Realms.

- Channel hopping: On top of the previous mentioned problem of finding free grind spots, the channel hopping cooldown of 15 minutes is very annoying. That's basically wasting 15min of my time waiting to hop the channel that was previously taken into another channel and hope that the next one is free which is very unlikely. Removing this cooldown entirely or reducing it significantly would help.

On some bright note, let's talk about some things that really like about this game and feel where BDO truly shines at.

- Combat: This is pretty obvious as everyone is already aware how great the combat is in the game. All of classes in the game has excellent and high quality animations attached to their combat style with action-combat oriented controls which I find very fun and more engaging instead of traditional hot bar in MMOs (altho there's option/way to play it with hot bar if you wished to).

- Progression: Since this game is like a sandbox open-world game, you can play this game however you want and go where-ever you want to go. What's so great about it, is that you can have same end-goal as someone else, but getting to there can be very different from person to person. For example there's so many ways to reach your end-goal of 700 GS gear, you can enchant your gear till there, grind mobs or do life skill to earn money and then buy the gear from market instead or you could just work towards it slowly at your own phase by doing all of those that were previously mentioned combined. Also for new players, the progression has improved so much with Season Servers, where it's easier way to progress and by the end of it, you'll have a pretty good gear to start your journey with.

- Amount of content: I really appreciate that this game has so much contents and events and it continuously is still getting more by the quite frequent updates. Whether you're life skiller, PvE:er or PvP:er, this game has it all. There's also so many classes in the game (24+) that you can create and try out. There's so many ways to spend your time in this game. Even after all these years, I constantly find something new about this game.

- Visuals/Graphics: The game looks absolutely gorgeous. From it's weather effects to the outstanding plains and environment, the game has one of the best graphics in the whole MMO genre despite being almost a decade old game.

- Character customization: The game has one of the best character customization and I wouldn't be surprised if some spends their whole day in character creation screen.

In all I hope the game keeps improving and at least address the issues I had with the game. It's really cool that devs of the game interacts and engages with the community. I still very enjoy the game and will continue playing it as long as it keeps getting better and pump out contents by each update.

👍 The Developers are making changes to shift from the previously horrible systems that forced players into spending a lot of real life money just to have the necessities to enjoy the game.

👍 The Combat system in this game is really fun.

👍 Life skill professions are also done nicely in Black Desert.

👍 A lot of gear equalized content, to some degree reducing the impact of pay to win.

What changes I would like to see:

 ⚠️ Need to increase inventory slots and weight granted by value pack by a margin!

 ⚠️ Need to make outfits un-meltable at blacksmith for cron stones upgrades (cosmetics should be cosmetic, cron stones prevent downgrade or destruction of gear or accessories respectively when used in enhancing/honing gear)

 ⚠️ Need to add a party finder for dungeons and add more dungeons/bosses.

I feel like the game is at a crossroads and can go either way at the moment. The game has a lot of item bloat so you'll nearly max out your inventory and all of the different city storages available within 80 hours of playing if you hoard items like a beginner, then what you can do is spend money to expand it, also the weight limitations will cause you to stop grinding every 30 minutes. As a player with a value pack and 4x weight expansion from loyalty store, when grinding polly forest I had to stop every 30 minutes due to weight, meaning I was wasting some of my time from the 1 hour XP scroll buffs I have consecutively used beforehand.

Now to the negatives, some of these are personal taste, some is just badly designed on purpose so you spend:

👎 DAMAGE NUMBERS ARE NOT AVAILABLE. This is to compensate for the bad class balancing, instead of throwing out 23+ classes, how about you focus on balance?

👎 Item bloat: One type of monsters can drop like 5 gray vendor items, 3 or 4 coursair training (something with horses idk), different type of enhancement materials, and you generally get your inventory filled up really quickly.

👎 Inflation: In the end game you are counting money in the millions and billions, either introduce gold as a character bound currency, worth X silver, to auto convert and make business as regular or find a way to make the big amounts count, spending 3 million silver in this game is like spending 50 copper in WoW.

👎 Weight limit: Serves no other purpose but to give incentive in buying additional weight capability. Why do gray vendorable items have 0.10 weight attached to it?

👎 Class identity: A great majority of classes are basically the same, it's AOE with different colors mostly inside a mid-range or close range melee category, only 3 classes can be even somewhat good at range: Witch, Wizzard and Archer, this is out of like 23+ classes meaning at least 20 classes and almost twice that of specializations are just different flavors of melee and midrange circular attacks.

👎 A lot of sub systems mixed into the convenience of the game making it confusing at the time to know what does what, requires a lot of youtube and google.

👎 Questing and the scenario of quests is usually so bad, that just listening to the NPCs/reading quests or watching cutscenes will make you feel your brain turning into mush, press and hold R, skip when you can.

👎 Fairy and Maid systems are not a good experience, the first one can auto consume potions but requires luck to get the correct tier of fairy and is a remnant of the pay to convenience, and the latter is required to access storage or auction market globally.

Honestly this game could have been amazing.

When it first launched it was ahead of the times. Now its a laughing stock of an MMO.

Graphically it is stunning (character models) particularly the females , when the game inst suffering terrible pop ins, glitches and terrible line of sight problems. When it functions it is a very pretty game indeed.

This is easily the best CREATE A WAIFU simulator out there in the mmo space.

That is the only good thing about this game.

Everything else is garbage. The over bloated menu systems the terrible optimisation, 
The over complicated quest design, the terrible sub menu and trading system.

The whole game needs overhauling from the start to the attempted "new version" which is effectively a soft reboot of the game.  However why give players a choice to start there , just make players start there and build the game around it.

I was one of the first to actually BUY the game before it went F2P. The in game purchases are what you expect from mobile and F2P games, but when I bought the game it was not a F2P title.

I never got any recompense for that or any bonuses for having an OG account. 

The Combat and the combo system is why this game is still popular and it can be very fun if you find the right group of people or friends to run around in the pop in world to enjoy. However it does not last for long
and the grind for xp and boring quest design soon shines through.

Its a shame because this is easily one of the better looking games in the MMO market its just a shame aside from the beautiful females you can create and the fun combat system everything else is god tier awful.

It has a lot to offer if you like doing quests, and its one of the better looking mmorpg's out there. Gathering, hunting, fishing, farming, cooking, crafting, trading are most of the life skills you can work on separately for each class you create giving you even more to do if you dont feel like doing quests that day. It has just about everything you can think of, so it more than likely has something that you will enjoy doing. My advice though, if you decide to try it is as soon as you start playing the game find a good guild to join! There are people that will be more than happy to help you with anything you might have questions about. If you end up in a guild that does not have helpful people, then leave it and find another one. This game kind of gives you a rough idea on how to do a few things but will expect you to just figure everything out on your own. So a guild in my opinion is a must!

[b][u]I'll try to keep this review as simple as I can for such an extensive game - below are my personal favourite parts about the game:[/u]

- Character customisation is amazing[/b] (I'm talking from the perspective of the female characters, I have to admit I haven't made any male characters.) You also get about 15 days free customisation on already created characters if you're new to the game - just hit F4 in-game to be taken back to the customisation menu. Customisation differs slightly between classes, with some hairstyles/tattoos only being available to certain classes.

[b]- The combat system,[/b] this is definitely the best part for most people - currently I've only played extensively on the Corsair, but her combat is really beautiful. You can tell they've put a hell of a lot of thought into this aspect of the game, and it's really paid off. All classes have their own unique combat, including unique effects - for example, [spoiler]being pirate themed, the corsair has a lot of water splashing effects & will also activate a mermaid/siren appearance during some combat skills.[/spoiler]

[b]- Game has a horse taming system.[/b] In fact, this was my main reason for getting the game. The system is difficult to get used to, but again with some time spent googling, you get the hang of it. I've found the best method is [spoiler]4 sugar cubes + 30 second wait, I've never been kicked more than once doing that.[/spoiler]

[b]- All of your created characters will share your worker empire, mounts, and city/town storage.[/b] (They don't share skills, but this is why you should have a main character to focus on. Your main draw to creating alt characters will mainly be because they have separate energy levels - this is needed for hiring workers or unlocking new trade locations if you can't be asked to run all the way over to them.)

[b]- Residences.[/b] Along with being able to set up workshops, storage houses & worker lodging, you can also own up to 5 residences for personal use. These can be decorated with furniture from the pearl shop, or from furniture vendors, plus it's a place to keep your pets.

[b][u]Now on to the negatives:[/u]

- Lack of hand holding.[/b] The game has so many features, and explains nearly none of them. This does make the game difficult to get into, and really takes you out of the experience when you have to keep referring to google or the adventurers guide.

[b]- No fast travel system.[/b] Again, this is another draw to creating alt characters, as your character can be transported while you play on another character, but I just think this is odd. The developers have clearly acknowledged the long travel times by adding this feature, but surely a fast travel feature would have been far easier to put in place? Even if this is only available between cities, similar to World of Warcraft.

[b][u]Overall,[/u] the content in this game is the main draw point.[/b] It's like a mix between an RPG and an empire tycoon. (If you choose to work on the worker gathering and trading aspects of the game, that is.) My main issue would be the lack of hand holding in this game - it's great that they encourage players to figure things out for themselves, but you end up spending a hell of a lot of time on google trying to figure out how to do anything.

I hope that this review has been helpful, I personally love the game, and although I have a few issues with it I don't think they are big enough issues to put me off of trying to work around them. Thank you for reading.

[b][u]235 Hours Update: It's been a while since I first started this game and wrote that first review, so I figured I'd check in again from the perspective of a later-game player - my newly discovered pet peeves are below:[/u]

Horse Breeding -[/b] This is a feature I would have LOVED to use more, but with males only having x2 breeding chances and females only having x1 before you have to spend real money to reset them, I think this system very quickly becomes a huge hassle - of course you could always capture wild horses and breed them 1-2 times before needing to capture more horses to replace your breeders, but again this is a lot of work for even just low tier horse breeding.

[b]Dyes -[/b] A beautiful feature in BDO is being able to dye your clothing and also your horse's armour - you obtain these dyes either by a monthly subscription to a pallet that gives you access to all dyes, or you can play russian roulette with the random dyes to get something close to the colours you want, and have them permanently. [spoiler](There is of course a select few dyes that are on the players market, but these are very rarely stocked and will cost your life savings of in-game coin.)[/spoiler] [b]This system is absolutely horrific,[/b] I understand it must be quite the money maker from their end, but from a players point of view this is just a needlessly painful system.

[b]The story is... Meh.[/b] I admit this may just be my short attention span, but I find myself skipping the dialogue pretty much constantly before hitting the rare cutscene and going "WOAH what's happening here???" - more frequent cutscenes would have been brilliant, but maybe that's just me. I also acknowledge that takes way more time than just giving you a few text boxes.

[b][u]Now just to do things backwards from my original review, here's some things I've gained even more appreciation for since the start of this journey:[/u]

The in-game world really is gorgeous,[/b] I can't help but stare in amazement at so many of the places I ride by, and I have such an appreciation of getting to know the trails that I take often and starting to recognise the small features of the land as you make your way back home really is such a nice feeling. Even after all this time, I still don't feel like I've explored everywhere.

[b]Residences -[/b] I have such a love for games that give you a home and allow you to choose exactly where you'd like to call home - I think this feature is so cozy, with being able to come back to your pets and all your storage items, stopping by to craft and cook, stopping by the furniture vendors in Calpheon to bring a ridiculous amount of candles home - living in Britain currently where mortgages are becoming insanely expensive, having a place to call your own even just in a game really brings a lot of peace.

[b]Character customisation just keeps getting better -[/b] I don't mean to repeat everything that I already had an appreciation for, but honestly seeing your character evolve with you really is a nice feeling, I will admit I have spent far too much on cosmetic items (Dyes included, even though I still hate their system) it is really nice to have your own unique look, and to see everyone else's styles through their characters too.

[b][u]Overall, I think you can see where I stand on this game - [/u][/b] I very much treat this game as just a pretty cozy life sim game most of the time, and it stands as a solid game even if you only focus on those features. Whenever you're in the mood to quest and start fights, that option is open to you.

It really is such a diverse game, and I couldn't recommend it more for anyone with an interest in life sim games, rpg games, combat games, empire tycoon games - or even just a pretty game to take screenshots in.

In short: As a new player I feel overwhelmed with "new and shiny" while starving to understand the basics. As casual player of MMOs I don't want to spend hours reading wiki to find out about the basic stuff.

Game feels like you are thrown in the middle of casino. So many flashing icons, daily, hourly "click here" where reward is something you don't know what is it good for. Combat, gathering, crafting? Sure we have those. No we won't spent time explaining how to do basic, because... look another flashy icon click it! Oh back to combat, just smash your keyboard randomly it will do the trick. I did not? Just smash more keys it will work. You care to know what are those icons or what effects the skills you use have? Forget it, animations are cool that's all you need to know.

For real now. Graphic is nice, combat looks cool and game probably has many options to keep players busy. I say probably because not many of the game mechanics are explained to you. There is some story line with narrated quests and it feels weird to be honest. Audio is out of sync or not playing at all unit you interact with NPC again. I have never seen so many graphical glitches related to texture collisions and lighting in MMO game ( This is first modern MMO I played in a while so it might be "standard" in these days ). HUD is in default filled with stuff I don't need or even worse find very annoying. I really don't care who failed enchanting their item and don't see any reason to pop up alert message with sound to let me know about it ( can be turned off in settings ). Instead I would like to know how to make font size bigger and letters looks crisp, since changing HUD size can make it hard to read. 

//Giving the game another chance. I can confirm previous statement, too much stuff very confusing. Because the season exp bonuses, you really don't spend much time in places where basics are explained by quests (gathering, cooking, etc.). At level ~60 there is next "progress" in combat style and I have no clue what is going on with this or what to choose and what I loose for it. This is the final point for me. I learned quite enough about professions but combat is just smashing keyboard... no idea how those combination works, with season equip mobs can't even scratch you so it does not matter.

Why should you play Black Desert Online you might ask yourself?

Black Desert is ultimately THE BEST Sandbox MMORPG out there.
Do what you want, enjoy what you want. If you don't like it then don't do it, in Black Desert Online you are froming your own path.

Since its first release things drastically changed, we swapped from Kakao Games to Pearl Abyss which has been the best thing that could've happen with this game. The old Cashshop Company Kakao Games is not involved with this Game anymore hence giving us the Cashshop we have today. Since the Game is under Pearl Abyss's roof completly and alone, you are getting free items. Do you ever need to purchase something from the Cash Shop? Yes you do, the Pearl Tent. 
Is it expensive? 50 Bucks and you decide if you grab it for that price or cheaper, you can get it for 15 Bucks too if you're buying it in sale combined with coupon and once its time that you kinda have to pick up the tent, you have sunken hundreds of hours into the game anyway.  So what are you getting for your  5 ( 55/20 bucks).
You get a great Sandbox MMORPG where you decide what you do. 
Are you a fan of grinding then go grind.
Do you want to lifeskill/Sail a Ship or just take screenshots? Go ahead. 
Whatever you want to do you probably going to find it here. 
Don't listen to the but its a job game of comments...
It can be, they decide it to make it a job. Show me a single MMORPG besides FFXIV where you can pepega clap everything in a day. 5 heads nowadays think a game needs to be done in a day or two. BDO is a marathon, if you decide to grind you decide to grind. You don't need to if you don't want. The Game has Seasons which will give you a headstart in this, but since Arena of Solare is out, enjoy your gear balanced pvp where you can jump in without any restrictions, where experienced players clap you anyway cause you are simply a bad player and they actually saw the potential of the game instead of complaining about having to grind in a MMORPG.
good

Holy shit they made it good? I played in 2016 and while the combat was great the pay2win was way too strong, progression was way too RNG, and the PVE was very underwhelming. In the current state of the game my previous complaints have all been addressed and also thare are a ton of classes to play with a bunch of different playstyles/aesthetics on offer. "Seasonal" characters are a fantastic catch-up mechanic while also being the best implementation of alt-boosting I've ever seen. 

BDO remains very dense and unwieldy at times, but that's a part of there being a massive amount of content on offer, with none of it gated behind paying. Game is pretty much funded by cosmetic underwear sales nowadays it seems.

The combat system is extremely fun.
Once you reach ~220AP the game becomes a job.

I enjoy BDO casually, and it's evolved to where you don't need any micro-transactions from the Pearl shop to enjoy the game.

It's not for everyone, so please read up on the game (PVE and PVP) to see if it's right for you before buying, especially understand the chance system for upgrading armor and weapons. There is a LOT to do and it can become quite a time-sink.

July 2023 Update

A ton of videos and people have been bragging about how good the experience is now for new players. I made a new account and logged in. 20+ minutes of unskippable cutscenes and p2w instantly thrown in my face. BUY THE BATTLE PASS WEEE day 1 get an outfit box you can sell on the market for 600+ million silver. So literally selling silver for $..... what a sick joke
Nothing has changed, don't be fooled by idiotic youtubers and fan bois trying who are paid to speak positively about the game, or who are trying to save this dying game....
____

I played this game when it launched originally in KR. 

It wasn't very enjoyable because of the lag, and the NA players stood no chance in PVP.

I quit the game 

One day saw that BDO had come to steam!

Alright finally time to play on NA servers!

I played a few hundred hours before quitting...

Finally I decided I would give BDO one last try

I made 5 characters within 4 weeks

a lvl 60- Shai for the event
a lvl 59- Archer 
a lvl 61- Mystic 
a lvl 60- Warrior
a lvl 61- Guardian 

Okay so here's what I've learned, and here is why Im quitting for good this time...

1. Questing will level you faster than grinding ever will. This is up until lvl 61 where after you hit 61 you get 100x less exp from questing than at lvl 60. So 1-61 is easy , everything else after that is the most cancerous grind you could imagine. Around .1 to .3% exp per hour of grinding depending on your gear etc.

2. There are way too many p2w things in this game. Anyone who says this game isn't p2w is delusional...

Here are all the p2w options that exist in the game

- You can buy more weight to make it so that your character can hold more items. This is important because the devs intentionally made potions weigh a fuck ton so you can barely keep any on you. 

- You can buy more inventory slots ... 

- You can buy more character slots - This is broken because you can make alts and position each one at different "world bosses" so when one spawns you can just change characters and boom no need to travel across the world...

- You can buy a Tent - The tent you can buy is 50 dollars and makes it so you have an additional storage and your own personal vendor. Vendor sells potions and you can sell trash loot to it which is huge since silver has no weight anymore. Finally an "anvil" that lets you repair without going back to town. The way the game was programmed your gear breaks after just an hour of grinding and you have to go repair it. You lose alot of time without a tent. Tent is 50$ and there is no ingame "free" equivalent to this. This is considered MANDATORY by all hardcore players...

- You can buy pets that auto loot for you. You cannot play this game without pets.. 
When you are doing "rotations" or farming in an area you need to be able to loot and move on. However manually looting requires you to walk over the exact loot drop, and press R , press R again. So stop and double tap R and lose minutes every rotation looting.
Pets are mandatory and not exactly cheap either. When you buy a pet from the pearl shop its a tier 1 pet. You can smash pets together to make higher tiers. Up to tier 5!
Some people have 5 maxed out tier pets which probably ran em a few hundred dollars per pet.

- You can pay to win @ enhancing
You can buy outfits from the pearl shop and then "extract" the cron stones out of them. You can then use the stones to protect your gear from degrading when you enhance.
You can also protect accessories from exploding when you fail. Not only can you do that, but you can directly sell these outfits on the market for like 200 mill silver. 

- The PVP in this game is 100% gear based
(Dont listen to any idiots that say its skill because its not. Better gear always wins)
Skill only factors in if you and your opponent have identical Gear Score.
Every class is pretty easy to learn, and after grinding for hundreds of hours you will easily master your "combos"
However... if someone has a total of 300 AP they get a bonus of 200 AP.
The game grants you bonus stats for reaching certain thresholds.
(AP stands for Attack Power/Points and represents the base number that your skills use to multiply with the damage percentages to deal damage.)
Most new players have under 100 ap and it takes awhile to work up to 200.
It can take years to get to 250 ap and the people close to 300 will hit 300 before you ever will
Which means you will get fucked everywhere you go

- If someone pk's you, you will lose 1% exp. This is huge at higher levels and you can avoid this penalty if you pay for pearl shop items.

- There's a transaction maid and marketplace butler that let you access storage/marketplace from wherever you are. Normally you would have to go to town or to the correct npcs. This is huge P2W.

- You can buy more storage in every town with real money

- You can buy worker residence that you cant get any other way with real money 

______________________________________________

The p2w is one thing... but there's more 

For example the game tries to make you stay logged in and keep your computer on....

If you afk you can make money or get exp/skill point by afking etc

Some people will afk grind for months just to reach higher levels... how pathetic

In a time where everyone is trying to save money, BDO tries to make you keep your pc on...

There is also no fast travel so you spend a ton of time auto traveling from place to place... 

The amount of p2w in this game is unreal and if you play this game you will eventually feel forced to drop more and more and more money...

The devs made the game in this way to leech every bit of $ from their players while providing very minimal content

It gets worse though... the main selling point of this game is PVP and GuildVsGuild

However the PVP is super laggy/stuttery and not balanced at all..

Gear will trump everything of course but certain classes are massively stronger than the rest...

Not only that but people can RMT by selling guild payouts 

When a guild captures a node or city they make alot of silver that goes into the guild bank

The guild leader can issue "payouts" that take 40% of the total guild funds and send em to all the members

Well massive guilds bring in more silver by capturing cities for a week than some guilds make in over a year

The old guilds that have been around for a long time probably have trillions in guild funds 

If you haven't gotten the hint yet it means you will never compete with people that been playing for a very long time

This game needs "seasons" and "wipes" to stay competitive 

OR 

Gear needs to not be nearly as important in PVP, as it is now (where gear is the only thing that matters)

The game is grindy beyond imagination and you will have to make this MMO your fucking JOB to actually enjoy it

There are plenty of other games and soon to be released MMO'S that wont do this to you

Don't make the mistake that so many people made in this game sinking tens of thousands of hours( and money) and regretting it 

I want to add that I did enjoy the concept of the game and animations so much.

I wish I could love and enjoy this game but im not a SIMP

The choices the Devs made on this game killed it. Im sure there are plenty of SIMP's who will continue to play and support the game financially

The amount of Grind and P2W cannot justify the gameplay

Eventually everyone gets fucking sick and tired of rotating their cooldowns and the only part of the game left to enjoy is the PVP...and the fucking PVP is dominated purely by Gear Score.. 

Which can be achieved through p2w and most of the players who have been here since launch will just wipe the floor with you

A guy that started 1 year ago and is still grinding, will always surpass you

There are people who have been playing since launch.. good fucking luck m8

Save yourself, your money, and your time for a better MMO or ARPG

Games awful.

Keybinds don't save even after hitting "Apply" followed by "Confirm". Keep in mind this is an MMO, which means every time I boot the game I have to fully rebind all my keys. Haven't even been able to get through the tutorial due to this garbage because every time I boot up the game I spend 30 minutes rebinding keys.

There's a black spirit. If you play Genshin, imagine every bad thing people say about Paimon but this time it's true. The Black Spirit will pop up and try and tutorialize the game for you by telling you what to do. But guess what, both the Black  Spirit and the hotkey "tips" they give you cannot be removed during the tutorial (or at least I haven't seen how yet, you can't modify the UI in the tutorial) use the default keybinds, meaning if you've changed them the tips they give you are wrong.

Did I mention you can't alter the UI in the tutorial? Who the hell thought this was a good idea.

Game looks really bad and washed out even at max settings.

May get a refund, may just let it sit on my account. Doubt I'm actually going to play it though. To be clear to everyone though, as a veteran of WoW, GW2, EQ, all that "quality of life" content creators are bragging about doesn't mean jack when getting through the tutorial of the game is torture.
I am happy Pearl Abyss at last has their game back in their full control and making the needed updates to the game. May it continue and begin a new era of BDO :)

Pros:
- Amazing graphics, best out of any MMO by far
- Biggest Life skills system out of any MMO by a longshot (Only runescape I'd say is even compared, but barely)
- Full Deep Character customization (the amount of detail you can add to a character is insane)
- Friendly/Welcoming Player Base (Most friendly MMO Playerbase I've ever experienced, just welcoming people in general)
- Intermediate to hard and grindy Content that makes you feel accomplished when finally achieving your goal, especially if you go the F2P route. (F2P takes time, but it is possible and by 1000 hours or so, you could have a really high GS and nice empire built up if your smart about how you play in the beginning)
- World Content has things like Boss encounters with tons of active/ different types of servers defeating the boss at the same time, even sailing content or hunting. The sailing takes you on the seas with cannons and boats like an old Pirates of the Caribbean meet up. Many, many boats show up to fight the sea monster/ monsters. Theirs also content where a big Hunt party tracks a certain monsters around the world at a fast rate and the group or platoon to do the most damage in these events gets a special reward, along with the regular award. 
- There is tons of Daily Content you can do, one is known as rifts which reaps great rewards and is a nice way to get silver and more items to help your adventure. You can do it alone on regular servers or together with friends in Dark Rifts, but only for season servers. Also don't forget about daily professions quest because there are plenty of those + regular daily quest like any other MMO. Theres also team rifts you can do with friends, it's triggered when everybody adds the same amount of summons to the this floating daimond artifact, it's fun and can be a challenge too.
- Season characters - SEASON CHARACTERS are toons you can create that have higher XP gains and everything such as a leveler needs to level up fast. These characters play on specific servers and get many perks even free upgrade materials and chances to upgrade Gear in the future better. This character makes the Paying to Win function irrelevant because these characters XP can be copied, thus making another character the same level as your season character when your done with the season! This is more valuable then having a deep pocket 100%. SOO this character (if you level it up) is a free boost plus 1!! In BDO having more characters helps your overall family of characters, it increases daily rewards in almost all aspects, especially if they are leveled up to at least LVL 56. 
- Instance Content - BDO offers a plethora of instance content and a lot of it gets integrated with the game itself + your friends, nothing in BDO gets left behind. When you complete things like the Magnus or Antoraxxion you open up more instance content availability and also more convenience items to help you in your Journey.
- Beautiful Animations/ Remastered mode
- Great Central market with being able to buy things that you can buy with real money, with silver. So if you can earn the silver you can buy it, most things are reasonable in the market too, this actually builds the games economy while simultaneously building the player morale and incentive, its like a return.
- Best Combat in any MMO by far, more flashy, more effects (you can dimm the effects like I do) more moves, more options and key combos like a fighting game..(LOL  WUT!) 
- 26 Players Classes.....like WOWW need I say more....
- Worker/ Empire building - By far the best part about the game. The worker system involving Contribution points and energy is phenominal. You gain energy and Contribution through questing and discovery, one way is by defeating enemies, thus giving you the knowledge on that certain enemy you defeated. This increases energy. Things like touching a book on a wall in a library can give you knowledge, also increasing your energy. Quests from what I  can tell give you the most contribution. Overall this system incentivises exploration and travel, making the player discover more :)
- This ones going to be controversial, but I love the weapon upgrade system, it adds way more spice to upgrading gear than any other game. Thats because theres a chance it will fail and even downgrade the weapon, even degrade it making you have to pay big silver to repair. This is frustrating to some but this is also why the grind is rewarding when you do get that upgrade finally, like you earned it buddy GRATS for real! So that being said cash will not help you in this aspect unless you are literally filthy rich and have  10,000+ to spend or more. Thats very unreasonable too and honestly youd'd have to spend more than 10k to max a charcter. SOOO its hilarious that people say this game is P2W...its not at all unless you have 20k buddy, moving on. I'm guessing half of the people or more who play this game play it for free or at the least dont pay a a lot. The monthly pass is worth it, I'd say. Though its like a sub, it gives you certain benefits but I would stay away.
- Loyalty Points: You gain these for signing in once a day, you can use this currency for rewards to help you on your adventure.

Cons
- PearlShop can be very expensive and the prices can be predatory to players
- Pay for convienience is there (NOT PAY TO WIN)
- Pay real money for small amounts of materials and other items such as Pets, horse skins, apparel + more cosmetic is available (Not enough materials to make a true difference unless you sign in everyday. At that point you'd use the loyalty currency they have for signing in once a day)
- World chat can get annoying to look at, I prefer to shrink mine

---- HONESTLY I HAVE NO MORE NEGATIVES.... LMAO, I love this game

I'll edit this more in the future when I think about more stuff, but for now I'm headed to bed, thanks for the read.

[b]Pvp 6/10:[/b]
Cons: Not balanced, doesnt require any skill, gear dependant, heavy d-sync, class carried, not interesting battleground, large scale pvp = lagfest
Pros: Non-target, cool animation, interesting combos, fast paced
Conclusion: Pvp is interesting if you have friends to fight against, and after you reach the minimum required gear to do it. Until then, dont even bother...
[b]Updated PvP ?/10:[/b]
2023. Still D-Sync-ed, more batllegrounds, not sure about anything else, but at high-end it's skill based, also Arena of Solare with capped gear which is nice

[b]Pve 6/10:[/b]
Cons: Repetitive, boring, no dungeons, no raids, basically an offline game
Pros: A big variation in grinding spots, till you reach endgame
[b]Updated PvE 8/10:[/b]
2023. Same as before, but now we have weekly dungeons and weekly solo boss "rushes" with leaderboards (if you are interedted, google "BDO Boss Rush"), even more grind spots

[b]Lifeskills ?/10:[/b]
Never tried, wasnt interested, but there is a large variety of lifeskills you can do, like gathering, fishing, alchemy, cooking, sailing, etc.
[b]Updated Lifeskills ?/10:[/b]
2023. Still not doing lifeskills :) But heard there are some changes, also sniper hunting which is currently the best money/h in the game which is nice

[b]Graphics 9/10:[/b]
Best visuals i have ever seen in an MMORPG, can be glichy sometimes in certain areas...
[b]Updated Graphics 9/10:[/b]
2023. Remastered mode, there are some grapichal bugs here and there, but still beautiful.

[b]Gameplay 9/10 before it gets boring, after its a 6/10...[/b]
2023 Update: still standing beside this

[b]Overall 7/10[/b]

There is a learning curve to the game and trying to learn everything at once will probably not be enjoyable. Stick to the main quest and take it slowly. The game tries to be more forgiving to new players with the concept of seasons and by giving a bunch of stuff to you at the start. They even let you change your character's appearance an unlimited number of times for the first two weeks so don't worry about just jumping in with a default look. If you are ok with doing a little research and you like MMOS I would definitely give this game a try.

This game is beautiful. I mean beautiful. Followed by Gameplay and Story this honestly is a nearly 10/10 perfect MMO. However the main flaw that messes it all up is the pay to win features. No matter what you do or how much time you dump into this game. There is always going to be a rich kid who will buy his way past you in game.

I want to say, just try it. Play it till you start to feel like your grinding then stop. However there are a lot of people with addictive personality that need to stay away from this. Once you dip into your wallet with in game items, most people cant stop. 
You will also have to keep in mind. There is also no getting to the top of the leader boards in PVP, Collector items, or other in game goals with out that wallet being opened. 

7/10 - A nearly perfect MMO with bad monetization. Spend your time and money on something else.

New player experience is completely awful.  A ton of menus, items, popups, alerts.  The game just drops you in and says "good luck".  You use "energy" to be able to chat in the game, when your energy runs out, you have to buy more in the shop or wait 5 min to be able to talk.  Combat is extremely convoluted and the graphics are mid.  Black Convoluted Online is what this game should be called.  There are systems within systems within systems and the game doesn't tell you how any of it works.  The pay for convenience in this game is extremely present.  As an example, it's almost $50 for a tent (everyone says you can't play without one)...No thanks.

The game has come along way since its arrival. I played when it was first released and had fun for the first few months until I hit a pay wall. I can say since Pearl Abyss has broken away from it's former publisher, and in its current state, it is worth playing. Most of the P2W from the past has been mitigated, and players can earn most of the items by just playing the game. Only draw back continues to be the weapon enhancement system which is brutal. If you aren't trying to min/max you gear score, you probably wont feel compelled to buy anything in the cash shop. The new Zone, and update bring a lot to new and returning players. 

Still take a lot of time to learn all the various mechanics, however the new quests help teach you quite a bit. Game can be overwhelming, but if you take one ting to focus on at a time it can be alot of fun. 

In its current state, I highly recommend.

Pro:  Combat and character creation in this game is top notch, probably some of the best I've seen. 

Developer seems to working to make game better, with some good freebees lately, and  adding new content and some new armor pieces.


Cons:  It"s a game that requires many hours to achieve success.  The armors and weapons are still somewhat limited and the upgrade system is still one of the worst if not the worst in gaming.  The RNG rates in this game are definitely not favorable to the player. Be prepared for all you hard work of gathering and grinding upgrade materiel quickly goes up in smoke at the push of one button.  I would equate the RNG system to gambling because everything is basically a random chance.  You will not be able to achieve much until you get a high gear score, which will take forever.  While I like the game, I find that I must step away at times to maintain that like.

I would recommend it to a new player looking for a MMO to play if you are into grinding and have the time to put into it. Be prepared to be frustrated and piss off. One or two hours a week in this game will put you far behind others.

From the moment I stepped into its huge open world, I was captivated by the level of details. The game has an incredibly realistic and seamless environment that truly feels alive.

But, I am writing the most realistic review. If you have 2-3 hours of free time per day, you will start progressing to higher levels in around 2000-3000 hours.

Otherwise its waste of time.

Some Pros:
- The character design is the very best of any game I have played.  Beautiful characters.
- so many options for customization
- exquisite wardrobe design.  
- fun combat, with interesting class skills.  good use of combos.

Some Cons:
- there are some issues with collision detection: getting stuck on terrain, getting hit by area effects when I am well outside the visual effects
- some animations will lock you for a couple seconds
- frequent late rendering of 3D assets so that the game feels like it cant keep up with rendering
- some quests can be frustrating with incorrect markers or unclear instructions

If you do enjoy questing in general, this game has thousands of quests.  If you can play in a guild or with friends, it is more fun.  If you like role plaing with others - there are a ton of RPers.

I keep returning to the game for short sessions to collect daily rewards, chat with folks, and maybe do a handful of quests.

Yes.

Probably one of my favourite games of all time, if you need a big ass timesink and like to grind MOSTLY without the need of ppl around. WELL THEN YOU HAVE A REASON TO START ATLEAST.

I like the way you just go out, run your circles, make money by killing mobs all over again. Its a simple life. No need for partyfinders and shit. You wake up 3am, noone online? Doesnt matter, matter in fact even good for you as the grindingspots are less busy. Also the combat system is the most fluid of any MMO out there, even beating a lot of singleplayers, so yea thats probably one of BDOs biggest selling points.

Issue being the way the game is currently patched and new content released, is that most of the content has either a hard or softcap regarding your gear. Meaning that you grind your soul out of your body to not have noticeably benefits in most content, which is in my humble opinion pretty stupid in a korean grinder game. This results into the issue that you have almost no content for which you WOULD NEED the best gear in the game, making it meaningless to grind for unless you just wanna flex to the gearlets in Battlearena.

So when we just started about Battlearena, PvP, my most favourite part about the game. Beginning in year 2022, we had a big balance patch, which would make most classes pretty good in terms of PvE, making it fairly balanced to play whatever you like, without griefing your own time. BUT on the otherside overloading most of the classes with pure damage resulting in the PvP being a fiesta not compareable to anytime before. Its been like 1 1/2years by now and the Devs do little to nothing to bring PvP back in shape. 

So I am basically ending up in a grind game, in which PvE doesnt make sense after a certain point due to caps and PvP doesnt make any fun to play due to overloaded classes. I cannot recommend the game in its current state, unless you just need a big ass timesink to spend time minmaxing your gear with having in mind to not being able to use it in most scenarios.

I cannot believe I am playing and enjoying an MMORPG in 2023. After years of being totally repelled by anything remotely resembling the genre, I've logged almost 80 hours here and have been having a fantastic time.

The two things that set Black Desert apart from the rest of the (imo) generic trash out there are:

- (Actual) realtime action combat (this is not FFXIV!), which feels responsive, flexible, and impactful (unlike every other MMO), and...

- Lifeskills, which are what really keep me playing. You can buy property, hire workers, chop down some trees, build a boat, sail the MASSIVE ocean, catch rare fish (or go diving!), fry them up (in a bunch of different ways!), and sell them on the market. All of these steps are supported by numerous interwoven systems that you are free to engage with, selectively exploit, or ignore entirely, depending on what you want to do.

If you've ever played an MMO and thought "what if the fishing minigame was a fishing MEGAgame?", this is where you belong.

I think I've spent more time gathering, cooking, farming, and messing around with economic systems than I have fighting things, and to be clear, I LOVE fighting things in this game (Maehwa and Corsair main, here). I just can't wait to sail more, upgrade my ship, and really get out there. There is so much to see and do!

And what a pleasure it is to SEE - the game is gorgeous. It is a joy to travel around and see the world, with all the different locations, enemies, armor and weapon designs, pets... Of special note is the ocean, with its sparkling waters and ebbing waves. Good stuff.

There are, of course, some negatives.

- UPDATE: There is now a fast travel system. I am conflicted, as I actually enjoyed my quiet travel time between cities. Now that I am able to just summon goods/items from wherever (though there are limits!), travel is far less of a thing, depending on your chosen activities.

- This is the elephant in the room: there is a cash shop, and while it's not P2W, there are certain things that you'd wish the game just... gave you (being able to call your horse from anywhere is one of them), rather than charging you for them. It's not a deal breaker for me, especially considering there is no subscription fee, and the base price is low, but it is very much present.

- Armor/weapon enhancement is done through a roulette system - some people will HATE this, but it hasn't impacted me negatively (yet) as there are clever ways around/through it. I also don't mind a gamble. YMMV.

- Dyes, on the other hand, suffer from an objectively terrible roulette system with no real alternative - buy the palette pack, engage with a pointless roulette and hope you get the right color/style, or... get used to default colors, I guess. This BADLY needs a rework.

- Sadly, you (currently) cannot dye ships, though you can dye wagons and mounts, along with pretty much everything else. I really, really hope the devs do more with ships in the future (likely?), and hopefully fix the dye system (unlikely).

- There are some economic balance issues related to harvesting and lifeskills in general. Certain prices and how profit scales likely needs to be adjusted/buffed. If you NEED to be the best and make the most money possible, and you want to do so solely via lifeskilling, this may annoy you. I simply don't care too much.

- Let me repair my Epheria Cog, or release an alternative. C'mon. I don't want a big, hulking vessel; let me enjoy my lil speedboat.

To summarize, if you're sick of garbage combat, unfulfilling lifeskills and economic systems, and P2W nonsense, Black Desert might be your jam.

EDIT: It has come to my attention that there are certain players who will criticize you for not doing things... optimally. I am not personally motivated by the "make number go up" brain worms, and am content to just cruise around and take in the sights while engaging in some crafting and management gameplay. It's fun. I enjoy it. I don't need the pressure. People will say I am playing the game "wrong", and that's okay. I am fine with that, and you should be, too. Have fun!
