BDO has a brilliant combat system that i honestly wish more MMORPGs would adopt. Far too many MMOs are just click your numpad over and over until the enemy is defeated. I adore the combo system and the flashy animations and effects of the classes in game. 
But what about the game itself, Rune?
 BDO is definitely more of a solo MMO than a "bring-all-your-friends-along-and-do-some-epic-raids" MMO. Which some people prefer, to each their own. However, i do wish Pearl Abyss would add more quests or raids or long dungeons that i can do with my friends. Me and my friends wanted a MMO that we can progress through together, getting cool gear and getting stronger with each other but sadly BDO is not like that. It is more of a grindy, dont-think-too-much style MMO (Its also very grindy in the later levels), despite the cool combat system, which is a bit of a shame. A lot of my time is spent just doing fetch quests and talking to NPCs rather than fighting big bosses and entering massive boss areas. But overall the game is fun and the game is enjoyable, i just hope there is more multiplayer additions to the game in the future. I do still recommend this game for its stunning visuals, amazing character creator and its fluid, smooth combat system. This game is always on sale for a cheap price and it is worth getting it.  Hopefully this review helped, and also made sense.

Black Desert is probably the most relevant MMO in 2023, and the only one that has lasted through the years for me, I have played them all. There is a ton of options to do in game that can take hundreds of hours to accomplish, so I find that aspect very rewarding. There is an element of "pay to win", so it helps to have $100 to invest in the game over time, but you do not "need" it. Black Desert can feel like a single player game in retrospect that the most interaction you have with others is dueling for grinding spots or selling through the Market Place. There are not really activities you do with others, other than talking in the group chat or World Bosses.

I personally have a ton of fun with the game, and like it to relax with "busy work" tasks of life skilling, which is things like Cooking, Alchemy, Farming, Fishing, Gathering, Sailing, etc. There are thousands of hours that take to master each to Guru level.

Now is the best time to join, as it is Summer Season. Create a season character, and play on a season server, and choose the Land of the Morning Light quest line for the best experience. You'll be grinding mobs at level 61+ in no time!

This is one of the games that I played the most. While having some negative aspects, the positive ones overcomes them. I will list some of pros and cons that this game has.

Pros:
- Always having content to do. From PVE to PVP to Life Skill to Bartering. There is always stuff to do, it all depends on what you enjoy.
- A lot of classes that each are different for your play style
- Events. This game has so many events that sometimes it feels a bit suspicious
- PVP. The PVP in this game it's pretty fun. (I am not going to get into this because it will be too much to write)
- PVE. You can play this game without the need to do PVP, and that it's a good thing for people that don't enjoy it.

Cons:
- Always having stuff to do.
- In game community. Some times reading the chat can give you a headache. But that doesn't mean that there are no good people there that you can have a normal conversation with.
- Sometimes you feel like you make no progress.
- Too much dialog sometimes for the quests. But that can also be a good thing.

If you're into MMORPG I can't recommend this enough. Full price or sale, the game is worth it.

Black Desert Online employs a manipulative strategy to boost player retention by requiring them to stay logged in and the game running at all times. This tactic aims to inflate concurrent user numbers and create the illusion of a thriving player base. However, the game goes even further by incorporating a troubling element of gambling addiction through its item enhancement system, exploiting players' psychological vulnerabilities and keeping them engaged through addictive cycles.

By compelling players to remain logged in, even during periods of inactivity, Black Desert Online prioritises quantity over quality. The emphasis on inflated user numbers and superficial engagement metrics comes at the expense of the game's immersive and interactive nature. Instead of providing meaningful gameplay experiences, the game relies on manipulative tactics to entice players into addictive behaviour.

The item enhancement system in Black Desert Online is particularly concerning. It employs chance-based mechanics that closely resemble gambling, enticing players to invest considerable time, resources, and real-world money in pursuit of better gear or progress in the game. The addictive rush of anticipation and the constant desire for improvement replace genuine gameplay experiences, perpetuating a cycle that preys on players' addictive tendencies.

Prospective players should carefully consider the ethical implications of engaging with Black Desert Online's deceptive design. While the game may present a vibrant community, the underlying mechanics exploit psychological vulnerabilities and promote gambling addiction. It is crucial to evaluate personal gaming preferences and values before deciding whether to participate in a game that employs such manipulative tactics.

First things first, why i am somewhat able to leave a meanigfull comment. 
1. I play since 2017, and have a decent amount of time invested ( 6000 hours ).
2. Speaking of invested, i started free2play and now i am at 7000$ spend, so i do know the cashshop very well.
3. I basically went through all ups and downs

First Chapter: Starting your Journey

Bdo has one, if not the best charakter creation in the Genre. Also it has now a ton of different classes and for the first playthrough it also doesn't really matter what class you pick. Just go with what you feel comfortable with. This is important if you want to have fun in the game, dont look at numbers, look at what you enjoy the most. Also take your time exploring, BDO has a great map to explore for you, dont rush and dont let anyone boost you. If you have friends who offer you to boost you so you can enjoy the "endgame", just decline, trust me, if you skip the "bonding" part, where you bond with the game and the enviroment, you will quit after a few hours.

Second Chapter: Deciding what Route to go

After you played the story and went through the the different Areas, maybe even reached lvl 60, its time for you to explore the different playstyles of BDO.
The First one would be grinding, where you will become a grinder to make your money. It basically consists of running around on the different grind spots in the game and kill mobs for hours on end. I personally also did that for about 5000 hours. Also this is the most common way to earn your money, as its the only reasonable way to inject money into the economy, as the mobs drop items you sell directly to NPC's. 

The Second playstyle would be Lifeskilling, here you make your money by everything else then grinding. For example by gathering meat or blood, these "raw" ingredients you then use for cooking or alchemy. These products can then be sold to the player market or later down the road a limited amount per reset to a npc. 

My advice would be to try both playstyles for a while before deciding, because once you decide you should solely focus on upgrading your gear in that field. Once you reached a certain point you CAN however start to build gear for the other playstyle. 

Third Chapter: Welcome to BDO / Cashshop

Congrats, now that you know what you want to do in the game its time for you to learn what to expect.
After the first 1000 hours you can nowadays expect to be done with the gear grind IF you decide to BUY all your gear instead of making it yourself. If you want to do it yourself, well then its an open end, you can invest 6000 hours like me and still dont have all the gear. This is also a good place to put the Cashshop. Yes there is pay2win in this game. You need a Value Pack ( basically a 15$ sub fee ) and there is the possibility to buy Cron Stones so that your gear doesnt downgrade when an enhancement failed, yes your gear can downgrade, thats the whole point of the gear system. BUT to fully maximize your account you need hundrets of thousands of dollars. So i wouldn't really say its that big of a problem. But be said there is a lot of convenient items you want to have, like maids so you dont have to leave your spot or a tent so you can repair outside of cities. If you want to truly enjoy BDO, expect to pay a few hundret bucks.

My advice, no matter how you want to play the game, be it safe or be it risky, see the game as a marathon instead of a sprint. Dont expect to be competetiv after 200 hours. You simply wont be. And thats where we come to the last Chapter.

Final Chapter: PvP

PvP is the one and only true endgame of BDO. Nowadays they capped some Nodes and Regions to fight for, so that even low gear players can "enjoy" the PvP aspect. But dont be fooled, you will most likely die all the time when you are new, veteran players just know the game and know the classes, so even if you have the same gear, they have the experience. Thats why i would reccommend to learn and master your class befor joining competetiv PvP.

Ah and there is also Forced open world pvp. Jup. You will die once a geared player wants your spot, get comfortable with it, thats how its always been, thats how it always will be. Thats the spirit of the Game.

I'd say that it looks complex as a newbie. One of the things that I disliked about this is that the chat window doesn't show up right off the bat. There's no way to interact with people until you hit level 10. Everything was so new that it had me lost and I kept wondering what to do or how to go about doing stuff. Thankfully, I had a few friends who taught me when I asked them questions. 

There's very little inventory space. I don't understand why I need to buy inventory space instead of just getting it normally. I got some boxes off twitch drops and I was worried if I would have enough inventory space to put it all in my bags? So I just left it in the mail alongside the daily stuff I get, in whatever void box storage it is. Instead of transferring it over. The game has so much stuff in it that just goes off the top of my head. With the mats and the reagents. Constant reminders in the bottom right. I guess, I'll figure it out eventually. 

Customization wise, I dislike how there's only fixed tattoos and there's nothing else possible. Wouldn't it be really cool if they let you add your own custom tattoos in it? Or let users add their own options?! Or just draw something.. Its got good customization but I feel like it could be a lot more than what it is. It feels limited for some reason, details wise. Because almost every face looks like its carved out of a mold. 

The ability to just go to the next quest guy automatically with a click is amazing. The skills and abilities are very fun to spam and use, its so much fun to beat monsters down! The graphics are fun, I love the world. The way that it looks. Although Tera's world is still my fav. this isn't bad at all. I suppose, overall I'd rate this as a 9/10 so far. The only thing other than everything that I listed is that; I dislike is that this game's mostly meant for pvp and there's no pve content like mythics and such. Additionally, no pure RP servers either and people can just hop servers like no tomorrow? But the new expansion seems to have some of that stuff with the tower monsters which I saw on yt. So I suppose, that's something. Its a pretty cool game overall and I'd definitely suggest people give it a shot. As long as you don't get bored of it, you will come to like it.

black desert

1) Well its P2W, but not as extreme as those in ios/android. There are a lot of cool cosmetics that need to be bought with $$$. It's pricing as well is very expensive, a costume costs about $20. 

2) Let's say you are rich. You can buy your way to reach PEN (max enchant) easily. But the nature of the game is grindy af. Like, no matter how much $$$ you pour in this game, the grind never stops. It also becomes sort of a chore. I have over 250 hours in my first account (non-steam version). 

3) The skill-ceiling for this game is very high. Your success in PVP does not only rely on the rarity and enchantments of your gears. You also need fast hands to do some combos. I used to beat PEN geared players using TRI gears.

4) The only thing that I hate in this game. Their mechanic for enhancing gears. Without fail stacks, it will be forever to upgrade a gear to PEN. This fail stacking method makes me puke from dizziness. This made me quit until I decided to come back now.

- I recommend this game. So far, this is the best open world mmo that I played. The game's nature (the grind) removes the gap between rich and broke players. Like, the game is really-really grindy even if you buy big-time. This is how MMOs are supposed to be played. Through grinding and not $$$.

Unending Adventure with a lot of stuff to do such as Life Skill, if you are a Jobless person who loves to play games like MMORPG, this is Perfect for you as you grind all the progress

depending on who you ask, you'll get very different opinions about this game...whether it be the p2w aspects, the gambling simulator of a gear enhancement system or the never ending grind

so yea, there is alot of "convenience" you can pay for...never mind the 3 separate subscriptions, one being 30 days and the other two being 15 days, all of which are necessary for their own reasons (to be fair, you do get a lot of them for free just by playing throughout events of which there is barely ever a time that one isn't running, or just through logging in)
oh also, almost every cash shop item can be sold on the market place...some people might complain about that, because people with high disposable income can just skip any kind of grind and print money...but that also means that us lowly peasants can buy those cash shop items without paying real money for them, all you need is a bit of time spent grinding and some patience while waiting for your order to fill, since the order queue is rng based on which order gets filled first

the gear enhancement system is rough and will ruin a lot of people's experience, so i would not recommend enhancing gear yourself, but instead grinding the silver to then just buy the items off of the market place to save your sanity (the only time you "have" to enhance by yourself is on a season character, but the rates there are much more forgiving and very managable)

oh the grind...yea...the grind is basically the "point" of the game
you grind silver so you can afford better gear to grind better spots to make more silver to get better gear and the cycle continues, so i suggest trying some trial characters to see what classes you like, since you will be spending a lot of time playing them
ofcourse you're not limited to one character that you're "stuck" with, the max amount of slots you can have is 30 iirc and there is alot of variety in how all the classes play, so try em all and see what fits your style

lifeskills are basically an entirely different game, but they are a very nice change of pace if you're tired of grinding, atleast in my opinion

i haven't touched pvp, so there's nothing i can really add in that regard

my final advice is save yourself the headache of trying to figure out all of the games systems by yourself, unless you're a masochist, because there are plenty of helpful resources online and even class specific discord servers, if you wanna get more specific
but huge shoutout to impansy, jonlaw, biceptimus and evildousharm on youtube, great content covering pretty much everything in video form
if you're more of a reader, i'll suggest garmoth and grumpy green as general sites and bdolytics if you wanna go more in depth on lifeskilling
but besides that, play how you want...don't let anyone tell you what you should be doing, how you should be doing it or what class does x better than yours
it's a game, not a job, so who cares about the "optimal" strats, do whatever you enjoy the most and what won't sour the experience for you/burn you out

tl;dr:
yes, p2w exists, but is also avoidable since "necessary" items are given out for free regularly or can be bought for farmable currency on the in-game marketplace
for the love of god, save your sanity and DO NOT enhance your own gear, save up the silver to buy it off the marketplace
this game is about grinding...if you came here for anything else, you're in the wrong place
trial characters are your friend, try a bunch and see which classes you like most
play at your own pace and do whatever you wanna do whether that be grinding, lifeskilling or arena/large scale pvp

oh and i've seen alot of reviews mentioning toxic chat experiences...i've had chat disabled almost right from the start, so yea, would recommend turning chat off (if your style of playing allows that ofcourse)

Personal favorite MMO right now.  Sometimes it feels like a game from 10 years in the past and sometimes like a game from 20 years in the future.  A huge, beautiful world that will take you years to even comprehend much less see all of or partake in every sort of walk of life available to characters in this world.  The combat is like nothing else I've played.  Sort of set up like a Dynasty Warriors type of game with the slaying of broad swaths of enemies, but with a complex farming/life simulation attached to it.

Heavy focus on slow burn solo grind up.  Not very much coordinated party PVE content.  The pay structure is very interesting.  No membership and you can totally game happily for free after paying the door charge and do most anything in the game.  I can't think of another title in here that will give you so many hours of enjoyment for your buck out of the gate.  Paying for stuff ends up being for two reasons: buying things you need to do the specific content you want to do most effectively and buying things to sell to other people for in game money (*cough* p2w....sorta).  The beauty is that you can spend in game money for most of the stuff you would want to pay for anyway.  So either way, paying just saves you time.

Black Desert Online is a game that's so shit, that it's only saving grace is its ability to basically play itself, so that I don't have to. 

It seems like every 5 seconds there's some awful cutscene, much of the early areas are populated by enemies that you can KO in a couple of hits for no exp, or enemies that you'll have to fight for several minutes on end, and not get enough exp to make up for the time you spent mauling them. These enemies will usually be within about 20 feet of each other, so you'll have no problem seeing what I mean. 

So the classes in this game... it's an MMORPG, and like most, it has classes. The classes can be cool, but they're gender locked. Want to be a brawler who summons clones and punches with fire? Too bad, you wanted to play as a woman, that means you're relegated to the less brutal but more water inclined punching class. Oh, you wanted to be a caster? I hope you like cc, because if you chose to play as a fem character, you don't get to be a big aoe burst class, you get to be a witch, who still does damage (though, less, and with a focus on cc), but for some reason there's a distinction between that and a wizard. 

Even when the game tries to include class counterparts for both sexes, you can't just play the same thing, and that's so wild lol. It takes more time, effort, and money to do that, than just working on rigging the animations to both sexes. There's no reason there can't be male pirates, there's no reason there can't be female sages. It's a counter-intuitive, archaic, unnecessary system that just makes you feel like the devs couldn't be bothered to make something and let people enjoy it. 

Speaking of gender locked classes, they're almost stereotypical, imo. All the m classes are these big, burly, fully clothed or geared characters, and all the f characters might as well be buck naked, chest exposed, with no pants or the tiniest miniskirt you've ever seen, always wearing stiletto heels, tons of exposed skin, gratuitous jiggle physics... you get the idea. I don't mind sexy outfits in games, and when there's the option, I certainly don't mind picking them up, sometimes... but when the game sets this expectation of you being, by default, super exposed eye candy who can't even just play the same classes as the m classes, it just feels really strange, and I'm not into it. 

I think it'd be really cool if both playable sexes could be whatever class tbh, not just f characters getting to be m classes, but m characters getting to be f classes. Just having that option would be cool. I'm a woman, and I like playing as women in games, too, but it just feels like this game sets up a really strange sort of stereotype right from the beginning, and if you don't believe me, check out the official class trailers on YouTube, you'll see the sort of thing I mean. 

As far as the rest of the game goes... there's a mandatory tutorial in the beginning that feels 1000x times longer than it actually is because it could have just been a skippable cutscene, but instead opted to be a series of poorly written, short, cutscenes with forced gameplay segments between them to try to make you pay attention to the shitty cutscenes. Once you get into the world, there's gonna be even more. If you don't enjoy the dialogue, get ready, there will be lots more. 

At least after the tutorial, some of it is able to be skipped.

Fun fact about the tutorial, btw, I literally couldn't alt f4 to close it. The developers are so hellbent on making you watch their cutscenes, that even using alt f4 to close the game will prompt a little message in the upper right hand corner of the screen, reminding you that you cannot skip cutscenes, even when you aren't watching one lol.

Speaking of dialogue, the game will ask what language you want characters to speak, but apparently the only dialogue setting that actually sticks is the subtitles, so at least the game is playable, but it would honestly be better if it wasn't lmao, it just sucks.

Thankfully, there's a keybind that's active by default (at least on keyboard) that just lets your character automatically move around and go from quest obj to quest obj, and lets you ignore the part where you actually have to figure out where you're going... not that it's overly difficult, but the more you play, the more you just go 'please, take the wheel, get me out of here, I'd rather play something else.' 

The game's UI is also pretty overwhelming, with ads coming up, lots of buttons, too many menus, and the menus themselves being overly cluttered, disorganized, and frankly, the only part of the game that actually feels like it should have had a tutorial. Ironically, it seems to be the only part of the game, as far as I can tell, that doesn't have one. 

The size of this game's world is pretty astounding. It's pretty big tbh, but there's nothing to do there. The big appeal of this game, as far as I can tell, is that it's designed to be like older MMOs, where there's big, open, areas... filled with enemies to farm kills from, but that's about it. There's really not much in the way of content diversity. You do the story, or you kill stuff in the open world. For how huge the world is, and how much of an emphasis the game's developers clearly put on combat, you would think that there'd be more types of content, but... nope, that's about it. You're either dealing with the story, or this. The game's big, and it's pretty, but there's nothing to really do unless you like this sort of thing (which I do, but I don't think it hurts to have some variety). In that sense, it's not unlike Guild Wars 2, but even GW2 has stuff going on in the world. 

For my fellow FFXIV players, it's basically meant to be going for the same style of gameplay/game that Eureka was going for, in Stormblood.

Small complaint on the character creation front, too, and this doesn't affect the rest of the game at all... but, for some reason, you can manually select a custom color for your hair, but not for your eyes. Like, you can get any color you want for your hair, but your eyes are given the choice between seemingly supernatural neon, pale brown, or dark blues/black. Really odd that you can't just pick more natural looking colors for your eyes, but your hair can be pretty much any absurd color that you probably won't end up choosing. 

Another nitpick would be that you don't have any in-game options for reporting toxicity or chat spamming. For some reason, a persistently online, social, experience doesn't really give you the ability to let a moderation team know when people are just being huge assholes in the chat. 

Overall, the game's pretty, but it's absolute shit imo. The level layouts in my experience so far have been pretty awful, enemies are either too easy or too difficult, while not rewarding enough exp for fighting pretty much anything beyond level 8 or 9, it seems like the devs really want to objectify and stereotype based on gender, so there's that, too, I guess? Not really a game I would recommend, and I honestly can't wait to uninstall it after I post this review. I just wish I could get my money back lol.

I would like to edit this review to add in, after the fact, that this game has no fast travel system. If you want to go anywhere that isn't right where your character is, you have to either manually walk there, or automate some kind of path and auto walk while you get up and do something else. 

Just to give an example of how big this game's world is, and what it's like to have no fast travel system of any kind, I decided to use the auto walk feature to get from one starting area to the next. This meant no combat, no stopping, no getting sidetracked, just going until I got to my destination. To get from one starting area to the next, it took about 30 minutes without any stopping, getting lost, drawing aggro and fighting, etc.

You would honestly just be better off not playing this game. You'd be doing yourself, and your wallet, both a favor

Alright, folks, let's talk about Black Desert Online, the MMO that has been sucking away my life for the past few weeks. First things first, this game is an absolute blast! The world of Black Desert Online is like a breathtaking painting come to life. Seriously, the graphics are drool-worthy. Whether you're exploring the dense forests or trudging through the scorching deserts, the attention to detail is mind-blowing. And don't even get me started on the character customization! I swear, I spent more time designing my virtual alter ego than I did on my last haircut.

Now, let's talk about the combat. Oh boy, it's a wild ride! This ain't your typical point-and-click MMO combat, my friends. No sir, Black Desert Online offers a fast-paced and action-packed system that gets your heart pumping. You'll be dodging, slashing, and casting spells with such fluidity that it feels like you're in an epic martial arts movie. The combos you can pull off are straight-up satisfying, and decimating mobs of enemies never gets old.

But hey, let's not forget about the grind. Yes, the dreaded grind. Black Desert Online has a reputation for being a bit of a grindfest, and I can't deny it. If you're looking for instant gratification, this might not be your cup of tea. Leveling up and getting better gear requires some serious dedication and a truckload of patience. You'll find yourself running the same quests and killing the same monsters over and over again. It can feel like a never-ending loop at times, and it's not everyone's cup of tea.

Speaking of loops, let's talk about the learning curve. Brace yourself, my fellow newcomers, because Black Desert Online doesn't hold your hand. Nope, it throws you into the deep end of the pool and expects you to swim. The lack of proper tutorials and guidance can be frustrating, especially for MMO rookies like myself. Figuring out the intricate systems and mechanics can feel like deciphering hieroglyphics. I had to consult online guides and watch countless YouTube tutorials just to grasp the basics. It's a steep learning curve, my friends, so be prepared.

Despite these bumps in the road, Black Desert Online is a game I can't seem to put down. The breathtaking world, the exhilarating combat, and the endless possibilities keep me coming back for more. Yes, it has its flaws, and the grind can feel like a chore. But if you're willing to dive headfirst into an immersive and visually stunning MMO adventure, Black Desert Online will sweep you off your feet and take you on a wild ride. Just remember to pack some patience and a healthy dose of curiosity, and you'll be in for a thrilling journey.

Where to start....Black Desert Online is a very interesting concept. Its enjoyable for both hardcore and committed players as well as casual and laid-back players. With options for pvp, pve, and lifeskilling, BDO offers many different options of play for everyone. The customization in the game is phenomenal, probably the best in any mmo I've played both new and old, with sliders for every choice and full customization for characters/classes. You'll never not have something to do. However, with all the good things in the game come not-so-good things. The grind to be relevant for pvp and guild wars is never-ending. Enhancing and drops/loot are completely rng based, with enhancing having low percentage success around 1% - 5% for the gear that makes you relevant with the breaking or degrading of certain equipment making the grind never-ending and expensive. For those interested in an engaging and interesting story, BDO has changed and retconned many things over the years overall making the story deeper and more interesting, however not better than its other mmo counterparts. The story quests are irrelevant to the overall gameplay and can easily be speedran and rushed to level characters.
Pros:
- Amazing customization 
- Many different class options with more coming each year
- Fun and diverse pvp and pve
- Diverse life skills and afk life skilling
- Beautiful environment/scenery as well as ability effects 
- Seasonal events, outfits, and areas
- Fun to use classes and abilities 
- Never-ending grind
- Decent Story
Cons:
-Pvp is locked by level which is easy to get however gear is important and it takes thousands of hours or insane luck to even get 1 piece of gear that would be considered decent for pvp.
- Everything is rng based from drops to enhancing
- Getting to lvl 60 is easy but everything after that take hours upon hours of endless grinding
- Not quite pay to win but very much pay for quality of life
- A lot of spots are highly contested by very high geared players and there isnt much option other than server swapping to be able to defeat mobs without threat of pvp
- Pvp is active everywhere aside from cities so once you are of level to pvp you either have to server swap or wait for people to leave.
-Once you get to a certain level and gear score you are limited on places to farm exp and money and will be there for hundreds or thousands of hours in hopes of a singular good drop.
- High chance of being caught in a cycle of grind, buy item, enhance item, break item while enhancing, lose mind, then repeat.
I have 11k hours in the game and have played periodically over the past 4 years and the game is more of a grind than any other mmo I have played. It's very easy to get burnt out once you finish main quests and have only gear score and level to worry about. However, the game looks great and can be fun when you get past the tryhard grind of it. If you decide to play it, good luck and Godspeed my friend. <3

The graphics and the combat are fantastic. I haven't found another mmo that feels better than this in the almost ten years since it came out. [h1]TLDR - Conclusion[/h1]
BDO Is a game you can pickup after leaving for a few months and get back into with the benefit of being gifted something for coming back and the additional benefit of picking up what you haven’t collected from the last time you logged in. If you want a well-paced MMORPG I whole heartedly encourage you to play this game. You won’t be disappointed if you like a bit of everything and don’t like being forced into a specific style of game play. You can play casually or competitively make friends and enemies become trader to the stars or just gain fame by posting selfies in the gallery. BDO is for want of a better word Awesome!
I can't give much more of an in depth review as the whole game is just too big and you need more space to give a justified review explaining everything. Best thing about the game is no loading times when travelling around the map. 

[h1]Characters[/h1]

There are a number of classes, some which are female only so at some point in the future we expect to eventually get their male counterpart which appears to be the MO of this game. You have a number of free character slots to begin with and with a little patience you can expand that to the maximum number of characters you have access to. Instead of youtubing what the most powerful class, I would recommend picking one you like the look of and working on levelling this. 
Some classes are easier to fight with than others as they have bind-able special skills which can be linked to create devastating attacks PVP or PVE.
The character creation tool of this game is about as good as the Sims one if not better. With the new graphical render engine the level of realism to the overall look of the characters is less plastic and more in line with the fantasy style. The attention to detail is pretty standard now but when this game originally dropped it was unprecedented. 

[h1]Anti Cheat[/h1]
This is a controversial part of the game and will be the deciding factor for most players as the service which is installed can be likened to a rootkit which will monitor your activities whilst the game is running so I’d advise not to log into any websites you wouldn’t mind any complete stranger logging into on your behalf because it’s NOT CRYSTAL CLEAR to what extent this anti cheat software is capable of but it will kill known tasks of software which can be used to inspect processes used for monitoring memory (which is the primary use of any cheat software but does not discriminate so you can’t run Microsoft process monitor (procmon)).
I don’t run Windows under an admin account and would never recommend any one else does or disable UAC for that matter. BDO insists that I do every time I run it to be able to use this anti cheat (which I don’t let it) You can quite simply run the black desert launcher with compatibility mode run as invoker enabled which will allow the game to run under the current account. This will limit the capabilities of the software.

[h1]Community[/h1]
I like this game a lot, ultimately the community makes the game live or die. There is a huge following but you can’t count the following on one set of servers alone. The servers are split between Console, Steam and non Steam versions of the same game so you won’t get an idea unless you tally up everything.  I’m not an ambassador to the game at all but I read and follow the general community and in some countries the BDO ethos is not nice or the local game chat has been likened to shear filth. I’m hoping that the new blood acquired from console players will bring a new lease of life to the game.

[h1]Servers[/h1]
In all the time I’ve played this game I’ve only once been unable to enter the game and the fix was to restart the computer to pick up a steam update. The game triumphs above any other MMORPG in that you only wait to load if you are jumping around the map from city to city. This has kind of been fixed now by the addition of the Magnus Questline. The Magnus allows fast travel between all the relams and you just need to jump into a well :)

Not including the Sea which can be navigated for free by hopping on board a trade ship bound for the other side of the map (~15 Mins travel time IRL) if you haven’t crafted your own boat and been sunk mid way through your voyage. So you never see a loading screen unless you are entering a dungeon or a PVP battle event.

[h1]Media/GFX[/h1]
The game has gone through a few enhancements over the years it’s been out for English speakers. The last one being the music which was remastered with a full orchestra soundtrack and these where brand new tracks not just re-hashed old ones which to be honest sounded like orchestral tracks to begin with. The graphics renderer had an overhaul too which added a new level of realism in the form of a physical based renderer. Don’t be put off by this game assuming it requires a beast of a machine as it is designed to run on just about any Windows machine which is no mean feat. In the time I’ve been playing there have been four additional characters released and four new areas (one under water) which still don’t open the whole map up from its fog of war look. 

[h1]Money[/h1] (not real)
The central market economy in BDO fluctuates like the wind depending on events which are running all the time. The market has been overhauled over the last year or so to rate control your purchasing. You will find acquiring wealth in the game quite simple once you master trade nodes and workers. You can quest which is good for levelling your current class and learning about the world you are playing in. You’ll learn how to level up your gear, which you won’t be able to do without the knowledge so you will need to quest. Some gear can be acquired through quests and levelled up through quests to the max. 

[h1]Gear and levelling [/h1]
You have three weapon traits, Primary offensive. Secondary Offensive/Defensive and the last weapon is for your Awakening skill which you have a quest path for at level 56. Some classes have a personal mount. Some have a support spirit (of sorts). Accessories like rings and necklaces can either be quested for or enhanced through world NPCs then there is armour which will buff different attacking aspects depending on the variants of armour you chose.
Levelling gear is done with similar items of gear or through the use of black stones. Different black stone varieties can be acquired through gathering, questing, PVE or purchased from the central market. Using your processing skills will allow you to craft lower grade black stones into higher grade Black stones for the enhancement of higher grade equipment or armour. It’s quicker to get the silver and buy the stones specifically for your enhancement runs.
Enhancements can be set to guarantee the enhancement of the equipment but at the cost of reducing the durability of said equipment (usually from %100 to %0 at higher grades). For accessories this is dangerous as you can quite easily lose a high levelled accessory to a failed enhancement. For accessories you can use cron stones which will not allow the accessory to be destroyed after a failed enhancement. For weapons and armour you will just lose durability and then need to either buy the same weapon or armour piece for a blacksmith/repair NPC to then recover the durability. 
Recently Stable owners have been given the ability to Repair equipment which is more for convenience as you would find yourself a long way between a central market NPC or blacksmith NPC.
Enhancements can be gambled on with the enhancement level you gain from a failed enhancement. There are so many youtube videos which explain the enhancement process. If that wasn’t enough equipment has three grades on top of the enhancement process, Green, Blue and Yellow (Yellow being the strongest grade).

Positives
+ Good graphics (for an MMO)
+ Excellent third-person action combat (for an MMO)
+ Wonderful variety of classes with distinct abilities and identities
+ Unparalleled and heavily detailed character creation system
+ UI customisation
+ Beginner worlds for first-timers (minimal PvP interference)

In-Betweens
+/- PvPvE (player vs. player vs. enemy NPCs)
+/- Open-world map design
+/- Open PvP (outside beginner servers)

Negatives
- Gender-locked classes (every class is either exclusively male or female)
- Forgettable storylines
- Story pacing is often ruined by progression barriers
- Extremely time-consuming and grindy progression (AFK-leveling will become necessary)
- In-game microtransactions for progression timesaving (pay more for an easier leveling experience)
- Female character outfits double as fanservice fetishwear
- Lack of in-built social activities
- Latency issues
- Optimisation for competitive PvP will require you to revert to potato graphics

I have 8360 Hours in total, 6178 hours on the retired launcher and 2182 hours on the new launcher as of writing this review.

At first this game was great, ahead of its time compared to other popular MMOs on release, visually stunning and really made you feel immersed in the environment it provided. However, now its just a former husk of what it once was, vomiting out poorly made content in hopes of keeping its current player based entertained long enough for them to shove a shiny new cash shop item in your face for you to buy to "enhance" your experience.

I'll break this game down into each of its sub sections and my thoughts and experiences on it so far:

Combat: The holy grail and only reason its worth playing, but if you're just here for PVE then its boils down to a hack and slash item farming simulator with disappointing, laggy and underwhelming boss fights. The best description I can give it is "It sounds way cooler than it really is." If you're here for PVP, well then you're in for a treat, but only if you're willing to lower your graphics down to RuneScape levels of quality so that your FPS is high enough to register your damage and keep track of the 50 players on screen throwing flashy AOEs around (If you're brave enough to leave Player affects on). In 1v1 encounters it feels and plays like a fighting game, think Naruto Shippuden meets Streetfighter, assuming you're at the same Gear Score and Skill level as your opponent, else its just you trying to avoid an invulnerable Panzer tank firing nuclear missiles at you while it de-syncs towards you at the speed of light.

Story: Its horrid. So much so that I've lost count of how many times they've changed it to try to make it interesting. In the newer story content it feels like they're trying to do more than the game engine will allow and some interactions just feel off. The English Dub is awful and feels like you're watching a bad Kungfu movie from the 90s. Because someone at Pearl Abyss thought it would be a good idea to give ASIAN CHARACTERS FULL ON SOUTHERN AMERICAN ACCENTS FOR SOME STUPID REASON. Its not memorable at all and you'll most likely be skipping your way through it to get to the "mid to late game".

Progression: This right here is most likely going to be the reason you'll quit the game entirely. Be it Combat or LifeSkills, either way its slow, so slow that having something on the side to keep you from falling asleep while grinding is mandatory at this point. So I hope you still have a netflix sub and a series on your watch list to keep your brain functioning while you run around the same rotations for 1-6 hours over and over again, day after day. Sure the game does give new players a headstart with the season servers and basically free accessories, capotias, T8 horses and MULTIPLE BATTLE PASSES (yes this is a thing because money), but really it only gets your gear score high enough to START the ENTRY LEVEL end game grinds. Expect to be farming for 3-6 months (depending on your RNG and drop rates) before you can even consider taking on vet players. And don't even get me started on Upgrading Gear. Its like gambling, sitting at a slot machine hoping you can succeed with that >5% chance for enhancement, but if you're willing to spend real money on pearl shop costumes to convert them to cron stones you can just slam your face on the enhance button without having to worry about YOUR GEAR DOWNGRADING WHEN IT FAILS. This is one of the many "Pay to Win" features of this game and anyone who says this game isn't pay to win is smoking unnecessary amounts of copium.

Cash Shop: I'm not going to lie here, the costumes are dope. But EVERYTHING in the cash shop is overpriced. To a point were you could realistically find yourself wondering if you should really be buying this costume or instead spend the same amount on one of the new AAA games that got released. Its predatory. And there are so many "pay for convenience" items that are so beneficial that the game feels like you're at a disadvantage without them. They created problems and are selling the solutions. Ofc you could go full Free to Play but expect your progression to take longer than someone with an unfathomable amount of credit card debt.

Gameplay: In order to do anything the "correct" way without missing something, you'll need a guide. A guide for levelling, a guide for gear depending on which class you choose, a guide for crystal sets, a guide for best farming rotations, a guide for worker empire setups, a guide for QUESTING, a guide for crafting, a guide for cooking, a guide for pvp match-ups, a guide for log books, a guide for navigating through the desert...the list goes on and on. I've taken so many people through the new player experience and it feels like explaining an encyclopedia to a preschooler. And I know it might sound appealing to dumbasses who like to gatekeep games and topics that require textbooks to understand, but its just exhausting. Its a constant back and forth of "How do I do this" and "Where do I find that". 

Community: Drama, harassment, hate, crybabies, racists, sexism, discrimination, false accusations and any other "isms" you'd experience from a typical bronze league of legends match. PVP means conflict. And because its a "PVP game" tech support will refuse to help you because "they can't interfere with pvp related issues". Even if someone is constantly harassing you or making racist remarks they wont do anything about it. Its "part of the game". I've seen so many degenerates saying things that would put them on a watchlist if they said it in public. So brace for degeneracy. Not to mention the game is region locked so 90% of the time you're going to be interacting with someone who can't speak English and is using google translate to swear at you because you stole their rotation.

This game isn't a game. Its a job. If you're looking for something casual you're in the wrong place. And fully expect to have to replace your GPU or entire Gaming laptop at some point from having to leave this game running overnight for some activities. 

It's not worth it.

There are a lot of rumours and circulation about this game being pay to win.

I would like to say that since 2017 I have about 500 hours total into the game (The game moved to steam at some point) and I only payed the base price which was around 10$ at the time. I have never spent any extra money in this game.

Story is really bad, but without spending any money you can easily make gear that will get you all around the world and experience combat which is really fun.

If that gets boring, life skills are cool, You can buy and customise houses and ships to sail the sea.

The combat really sets this game apart as it is by far the best in any MMO game I have ever played. Truly exciting and gets better the more you understand it.

If the game gets pay to win later on, I don't care I have had a lot of fun and will continue to do so for a few more hours, so for the base price? Totally worth it.

Sure you can level characters individually but you won't get anything new out of it, like achievements or titles. Your mounts, pets, titles are all shared across characters. Way too expensive to be "competitive" in any regard.  Waiting to get pets just to loot mobs would take you a couple years at best, if you want anything close to even a couple t3 pets.  Camp site buffs are required to be competitive with buffs, which is a good chunk of change even on sale.  Cosmetics are way too expensive and have the added effect of being able to consume them to risk an attempt at upgrading gear lol.  And the base costumes provided are pretty terrible, lackluster, and lack variety.  So if you want to look good be ready to spend again.  The inventory system is a mess.  Keeping up with quest items, enhancement items, and crafting items is near aneurysm inducing.   

All of this holds back a pretty mediocre but passable MMO, story-wise, but gameplay and graphics are pretty great.  Best looking MMO imo.

The game has changed a lot, though im unsure how I feel about it in its current state. Since it was bought by the developer i noticed a shift in prices and rewards. a specific example; we were given a scroll (about 4 months back) that said you could send Exp and Combat Exp to another character... it never had on the scroll that it would [b]SWAPPED[/b] exp. I used the scroll and bricked my character(not sure how many others did so) when i asked for a reversal (i didn't even want the scroll back i just wanted the characters swapped back) i was told to kick rocks and wait for it come out on the shop (fair I technically fucked up).... which it is at a whooping 100 USD

considering how long I've played you could imagine why i wouldn't want to play anymore have getting told "F" you by the game 3 times... the game feels predatory for transactions now...sure i have alts, and they are all 60+ but i can't help but feel cheated, i mean why give a scroll that Exchanges exp? just seems dumb in practice, especially when everything else functions on combining instead of swapping (they sell life scrolls that allow you to send from one character to another)

I feel like a lot has just become cash grabs, for a dying mmo. Spare yourselves


Greetings Developer,
 
While you maintain your statement, as we discussed VIA email before, i maintain my statement. The scroll in question did not list that it "swapped" exp, merely that moved exp from one character to the next or "transferred Combat EXP from current character to target character". Even if it was an error on my part I asked to be able to purchase or just have another scroll to swap my character's back. Instead of maybe seeing my mistake or potentially yours i was told id have to wait and that i was now stuck that way. I do not see the point in you re-iterating this message, i had already mentioned that i had reached out to the help line and how unsatisfactory it was. this isn't a plea for something this is a warning to others.

Kind regards.

That response aside, there has been progress in the game since the dev's have bought it. there's been some great changes but its still pretty cash shop intensive. So read carefully when you use items you get for free and enjoy. on an interesting note i noticed they changed how the scrolls are named since i played... wonder what caused that.

TL;DR Best MMORPG imo.
-----
Note: I also own the old version with it's own client and have around 1000h there.
-----
[list]
[*]No it is not pay to win. [spoiler]You could spend 1000 euros to get 1 piece of BIS but noone is doing it. Do not make it pay to win.[/spoiler]
[*]Yes it takes a lot of time.
[*]No you do not need monster of a PC to run it.
[*]OFC the game is most beautiful if you do have monster of a PC.
[*]Yes fighting is A LOT OF FUN if you are into street fighters.
[*]Yes fighting will be hella hard if you try to play it like classic mmorpg.
[*]Yes tiddies do shake.
[*]No you can't max size depends on class :(
[*]Yes same thing with booty :"C
[*]Yes there are extra [b]t h i c c[/b] classes. 
     [spoiler]If i remember it right: [b]Sorceress[/b], Ranger, Kunoichi, [strike]Guardian[/strike].[/spoiler]
[*]No you do not need to do storyline [spoiler]but you should at least once.[/spoiler]
[*]Yes you can go fishing instead.
[*]No you do not get a lot of exp from quests.
[*]Yes grinding is the best for exp [spoiler]and usually for money too.[/spoiler]
[*]No UI is not confusing.
[*]Yes you can turn most of the UI elements on and off. 
[*]No the game does not lack the mmo part.
[*]Yes you are sitting on part of the server only accessible to noobs.
[*]Yes the game is RNG based :( [spoiler]and so is your chance to lose virginity :)[/spoiler]
[*]Yes you get % chance to drop weapon % chance to upgrade that weapon and % chance to burn that weapon...
[*]Yes you can repair it even at 0 durability.
[*]Yes you can buy it upgraded at marketplace.
[*]Yes the map is huge.
[*]Yes? there are teleports? [spoiler]Haven't tried it yet. I've Arduanatt.[/spoiler]
[*]Yes there is open PVP.
[*]Yes you can avoid it if you want. [spoiler]Just swap server channel or bring friends [strike]pussy[/strike].[/spoiler]
[*]Yes you do get a lot of payed items (pets, outfits, ...) for free from event and daily login.
[*]Yes there is a lot of events (at least 1 is always active).
[/list]
-----
Side notes: 
If you are complaining about grinding to get 1 item or money how is it any different from doing 1 dungeon for hours to get 1 item? cough cough [strike]WOW[/strike] cough. Maybe this type of game is just not for you? I find it relaxing to just grind for few hours with occasional challenger to take my spot or ppl asking to go grind with them on harder spot.

(Also i have said it above that you need a lot of time do do anything but it doesn't mean you have to play 12h a day as ppl are saying in other reviews. With gear you get easily and for free at season you can get around 300kk-500kk money in 3h-4h grind. Are you so impatient that you want to be given BIS after playing 5h in mmorpg? Better go play minecraft and just spawn yourself some diamonds.)

As for toxic community ofc there is a toxic part of the community and there is the not so toxic part as in any other online game. If you are complaining about that have you ever played any other online game? CS? LOL? 
(Well if you did run into only toxic ppl and griefers that's just unlucky. I personally consider myself part of the not toxic community and i always try to help others. MMOs are better together.)

Also i have no idea what are ppl talking about having issues with language settings i have never had any problem with that and i recommended this game to 5 friend and as far as i know non had such issues smh. I do get very rarely some setting changed after patch but it's mostly things like fullscreen going windowed.

I enjoyed playing it and I have a few opinions, as a player who haven't spend a dime in the game.

Pros: 
PC optimization is fine for my end. (Things looks a lot prettier on ultra settings but it's too heavy for my pc ;v;) 
Graphic is not too bad.
The stories and missions are fine. 
Combat system not too bad. 
I also happen to like the freedom in character customization. 
It has some depth on managing a lot of things like skills, horses, trading, workers, raw materials production and etc.

Cons:
I feels like the enhancement for equipment is the only most important thing that needs to be grind and it's not easy. 
It can be frustrating sometimes.

Conclusion:
I am not sure about if you can actually top up some money to get "pre-made" enhanced equipment on the market, if it's available. If you can do that, that might actually be the only part that considered Pay-to-Win element. Overall, It's okay to play as a normal rpg game and also play it with your friends, without spending a dime like me.

While I normally don't leave comments on games I feel the need to do so here. This game is amazing and fun and will pull you right in. However, it takes a lot of time to really get results and there are a lot of in game purchases that help things go along. I played this game in November 2020 with over 850 hours at the time. I spent upwards of $500 dollars and had numerous characters, billions of dollars, a large collection of items, armor, gear, etc. I'd devoted heavily to the game despite not having much money IRL. I recently returned to this game and found I'd lost all of my account stuff as they had changed companies and deleted everything. I reported this to the customer service requesting some compensation for the loss as I'd been in the process of moving at the time of the transfer and was unaware of losing my account. The customer service basically informed me they wouldn't do anything to help and it was tough luck. I was extremely upset as they could have done something to assist me in restarting. Aside from this incident, the game itself is very fun with constant updates and an active GM staff. I would highly recommend this to anyone interested in fast paced combination combat and in-depth life skills. I'd also like to note there is a sequel coming out soon.

It does have it's quirks but I enjoy playing it with my family. My husband (49) and both my sons (21 & 23) play it with me (44). There is something for both types of players. If you aren't a spending person, there is still stuff to do without paying cash. 

For the others that can buy things and spend on the game there is a ton of stuff to make your playtime better! When you buy things, it's easy to understand even for the less tech savvy people. 

The game has so many places to get answers to your questions regarding quests and things that are game related that makes it more enjoyable as well. 

The general chat is less desirable some hours but gets better as you play. If you don't want to read it you just pop another chat up and you don't see it. 

Customizing your character is out of this world in depth. I was astonished and amazed at how many things you have control over as far as your characters looks. If you don't know what you want, there is something for that too. There's a whole database of previously done character looks to choose from for each type. 

There is a ton of content for every level and play style. If you want to craft you can. If you want to fight things you can. If you want to tame horses you can. If you like farming stuff there's that too. There's something for everyone and every mood. You can also get and decorate your houses. You can have a house in every city. It's neat. 

It was well thought out. If you can get past the quirks of the game, it's fun and something I see my family playing for years to come.

Title: Immersive and Captivating: Black Desert - A Gaming Masterpiece

Rating: ★★★★★

Black Desert is an enchanting and visually stunning MMORPG that effortlessly immerses players into a rich and dynamic world. Developed by Pearl Abyss, this game captivates players with its breathtaking graphics, vast open world, intricate character customization, and engaging combat system. Having spent countless hours exploring its realms, I can confidently say that Black Desert is a true gaming masterpiece.

One of the standout features of Black Desert is its exceptional graphics. The game boasts incredibly detailed environments, lush landscapes, and stunning character models. Whether you're traversing sprawling cities, exploring dense forests, or battling powerful creatures, the visuals never fail to impress. The attention to detail is remarkable, making every corner of the game world a joy to behold.

Character customization in Black Desert is unparalleled, offering an astounding level of freedom and creativity. From choosing your character's appearance to customizing every aspect of their facial features, hairstyles, and even body shape, the possibilities seem endless. This level of personalization ensures that each character feels unique and allows players to truly embody their vision.

I mean, i truly think this game is supremely underrated. In the beginning, yea we had alot of toxicity and there was a bad community and alot of bugs. But they've smoothed so much out. There is a dedicated updates every week, new content, new classes alllllllll the time. Endless things to do. There is a dedicated community that keeps me coming back. I would say that over time this game has become one of the best mmorpgs to play. The "pay to win" aspect is heavily outweighed by the endless free items and gear given out regularly. The pay to win issue has been always relevant for the games growth... as any MMO. But they've been able to shift it in an angle that isn't directly affiliated with being better as compared to before. I will admit that when it was first released and within the first few years it definitely was considered more "Pay to win" but id say now, its not nearly as much and it makes sense. I mean if we wanna compare to things like Lost Ark; Atleast we dont have the ability to literally Buy gear score... just saying :) 

Above that, there is PVP, PVE content alike. I feel like this stuff hardly ever gets spoken about for some reason. But the PVE content is truly incredible. Its widespread and can have you going for a long time. To give some examples; Housing - You can do so much customisation with your own house that it would interest any UWU boy or girl to wanna decorate for hours on end. 

Taming/breeding- for those peeps out there that love training and horses and stuff

cooking- Literally endless recipes and like u could literally learn some stuff ofr ur own knowledge and kitchen because it does have some legit recipes just sayinggggggg

crafting/processing- i mean look this one up yourself, its pretty endless

Sailing or fishing- So yeah this is a whole category of its own btu this game got its own whole ass ocean and underwater exploration and fish u can fish and eat and also big sea monsters u can hunt , u can also get lost in teh sea and it can be scaryyy yup 

I didnt even name all of em because im not big on PVE in general but u can see this game somehow enticed me to enjoy PVE 

PVP- The pvp is pretty sick. There is no comparison to any game rn when it comes to the fast pase action combat. Idc what anyone says because ive played em alll okay. Bdo action combat is unmatched and it realy shows in PVP. 

anywayss, yeah there is some cons about this game and id say it would be time investment (LOL at almost 24k hours)but keep in mind most of its AFK so thats another thing to be aware. Think of old MMO where you would leave shop overnight and make money; instead u leave ur character to do processing or do fish and make money. And that's why u seen alot of hours. 

ANYWAYS amazing game, Highly recommend 9/10

I have spent a lot of time on the line between recommending and not recommending this game. Black Desert is a rather complex and involved game in some ways but overly simple with not much depth on the surface. As I once described to a friend, "it doesn't have much depth, but a LOT of breadth."

However, recently Pearl Abyss took over international publishing of their own game, removing Kakao Games, which has turned out to be a very good thing. It's taken a while to show, but Pearl Abyss is (albeit slowly) repairing and upgrading their game massively. My TL;DR take is, this is a great time to be a new or returning player to BDO, as (at the time of writing) there's a new area being released within a couple months and a lot of planned upgrades to the core game play, such as the entire original main story quest is supposed to receive actual voice acting and better cut scenes. There's already a sample of this out for the original initial area (Balenos). PA is constantly giving out cash shop items, at least 2 to 3 times more than Kakao ever did. Constant stream of events with actually decent items in them. Decent items in every Season's free rewards. Etc.

Now, to address the elephant in the Lily. Pay to Win. Black Desert has for some time, and still often faces, recurring accusations of pay to win. Now for the purposes of my own review, I am solely going to be dealing with this concept as "paying for something not available to be acquired in game without a cash purchase and/or providing an advantage exclusively through cash purchase." Recently in an argument in the new player group in game, someone brought up an example that when I thought it through, I thought was the PERFECT example despite the fact they used it to prove the opposite point.

Their example was that: If two players start the game at the same time but one pays cash while the other does not and that cash outlay provides an advantage, that's a problem. Well, actually. *Nerd glasses push.* Here's the problem with that assessment, people paying money into games often do so to compensate for lack of time, so a person paying money might say only play BDO actively for maybe 30 hours a week? Say, 3 hours a day during work days, 7 to 8 hours a day on their day off. This does not include afk times for horse training, fishing, etc. Now let's say the other guy is a hard core gamer with no life. He drops 80 hours active game play a week (again, not including afk timers, we'll just presume both have about equal afk times or neither afks because new and don't know that's a thing).

Now, following my example above and that working person with money has a near infinite bank pool of free cash to spend on the game, he will indeed pull a brief advantage with costume, underwear and tent buffs. Very likely, he'll also buy inventory space, weight limit space and possibly even bank space in a couple of cities. However, presuming they started at the beginning of a season, the gamer will quickly be done with his season before the other guy. He'll be learning about life skilling earlier, how to gain energy and contribution. How to use contribution to expand bank slots. How to do the Magnus quest to gain access to every bank in the game. How to acquire and use workers. Where the best spots are to grind for silver. That he can buy his own costumes off the Central Market. Which quest provides the free tent. That PA will give out undies eventually if he's patient. By end of Season, the gamer will likely have a rather large advantage over his "p2w" friend in the ways of knowledge and advancement in the game, not to mention acquiring and having spent his time grinding for the materials he'll need for enhancing his gear up.

"But Ashi, what about crons? You literally buy costumes for crons & you HAVE to have crons for enhancing your gear!!!!" They can be bought from a vendor? Sure, it's cheaper if you put a buy order for costumes on the market to get those crons which by implication makes it "p2w" because someone has to buy those costumes to fill those orders. I have 3 costume boxes from give away's in my bank I haven't used yet & get literal thousands of crons from just PA give away's, without even going to bosses which literally everyone does. (World Bosses are known for giving out crons). So, why are you complaining about supporting a p2w model that even the whales don't really support much anymore? Go buy them from the vendor or wait for them from the game.

The biggest problem is that the average player in BDO wants to "Rush to end game." Well, end game started when you turned it on, more or less. Black Desert Online is a Marathon, not a race. There is no "end of the game" per se, not really. You can hit a point where progression is pointless, yes. But then new content will come out and change that goal post. Take your time, smell some Silver Azaleas along the way and have fun, it's just a game.

Black Desert Online is an immersive sandbox MMORPG with a focus on PvE content, although the PvP aspect, featuring an engaging action combat system and skill animations, is quite enjoyable. As a fan of sandbox MMOs, I appreciate BDO's open-world approach to gameplay, offering a variety of in-game activities. However, the game's questing system leaves much to be desired, feeling rather dull compared to the rest of the game.

Having played other MMOs like Lineage 2, WoW, Aion, and GW2, I can say that BDO's graphics and performance are top-notch, although they require a powerful computer to experience fully. The game's community can be a mixed bag, with friendly and helpful guild members and Discord users, but in-game interactions are often marred by toxicity.

As a complex and deep game, BDO's learning curve can be quite steep, requiring dedication and motivation to master its mechanics and systems. However, once you get the hang of it, the class combos and skills make for an addictive gaming experience.

The developers' commitment to the game is evident through their weekly updates and the Global Labs test server. While BDO initially had a pay-to-win reputation, it has since evolved to require minimal cash shop investments. The tent is a prime example of a useful in-game purchase. However, the game's enchantment system can be frustratingly luck-based, and spending money on additional attempts may only lead to more frustration.

Overall, Black Desert Online offers an engaging and addictive sandbox MMO experience, with exceptional graphics, a variety of in-game activities, and consistent developer support. While the questing system and community interactions could use some improvement, BDO remains a rewarding game for those willing to invest the time and effort to learn its intricacies.

Don't play this game. It either ends up as a frustrating chore (like it has become for me) or a money pit. If they fixed a few things it would be the best game on the market but they won't because that would make them less money.

Things that could be fixed

-Enhancing. This whole system in my opinion is made to be a frustrating as possible so you either PTW your enhancements with cron stones or gamble hundreds of hours away with no guarantee of success. There is no point playing a game that actively punishes you for trying to get better gear. People will say just buy your gear - someone still has to enhance it.

-PVP. Where to start. Open world pvp suck because if you are a new player you will get bullied anytime someone gets bored and wants your spot. If someone with better gear than you picks a fight you will lose every time. The pvp in this game would be amazing if you could actually experience it. The easy solution would be to make servers with gear equalized open worlds for people that actually want to fight other people.

-Grinding. I understand they don't want us to get done with this game quickly but holy shit is this game a time sink. you can see my hours at the time of posting this, I have 273 ap 355 dp. That is barely good enough to even start touching the world at large. Id be looking at probably another 3000 hours to get into anything close to end game gear. There are long games and then there are games that are a second job: this one is one of them.

I'll add that the actual variety of grind spots at most levels is unfortunately low. most spots are the same thing in a different landscape and its a shame.

-Life Skills. I'll keep this section short. If you are going to have life skills make them engaging and actually make the money comparable to running in a circle killing things. Nothing is worse than watching a bar tick down so you can watch another bar tick down (and so on and so forth)

-PTW. people call it "pay for convenience" you can call an apple an orange but it's still an apple. 
examples: Premium Tent, outfits for silver, outfits extraction (and buffs), character slots, character weight, energy potions, nader's band, maids, horn/flute, inventory slots, pets, fairies etc

TLDR. Don't play this game as a new player. The time investment to fun payoff is completely lopsided unless you are willing to give this game thousands of hours of your life

I can speak from experience when I say that Black Desert is a visually stunning game with an engaging open world that provides players with a wide range of activities to partake in. Each character class in the game has a distinct playstyle, and the game's extensive skill tree enables a high degree of customisation. Fast-paced and engaging, the combat system features satisfying combos and skills. The game also boasts a strong economy structure that offers lots of options for players to engage in farming, trade, and crafting. Black Desert is an excellent choice for anyone searching for an immersive open-world game because it is well developed and entertaining overall.

I AM NOT AN ADDICTED MANIAC, my playtime is really mostly just afk horse training!

Pros:
- there's a lot of things to do in the game (hunting, fishing, cooking, alchemy, gathering, horse training, bartering, sailing) they're a chill side thing to do in the game. Or it can become a main one for a lot of people as everyone likes different things)
- the character customization IS THE ABSOLUTE BEST out there (that was the main reason I played this game from the start, and now that I don't play the game anymore it's the only reason I still sometimes come back to it 😂 but only to customize characters)
- the graphics, the places, the whole world is absolutely gorgeous, clear, beautiful and huge! There's so much to explore and see!
- seasons are nice and help you get decent gear faster
 

Cons:
- there's some bosses and stuff you can do with your friends too (but tbh it's not a lot and it can get boring after a few times and become monotone
- It's very likely playing this game will become a chore and not something you enjoy but something you HAVE TO DO because you HAVE TO GO TO THE BOSS at this time or you CANNOT miss a node war with your guildies and blah blah blah. It's not a chill enjoyable game anymore once you get addicted and you're required to do things
- it's extremely grindy, which is not fun and people can be toxic - they will kill you at sight because they're having a bad and and pick a fight if they're bored. Grinding can take you literal hours from your day, doing the same thing over and over again. Imagine you're spinning between the mobs for 4 hours just to get some loot that you can sell for a bit of money.. If you think that's enough money to buy you the gear you need or the horse you need. You're absolutely wrong. 😂 Try repeating the grinding every single day for a month or more doing that for a few hours and maybe you get strong enough to not get one shot by most people in the game. 😂 Also the same goes for dropping a special loot. It's rare to drop something good or valuable.
-enhancing is an absolute nightmare I still sometimes wake up from a dream, getting ptsd from trying to enhance a necklace to TET or PEN and accidentally not clicking crons and the necklace is now gone. Time to spend a few billion just to get it back or replace it with some capotia one we got for free as a gift which has was less AP. 
- there's super cool dream horses, that cost ONLY 12 billion or you can try to make one. You probably will manage to get one after 32 attempts (that cost more than the 12 billion) but hey at least you didn't spend it all at once.. Right?!!! Oh and then there's even more special horses that you can get by breeding TWO dream horses! Yea good luck with that.
- a good thing is you can make a lot of friends in this game! You'll definitely make thrice as much enemies tho! Super fun!
-afk traveling outside a safe zone is dangerous there's some people that'll randomly kill you, or maybe they're your old enemies that will kill you for a reason that is also unknown.

Overall 
It's a super fun chore -I mean game. But the fact stays it is very beautiful! I recommend 😁 just don't get too addicted, unless you don't have life at all and want to live in bdo like most people do.
The game has great graphics and is able to keep my attention as long as possible and this is just my experience

Well this is a hard one. I have something of a love hate relationship with this game. I´ve played it since it came to Steam and have never spend this much time in a Video game. These hours are nearly all active hours and not really any afk time. I´ve met my wife through this game and have spend way to much money on it. 

If you are looking for a game you spend a lot of hours into, than this is the game for you. For an MMO the fighting is purely unique. Having tried WoW last week i have to say, everything besides Black Desert combat wise, bores me. It´s really overwhelming for beginners but keeps you entertained until you have spend at least 200 hours into it. After that time it becomes really "grindy" (which MMO dosen´t). The thing most players hate is the Luck-Based upgrading System. I don´t think it is that bad. You have a lot of fun and fond memories until you have to grind for a month just to see your progress disappear. 

I can recommend this game dearly, but you have to know when to stop and don´t spend any money on it. Now you will receive everything you need that you had to spend money on in the past years to play properly. So go on, try it. Its only 10 bucks (5 when on sale). I don´t think anyone will regret it who likes MMO´s.

I'd normally give this game a positive review, all considering it's a pleasant MMO, but when I went for my favorite classes (the Witch and the Wizard), I discovered that out of 10 possible outfits selectable from the beginning of the game, SIX out of TEN featured Hebrew letters.
I can understand that those letters' look may appeal someone's sense of 'arcane' and such, but in my opinion they were a REALLY POOR CHOICE for a game having to do with a lot of magic, especially as they are notoriously considered to be an 'anti-magic' alphabet.
Knowing this, being the erudite scholar that I am, I decided to honour my knowledge and choose another class.
I still fail to understand why the Hebrew letters were so overly abused in these skins. Is there some meaning I'm missing?
(NOTE: In the game "Nier", they were at least used to display the 'Black Scrawl', a magickal sickness that wrote those letters on the skin of the afflicted and lead them to an agonizing death. That was more accurate.)
