[h1] Pay to win [/h1]
I've given Black Desert Online a few chances over the years, but I still can't seem to enjoy it. It feels like a casino game and a place where only rich kids get to enjoy, which makes it feel elitist and uninviting.

[b] Pros [/b]

The combat system is one of the best since TERA shut down. It's the only reason I might consider coming back to the game.
Character creation and design are well thought out and enjoyable to play around with.
The game's visuals are impressive, with great graphics and skill effects.
There is a lot of depth in the game, with unique features such as sailing and mini-games that add to the overall experience. Crafting and gathering are also enjoyable.

[b] Cons [/b]

Gear Upgrade System: Downgrading and sometimes even losing the item you are trying to upgrade is the biggest problem for me. Yes you can use "cron stones" to not lose your item but it still has a high chance of downgrading. Which means you lose progress and I can't stand that. (Counter argument to this is to grind and buy the item that has been upgraded already, which I will come to that later on.)

Grinding and the RNG system can also be tedious. I am not a fan of solo grinding. It feels bland and boring. 
You are given scrolls and potions that increases drop chance but even with those items grinding feels unrewarding. The percentage must be super low that even popping all the consumes needed, the item you are looking for will not drop for hundred of hours. Which takes the fun out.

P2W: I don t understand how people think that this game is not p2w. 

The minute i joined and asked what I need literally everyone told me i needed to BUY campsite tent. After trying to grind for infinite potion pieces I have realized that they did not put any merchant NPC around so that you can not sell the trash items that you have to sell because of the weight (gets heavy pretty quickly). Silver may not have any weight anymore but this does not feel any different than before. Not just the weight, you can also repair in tent and even get buffs that gives you extra AP. 

People buy 35 costumes in a week and sell them in market to get in game currency. They can get 1 PEN item in 4 weeks with that. As I mentioned before, because of the gear upgrade system is so bad even players ignore and find a way to avoid the system.

This is the least of the problems but i really like holy trinity and believe that games with holy trinity have decent mechanics that makes the game really fun to play.
everything

Black Desert Online (BDO) is a massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) developed by Pearl Abyss, offering an expansive world filled with endless activities and adventures. Although it might be overwhelming for new players, BDO's diverse gameplay, stunning graphics, and thrilling PvP system make it a captivating experience that should not be missed.

PvP System:
One of the most notable aspects of Black Desert Online is its exhilarating Player versus Player (PvP) system. Despite occasional balancing issues, it remains a highly enjoyable and engaging experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats. The open-world PvP, coupled with the ability to engage in large-scale battles through node wars and sieges, adds a level of intensity and excitement that is truly unparalleled in the world of MMORPGs.

The diversity of classes and their unique playstyles cater to a wide range of players, making the PvP system accessible to everyone. From agile archers to powerful wizards, there's a character that will suit any player's preferences. Furthermore, the intricate combo system allows for strategic and dynamic combat encounters, rewarding players who invest time and effort into mastering their chosen class.

Content and Activities:
Black Desert Online boasts an astonishing array of content and activities that cater to a variety of playstyles. Whether you're a casual player looking to relax through life skills like fishing, cooking, or trading, or an avid adventurer seeking the adrenaline rush of slaying monsters and completing quests, there's something for everyone in BDO.

The game's stunning open-world design invites exploration and discovery, with its breathtaking landscapes, captivating lore, and hidden treasures. This richness of content ensures that players will never run out of things to do or places to explore, as they immerse themselves in BDO's vast and dynamic world.

tl:dr
Black Desert Online is an immersive and captivating MMORPG that offers a plethora of content for players to enjoy. Its thrilling PvP system, despite some balancing issues, delivers intense and strategic battles that will keep players engaged for hours on end. The sheer volume of activities available ensures that there's always something new to discover, making BDO a truly unforgettable experience. So, dive in and lose yourself in the breathtaking world of Black Desert Online, where endless adventures await.

Oh boy, where do I begin with Black Desert Online? I've spent 1,825.7 hours on a game that has deleted my original account and sent only one email about transferring it...two years ago. What a joke!

The game itself is a confusing, hot mess. It's like they threw in all the MMORPG elements they could think of and hoped for the best. The character creation is the only highlight - I mean, who doesn't love spending hours fine-tuning their virtual self?

But once you're in the game, get ready for some serious grinding. And by serious, I mean excessive, mind-numbing, soul-crushing grinding. The pay-to-win system is also alive and well, so if you don't want to spend real money on the game, good luck.

The PvP system is a whole other can of worms. Like, seriously, high-level players just want to harass those who are lower-level? Where's the fun in that? And let's not forget about the bugs and glitches that make the game even more frustrating.

So, if you're looking for a time and money sink that will leave you feeling both angry and entertained, give Black Desert Online a try. But be warned - it's not for the faint of heart.

Black Desert is an immersive and visually stunning MMORPG that offers players a vast open world to explore and adventure in. The game features incredibly detailed graphics and animations, which bring the world to life and make every aspect of gameplay feel truly immersive.

One of the standout features of Black Desert is its character creation system, which is widely regarded as one of the best in any MMO. Players can customize their characters with an unprecedented level of detail, allowing them to create truly unique and personalized avatars.

The gameplay in Black Desert is equally impressive, with a deep and engaging combat system that rewards skill and strategy. Players can choose from a variety of classes, each with its own unique abilities and playstyle, ensuring that there's something for everyone.

In addition to combat, Black Desert also offers a wide range of other activities and features to keep players engaged. These include crafting, fishing, horse training, and even farming. There's always something new to discover and undertake in this rich and expansive world.

Overall, Black Desert is a fantastic MMO that offers a truly immersive and rewarding experience for players. With its beautiful graphics, engaging combat system, and deep customization options, it's easy to see why the game has garnered such a dedicated following.

Black Desert Online is a visually stunning and immersive MMORPG that has been gaining popularity since its initial release in 2016. The game boasts breathtaking landscapes and detailed character models that create a rich and engaging world for players to explore.

One of the standout features of Black Desert Online is its deep and customizable character creation system. Players have an incredible level of control over the appearance of their avatar, with a vast array of options for customization that allow them to create truly unique characters. Additionally, the game's combat system is fast-paced and action-packed, requiring players to utilize a wide range of skills and strategies to succeed.

The game's storyline and lore are also well-developed, with a rich history and a cast of characters that add depth and intrigue to the game's world. The game's quests are engaging and varied, ranging from simple fetch quests to complex storylines that take players on epic journeys.

However, Black Desert Online does have a few drawbacks. The game can be quite grindy, requiring players to invest a significant amount of time and effort to progress through the game's various systems. Additionally, the game's monetization model can be a bit frustrating for some players, as many of the game's more powerful items and cosmetics are locked behind a paywall.

Overall, Black Desert Online is an excellent MMORPG that is well worth checking out for fans of the genre. Its gorgeous graphics, engaging storyline, and deep customization options make for an unforgettable gaming experience. However, its grindy nature and monetization model may not be for everyone, so it's worth doing some research before diving in.

The stun locking in PVE is so horrendous sometimes it makes me question why I try to do things solo. The "group" content is virtually non-existent. The quest markers often point you in the complete wrong direction due to bugs, and since fast travel isn't a thing you basically waste plenty of time running back and forth whether it's on foot or horse. It's SO slow. 

If an enemy can stun lock you 100x in a row, what's the point of even fighting it solo? Just have it kill you with a guarantee ohko that's a bit fair to dodge. Not some unseen attack and mechanic that locks you into place for 20 minutes while you burn through hp potions to hopefully escape. OR, give the player an invincibility i-frame window after a certain number of stun locks to AT LEAST attempt to regroup. The frustration from this alone is an instant dashboard and opening of any other game that doesn't punish you for getting hit by unseen bologne. Yes, bologne. 

Quest Markers being bugged is only mind-boggingly infuriating because there is no fast travel. If you accidentally run across the map due to this, you just wasted 30 minutes travelling. Other games, this takes you 10 seconds. This isn't even bad once or twice. The game is beautiful, the scenery is fantastic, but the slog of getting anywhere makes wanting to do this 5x awful, let alone 100x. 

Group-content... why doesn't it auto que you with another group when attempting the few dungeons the game offers? Or other solo players. Yes, the option appears to do it solo... but why does the option appear to do the "group" version if it doesn't matchmake you with others? Simple fix - grey it out or place a comment beneath saying (you must find a team yourself, this is not a matchmade activity) SIMPLE. 

Visuals are still top-notch though, only thing keeping me from uninstalling and never coming back tbh. Everything else is just tedious, and I love games that require grind. Just not wasted grind, that's just big poopy to me.

8/10. BDO is a great MMORPG ONLY if you play it casually. I have played FF14, WOW, GW2, BnS. And BDO is the king of open world sandbox MMORPG currently.
Pros:
[list]
    [*]Great openworld content.
    [*]Many lifeskills to try. My favorite is horse training and sailing
    [*]Amazing skills animation, butter smooth combat.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
    [*]P2W. Many dogshit systems that force you to spend money. Especially if you care about being competitive
    [*]Pvp is trash. Server desync is real, classes are not balanced at all.
    [*]Super RNG heavy.
    [*]PvE content is grinding mobs in circle for hours. No challenging content.
[/list]

TLDR; If you're looking for a casual MMO to chill, try it out. If you want challenging content or do competitive Pvp, stay away. Personally, I play FFXIV for pve raids, and I chill in BDO for other casual stuff.

Do not touch if you are not running a high end PC or have a vast amount of patience. I do not have either. When I start a game, I typically start a game by going into menus to play with configurations until I am happy with it. 

On start, I went to settings in the main menu. Somehow, altering the graphics  somehow changed the entire screen resolution of my computer, even after the game was closed. This lead to extensive fiddling with UI and resolution to get something that didn't put menus off of my screen. Unfortunately, these efforts were wasted, because the frame rate counter in the settings menu was only reading 60 fps because it was measuring the start screen alone, and did not reflect what I had when I started the game. 

Upon starting the game, you are immediately shoved into a heavily restricted tutorial that does not appear to allow you to access the settings menu- since the esc key just takes you back to character creation at that point. And unfortunately, I could not find any way to get back to the start screen and settings menu from the character creation/server pick menus (this might be an effect of the resolution/UI scale issue... which is a problem in and of itself)

I am sure this is a great game when you can get it to run. But this forces you to repeatedly shut down the entire program and restart the game for every attempt to try a graphics setting until you get something you can stomach through the tutorial. 

I also had issues since I had hoped to go directly into controller support, but I understand that is a "me" problem when it comes to PC games. The settings issues take far more precedence.
The game has a lot of issues but the combat makes up for all of it.

i'm completely rewriting my positive meme review to give my actual opinion on the game.

you'll enjoy your progression and the experience for a couple of months, you'll probably join a guild and their discord and get to be friends with some of the people you play "with".  that's about it.

the main selling point of this game is combat and graphics - the game can look great, but it's not feasible for combat, as your damage is tied to your fps (no, i'm not joking, yes the devs have tried fixing it and it actually broke the game, so they have no plans to change it).  additionally, due to the nature of mmos and each user being connected to a server, ping is certainly an issue. classes with a lot of protection combined with users with high ping equate to opponents being in protection for far longer, with gaps in it appearing far less frequently.  if you're curious to see this in action, for NA, find any Aussie sorc and enjoy. the combat can be enjoyable and rewarding, up to a specific gear point.  after which, there is minimal balancing, and the combos and skill rotations you've learned and mastered are useless, as it becomes a test to see who can get one-shot through protection first.

the grinds are boring and repetitive, even if you try changing up the class you grind on or the location you grind in.

the community is mixed - on one hand, they will scream about the most efficient grind possible, and then they will go right to the enhancement screen instead of simply buying the item off of the market by grinding an extra couple of hours.  in one breath they will tell you about why your current progression is bad but then they will give you the wrong advice on how to progress next.  most of the community is so focused on their own grind, any form of pvp is just an instant server swap or they'll bring their entire guild to fight one person.

the developers are awful - every single major event where they make announcements is filled, and i mean FILLED, with "we've decided to delay/rework/cancel this upcoming content that we announced 2 years ago, sorry". i'll give you an example - in 2020, they made a big deal about adding a tower-like dungeon that you could do cooperatively.  they said that they would have it with the next big region update, late that year.  fast forward to DECEMBER 2022 - they announced that while they were in the final playtesting of this dungeon, their play testers found it to be too difficult and SCRAPPED IT ENTIRELY.  Their most consistent updates are to, of course, the cash shop and to in-game items that make existing cash shop items sell better.  enhancing an end game item too hard and your market place preorders won't go through? no problem! pearl abyss has developed an entirely new item that you can enhance to have the same stats as the end game item! as with all expensive enhancing, the only way to protect your enhancement from downgrading is by using a rather rare resource, which is conveniently available en masse in the cash shop! don't even bother submitting feedback - there's a few discords and official channels where they allow players to make "suggestions" but if you're not korean, you will be ignored.  part of the reason the class balance is so bad on na, eu, mena, sa, ru, etc is because class balance is geared towards the korean playerbase and regional ping (tip: it's always low!).  why is berserker busted? because the devs keep buffing him in the hopes that korean players will use him despite the character being "ugly" (even though you can customize your character to a high degree). why is awakening mystic terrible? because the korean playerbase considers her to be very good (she is not).  they continue to add more and more classes to a game that they can't balance as is.

don't play this game.  please, take it from a player who's sunk 11,597 hours in over 5 years, along with $11,726.12 USD, into this game.  it was fun for a long time, but i can't say that anymore.  the game is not good.  it is not fun.

tl;dr - fun for season if you're new, repetitive after the first one. graphics cool, but don't matter because you won't be playing the game in them. community is dumb, but you'll find some cool people. devs are horrific, dumb, money hungry, and will not listen to your feedback.

One of my fave mmos. most of my hours are on console but recently changed to pc. While i am giving it a good review i sadly cannot recommend this game for those with a weak wallet.  This games pvp is all over the place with balance issues and at the end of the day thats what this game is trying to draw you to. the pvp. The life skill aspect is pretty decent and you can go that route but it has its own cons some of which others will just leave you in the dust.
---------------------------------------------
((Cons))
-Gear score can take years to even get to a point where a F2P casual player can be relevant.  Unless you are down to put in some hours daily.
- Upgrading system is very Korean and convoluted.( you will spend hours and days grinding at a chance to just blow your gear up and do it all over again)

-Very Pay for Convenience Heavy compared to other mmos

-Pvp is forced at some points. (not fun contesting a grinding spot they fail to hold, so they call on a few friends/clan and now youre 1v3 in a grind spot youre sick of and still...  defending it thinking about the money you could have made in the time you have to fight for this spot. 

-Not a lot of multiplayer content aside from pvp so you will be alone most of the time. assuming you dont have a grind buddy

-No dungeons

- You will need a guide for most things as the game is a complete confusing mess with menus and quest scattered all over, Confusing crafting and Upgrading menus. 

((Pros))
-Beautiful graphics.
-Best char creator to date
-community can be great. 
-The skills are flashy and fun
-Farming for the first few 100 hours feels great and fluid.
- its addictive (should be a con lol)
-Beautiful world building.

It's a visually stunning MMORPG with a complex and immersive world. The game offers a vast character customization system and an engaging storyline. Everyone can be beautiful or hideous in this game. However, it's not without its flaws.

Pros:

Amazing graphics and character customization
Unique combat system that requires skill and strategy
Large and immersive world with various activities and quests to do
Deep crafting system with a wide range of options
Active and supportive community
Cons:

Limited character progression for free-to-play players
Grindy gameplay can be overwhelming and repetitive
Overly complex UI and systems can be confusing for new players
PVP can be very hitbox questionable from lag
Pay-to-win elements that may unbalance gameplay
Lack of engaging endgame content

Overall, Black Desert Online is a beautiful and engaging MMORPG that's worth a try for fans of MMOs. However, its heavy pay-to-win elements in the later game and complex gameplay may not be suitable for everyone.

Thought I would update my review 20k or so hours later. What I said above is still 100% true; i just wanted to add more detail about a few controversial points that people always ask about: grind, pay2win, gambling. 

If you enjoy grinding, especially the kind of grinding you can pair with secondary distractions like 2nd monitor TV shows or music & discord, then this game is godlike, 10/10, fun long grind good combat good lifeskills good marketplace good long-term plans you get to invest & strategize and come out rich.  Put in the time and you'll get to the end. 

You can always pay2win too but be aware, pay2win in this game doesn't uniquely make you godlike, it just puts you on the level of the people who've been grinding for years. If you want to feel like an OP god via your credit card you should probably play another game that makes pay2win easier for you. Besides, most of the gameplay is either solo (so why pay to be more powerful?) or if it's PvP it's usually PvP in stat-capped contexts where extra gear either doesn't help or only in limited ways helps. So... yeah you can pay2win. It's just probably not what you think. That's why people still argue about this to this day, there's so many little "if" and "but" to this stuff; it's kinda complicated, lol. I'll say it again and again, you can pay2win in this game, people do pay2win in this game... but you don't *have* to. What you do with that knowledge is up to you; plenty of other games have NO pay2win, so if it's a dealbreaker, well, it is what it is.  

If you can't stand grinding and just want meaty novel experiences every moment you login, then just go play other games and save yourself the effort. This is a game where you'll log in and say "oh boy! Time to kill trolls for the next 4 hours! And in another month of doing this, I can buy the sword that is 137 AP instead of 128 AP!" See what I mean? Being able to tolerate or enjoy long repetitive grind is a prerequisite to finding any satisfaction in this game. If that's you, then welcome! If that's not you... well, i'm just saying it like it is. This game's a grind, buyer beware. 

If you are susceptible to gambling addiction, avoid this game. You don't HAVE to gamble, but if you are susceptible you WILL gamble. And if losing gambles is frustrating for you, well you will lose gambles and you will be frustrated. You will get impatient with saving up 150 billion silver to buy a new earring, and you will look at that enhancement menu and say "4% chance I get it in one click, 96% chance it downgrades" and if you get tempted, you click that and guess what? 96% chance it fails, just like it says. meanwhile, your lucky friend will take the chance and get it, easy. Jealous? It's a casino. Like my other points, if this kind of thing is a deabreaker, then stay away. It is what it is. 

Anyway, if the above info doesn't discourage you, the game's cool. It's got fun combat and the guild wars are cool. I certainly like it, maybe you will too.

I love  this game and before I knew I had already spent a 1000 hours on the game. And this is my judgement of the game.

Pro:
- lot's of diffrent and unique classes (Every year they add more classes)
- events (There is always some event going to keep you busy)
- Horses/ships (there are tiers of horses and ships in the game)
- big open map (you will spent a good amount of time exploring)
- community (most of the community is kind and helpfull to eachother)
- Lot of Pets (pets give you buffs and make your work somethimes eassier)

Contra:
- Gear (I find the amount of armors and weapons really low. You either do a season for season gear or you spend a huge amount of money to have some decent gear)
- Upgrading system (you upgrade your armor/weapons/etc from 1-15, after that it's in romen numbers 1 to 5. Once you hit the romen numbers the chances to succeed are really low. I find the jump too high)
-Trading: You can barely trade something in the game with your friends. Almost everything goes through the central market.

I hope this helps some people of getting an idea of the game.

"A visually stunning MMORPG with deep gameplay mechanics"

Black Desert is a visually stunning MMORPG that offers a deep and engaging gameplay experience. The game's world is vast and detailed, with breathtaking landscapes and intricate environments that will immerse you in the game's lore and story.

The game's combat system is well-designed, with fast-paced action and a variety of classes that each have their own unique playstyle. The game offers a lot of depth and complexity, with a variety of skills, abilities, and customization options that allow you to tailor your character to your preferences.

The game's crafting and trading systems are also well-developed, with a variety of resources and items that can be gathered and traded for profit. The game's economy is vibrant and dynamic, with a variety of players and NPCs engaging in trade and commerce throughout the world.

On the negative side, the game can be overwhelming and complex for new players. There is a lot of information to absorb and a variety of systems to learn, which can be daunting for those new to the game.

The game's graphics, while stunning, can also be demanding on hardware, and the game requires a relatively high-end computer to run smoothly.

Overall, Black Desert is a visually stunning MMORPG that offers a deep and engaging gameplay experience. The game's combat, crafting, and trading systems are well-designed, and the world is vast and detailed. While it can be overwhelming for new players and demanding on hardware, it's definitely worth checking out for fans of the genre looking for a rich and immersive MMORPG experience.

Over time you may have to spend a few bucks for some progression or rely on some events to give you free stuff, so if you do not have any qualms with busting out the ol' reliable, consider playing casually and maybe do some "life skilling" by engaging in other activities like horse training, crafting, etc.

All in all it's a pretty enjoyable game that I get back to from time to time just to pummel some enemies on my Mystic.

Having played the game on and off since 2019, I think it's fair to say I have a fairly experienced outlook on what the game has gone through and where it's at now.

The uptrend in player numbers and clear increase in popularity is, in my opinion, a direct result of the positive changes made over the past two years to almost entirely overhaul the game from its old customer gouging practices that were enforced by their original and ever infamous publisher, Kakao Games (you may know them from their ruining ArcheAge fame). 

Pearl Abyss became their own publisher in 2021, and since then they have taken the game from strength to strength, making the game more and more new player friendly, and giving away so many once expensive and exclusive pets, maids and outfits, to the point that it has become genuinely hard to justify spending any money on the game these days even as an experienced player.

If you were turned off in years past by the once obnoxious business practices, I would give it another try and see how you find it, because the incredible combat and open-world sandbox are unlike any other MMO out there, and it's now more accessible and enjoyable than it has ever been.
Retail version of the game is pretty good now, you can still go to a private server is you so wish, but I don't see the need now.

Literally Hundreds of hours, thousands of dollars, all deleted.

I started this game six years ago when it launched coming from archeage with a group of friends.  In that time i purchased virtually every upgrade one can for their account, character slots, weight limit upgrades, outfits, underwear, premium time.  First when it was under Daum games, then when Daum got bought by Kakao, and even when Kakao got bought by PA.

This game was my go to when no other titles held my interest, PA's decision to delete all characters that didn't transfer actually required more effort and labor than simply transferring everything.

Losing my chracters is forgivable, they can be replaced.  But the thousands of dollars of cosmetics, inventory upgrades. The hundreds of hours of collecting knowledge enough for over 300 energy and 300 node investment points, Grinding out S rank for the popular farming mobs, learning the conversation chains to collect gated knowledge from NPC's, Grinding out the materials for a merchant vessel, breeding high tier horses, etc....

Losing that investment not because the game was shut down, or because i did something that violated ToS and got banned, but simply because PA decided not to transfer all accounts... It leaves such a bad taste in my mouth I caution anyone against trusting that their characters in ANY PA TITLE will be there waiting for them should they decide to take a break from said title.

TL;DR: Thousands of dollars, hundreds if not thousands of hours, all gone for reasons that still defy explanation.  This game was a gem, despite all it's flaws, and PA ruined it for me and who knows how many other players.  Buyers Beware.

P.S. The real kicker is less than a year before the transfer when i was still actively playing i purchased BDO on steam in the hopes of moving my account from the independent launcher to the steam launcher and put in a ticket to request it only to be told, 'this is not possible'  I installed the game and ran the launcher overnight just to be able to leave this review.

**Edit @1300+ Hours** friends asked me to play again with them and against my better judgement i agreed... I'm addicted all over again.  I stand by what i said before, but the game really is a lot of fun.

Black Desert is hands down one of the best MMORPGs I have ever played. The game world is vast and beautiful, with stunning graphics that will leave you in awe. From the deserts to the forests, every location in this game has its own unique feel and atmosphere.

The character customization is unparalleled, allowing you to create a truly unique avatar that is entirely your own. You can customize everything from your character's facial features to the way they walk, and the level of detail is truly impressive.

The combat system is fast-paced and incredibly satisfying, requiring you to master your skills and abilities in order to become the ultimate warrior. The skills are visually stunning and the combos are extremely fun to execute.

The game offers so much content, from PvE to PvP and even crafting and trading. The vast open world and non-linear gameplay will keep you entertained for hundreds of hours, with plenty of secrets and surprises to discover along the way.

In conclusion, Black Desert is a true masterpiece of an MMORPG that is definitely worth your time and money. The stunning visuals, deep combat system, and vast open world make it a must-play for any fan of the genre.

As someone who has invested 3000 hours into Black Desert Online, I can confidently say that this game is a masterpiece. The attention to detail in the graphics, the immersive open world, and the extensive character creation system are just a few of the things that make this game truly exceptional.

One of the things that keeps me coming back to Black Desert Online is the sheer amount of content available. There is always something new to do, whether it's fishing, crafting, or engaging in PvP battles. The game truly offers a diverse range of activities to keep players entertained for hours on end.

The grind required to progress through the levels can be daunting, but it's also what makes the game so rewarding. There's nothing quite like the sense of accomplishment that comes with finally reaching a new level or obtaining a rare item after hours of hard work and dedication.

What I appreciate most about Black Desert Online, however, is the community. The game has a thriving player base that is always willing to help and support each other. Whether it's sharing tips and tricks or working together to take down a tough boss, the community aspect of the game is truly special.

Overall, I highly recommend Black Desert Online to anyone who is looking for a deep, immersive, and rewarding MMORPG experience. With 3000 hours invested, I can safely say that this game has exceeded my expectations and provided me with countless hours of enjoyment.

[h1] Never fails to disappoint but still will remain my favourite MMORPG [/h1][b] Never have I ever thought Black Desert Online will make to the top of my list when it comes to feeling like I'm able to do anything I want in the world. [/b] All the travelling and exploring, questing and life-skilling. From gathering, hunting, trading, bartering, cooking, alchemy, fishing or horse training - you'll find your niche and enjoy it! [b] It feels like an experience from a world you wish you were born into [/b] as if it was a true medieval dream meeting fantasy at its most appreciated aspect - magic & exceptional skills! Plenty of classes to choose from and even though they are behind a gender and race lock - there's still a way to find what any new player would enjoy! PVP is a lot of fun! I hope you find your place in this vast world of so many possibilities! I've kind of grown tired of PVP and constant wars but I'm sure the experience is no match to no other mmo at the moment.[i] Of course, how could I forget - it is filled with bloodthirsty good-for-nothing children who know nothing better but how to grief totally innocent players in the world. Swords come first rather than words - one gets ganked, killed, declared war upon because of the most childish reasons. [/i][b] But do not mind that - there are ways to avoid people like that! [/b] A good variety of guilds to choose from, they're strong, cool, role-playing, life-skilling and have loads of knowledgeable people to help you out! Quite some nice people to befriend and play with! Most use discord - just be engaging and friendly - you'll find your way about it.

[h1] 8.3/10 [/h1]
So much stuff in this game.


Edit:
->After playing a LOT more of this game, I can say it's pretty darn good! 
It seems to have a lot more than other MMOs but the gameplay is like.. Completely different. 
There's no dungeons or really anything like that. 
There's this whole community store type of thing where you can sell and buy gear, food, and other random things.

[h1] Play style and Life skills [/h1]

->THE AMOUNT OF DIFFERENT PLAY STYLES AND STUFF YOU CAN MAX OUT IS CRAZY! 

->They have a whole section for your strength and stuff like that, but there's a lot of skills you can level up called life skills. 
These include, 

Gathering
Processing
Cooking
Alchemy
Training
Fishing
Hunting
Trading
Farming
Sailing

->And these can all be lvl'd up a CRAZY AMOUNT. Increasing the skill level normally makes it a lot more worth doing that skill.
Like upgrading Gathering by collecting plants and stuff like that will make it so you get more of that item when gathering. It also makes it so it's faster to gather. 
Some items have level requirements. The life skill levels are a little difficult to understand at first, but basically they go; 
Beginner	        Lv 1 to 10
Apprentice	Lv 1 to 10
Skilled	        Lv 1 to 10
Professional	Lv 1 to 10
Artisan	        Lv 1 to 10
Master	        Lv 1 to 30
Guru	        Lv 1 to 20

[h1] Money Making [/h1]

->There's so many different ways to make money in this game. You can farm, craft potions and items, farm enemies, and even breed and tame horses. 
The horses have a level and skill system of their own. 

[h1] Character classes [/h1]


->There is also a decent amount of Characters who all have their own skill trees that INCLUDE their own 2nd Skill tree later on that you can decide if you'd like to upgrade to.
There's actually reason that you may want to make multiple characters.
Reasons being that;
1: They have these seasonal times every once and a while that makes it so you can create a SEASONAL character and get a punch of unique rewards, including enough EXP to get you to about lvl 50. 
2: To try they crazy amount of Characters abilities. The first Character I played was a Tamer. When I played the Tamer I didn't have to pretty much ever get off my Wolf thingy. The wolf summon thing you get after lvl 20 as a tamer is pretty much faster and stronger than any horse. It also has like this life steal and mana steal thing so I was able to pretty much never die and just kept fighting high level enemies and bosses.
3:Some Outfits and weapons you find can ONLY be equipped to certain Characters.

[h1] Some other stuff about it  [/h1]

->It's kinda strange but there's a good amount of boat stuff in this game too. There's a shit ton of Boats with their own customisations and even like a upgrade tree?
->You can higher crew members for your ship to make it easier to use and even send them on islands to get resources. 

->You can higher workers and buy building for them to work at in order to produce items, clothing, etc.

->There's even a lil bit of Choice missions. They don't seem to change all too much though. 


[h1] Character Customisation [/h1]

->THE CHARACTER CUSTOMISATION IS AMAZING! There's plenty you can change on your character ALTHOUGH, the default features of a character (I.E. Their gender and some other small things) are Character class locked (I.E. Tamer class can only be female). You can change your voice too. If you don't want to or can't make a good looking character, there's a community catalogue in the character creator that has some GREAT and LOVELY looking people. 

[h1] The Map [/h1]

->The map is pretty fucking big too! There's a decent sized water part of the map  ( you need a ship for that stuff. It's got islands that you can explore a little), A desert part of the map (You need a compass to tell where you are in the desert and also some holy water so you don't die of heat), and then just some land parts that look different and unique depending on where you're.



->A lot of the game and characters are voice acted.

[h1] Conclusion  [/h1]

->There's so much more of the game that I did not talk about, but I am too tired to talk about the bible amount of stuff in this game. If you love MMO's or like to grind stuff, this is the game for you.<-

Good but extremely grindy.
Good For adventure ...

The Good

It's a beautiful world, and the character generation is way more detailed than an MMO has any right to be.
The world is unique enough that I find it enjoyable.  Far too often Fantasy worlds dig up Tolkeins grave and root around in his pockets for loose change for their ideas.

It does feel like over the years, they've completely cut the introduction to the world.  I guess that's for longtime players who just want to rush through the content to get to endgame though.

The action combat is exceptionally smooth, when I first played it, it was way smoother than I had ever expected an MMO to be able to pull off.

The classes are now varied enough to give you a lot of different options for different playstyles.  I usually don't like class based fantasy games, as I find them far too restrictive, and prefer a looser character building system.  But it's decent enough.

The Bad (For me)

I don't care for the endgame.  I know I went in knowing there was open world PvP, but I'd prefer it if it was opt-in or opt-out like some of the older MMO's.  So I really only play during Season.

Life Skills take up way too much time.  Even though I have something like 1.5k hours in the game, a solid 50% of that has been AFK doing life skill stuff.

Neither Good Nor Bad

The crafting system is almost exactly what I want.  If it didn't cause damage to the base item, it would be damn near perfect.  It's simple, you're not constantly replacing equipment once you get close to endgame, you're just upgrading your stuff.  Great.  But the billions of silver it takes to get high end gear, and repair your gear from damage, and failstacking to save your good gear.  Kinda ruins it.  So it's middling.

After putting years into this game, I think it is finally time to throw in the towel. Imagine allowing a player in the game to run around intentionally robbing guild storages and cashing the items in for his own profit. A player has been doing that for years. Reports have been made, forums posts have been made and garnered traction, yet for some reason, this company refuses to do ANYTHING about it. The player in question can't even speak in game, as he has been chat banned for harassing women and calling people the N word. He goes into game related discord servers and posts screenshots of his pillaging and mocks people for it. What MORE do these people need to see before they act? I find it incredibly insulting that they are dragging their heels when it comes to taking any action on this. This is giving me the impression that they value the thief over the honest players. I hope they all quit as I am about to do the same. This whole situation is disgusting and shows that the people working for PA are cowards when it comes to taking action in their game.

I had previously given this game a positive review which I deleted today, I will consider changing it back when something is done, until then, stay far far away.

Update: it appears that player in question is actually an employee of Pearl Abyss and that is why no action has been taken, and also, people have lost their jobs because of it, to keep the offender safe.

Another update:  This company has now hired a player who was involved in a scandal in 2020 to be a new Community Manager.  Mappers working for the company.

Where this game shines for me is with its Seasonal Servers which allows you to try different class of your choice each season with decent rewards while making said character progress and gear for most of the content in the game without even spending any money.

I haven't played BDO much but I have much to say, (all good). The graphics are better than other mmo's I've played. I like the story for the mountain of eternal winter quite a bit. (It's the only story bit I've gotten through at this point.) I don't usually like lifeskills in mmo's but the lifeskilling in BDO is actually kind of fun. They're like minigames you can play in a way, but you can also afk grind levels and I love that they understand the need for it. You can't trade in-game, so you don't get a chance of being conned with game currency scammers, and the marketboard system is set up so you can't sell below a certain price, so you're not being constantly undercut. You have to actually aim when using abilities when fighting and can't just autolock onto your target. Overall the game play itself is much better and more thoughtful than other mmo's and I highly recommend it.

Maybe I'm just too old or not familiar with MMO conventions, but this game is WAY too complicated. There's too many tabs, too many currencies, the tooltips are like short stories and the dialogue is as thick as pea soup. The combat is actually pretty fun with lots of promise but it took WAY too much of a time investment to actually GET to any of it. 

Also, it behooves me to say that, while the character creator *is* impressive, it's not nearly as unlimited as it would lead you to believe. Each class is bound to a model (and yes, the classes are gender-locked, which isn't as huge of a problem as I would have thought at first blush, to be fair), and while you can change the model's hair (the hair tools are actually pretty rad) and apply tattoos and makeup, you can't change the face very much at all without completely distorting it to look inhuman (or just plain disgusting). Want to make a thick-jawed, broad-faced Shai? Not gonna happen. It's not nearly as robust and creative as the game would have you believe.

In general, this game is pretty neat if you can invest yourself into it and learn all the labyrinthine systems and lingo. The combat's fun and the world seems pretty neat. But, especially with the purchases, I can't help thinking, after being shunted through three or four different screens just to make *one* purchase, that I'm being taken for a ride. Give it a try if you're a die-hard MMO fan with time to burn and a strong motivation to learn, but if you're looking for anything that falls anywhere on the "casual" scale, give this one a pass.

As someone who put a ton of hours into this game over the years, I can honestly say i did not enjoy how unforgiving the games upgrading system was, and how much it impacted my ability to actually make good silver at high end areas. HOWEVER, in the last couple years they have made it so unbelievably easy for a new player to come on, and within a few months be making solid silver at high end spots with reasonable gear. Are you going to come in and be competitive in PVP after a few months, no. However, are you able to come in and have a solid 6 months of consistent game play filled with progression and positive experiences, absolutely. If you have played BDO in the past, id highly recommend coming in and giving it another try, i definitely don't regret it.

Just clutter. That's what your inventory is going to be full of in this game. Want more space? Pay real money. Otherwise it's like a mailbox crammed full of junk mail.

For me this game became a full time job that I wasn't willing to take on. The inventory slots are so few and the Devs  fill them up on a daily basis. your options at this point are to shell out real money to buy more or grind it out and buy warehouses in every town and even at that you fill them up fast. At that point you are travelling from town to town combining inventory items and trying to make more space so you can just continue to do the quests which are almost 100% kill quests. The game itself it remarkably beautiful but cluttered to the point that the scenery is overtaken with monsters. For me it wasn't fun at all. It might be for you though.

Best MMORPG experience I have ever had, besides Final Fantasy. I've been playing since it released. Took a couple breaks from this game because of the extremely difficult gear enhancing system (just like many other people). I give this game a 9/10, if enhancing armor, weapons, and accessories was a little easier (Pearl Abyss has done a few things to try to make it slightly easier to obtain full PEN gear) I would give it a 10/10. 

Personal Opinion: I don't think that gear should ever be downgraded if an enhancement fails. And accessories should NOT break! I would rather have a slightly lower enhancement chance and my gear not ever downgrade and accessories not disappear. Or make it so that you don't have to have a RIDICULOUS amount of Cron Stones to prevent gear from downgrading/disappearing when enhancement fails, or make Cron Stones MUCH CHEAPER. And fail stack should still INCREASE when I use Cron Stones, especially since you are required to use such a ridiculous amount. The enhancement system feels more like punishment sometimes, rather than progress.

This could be the best MMO on the market.  Sadly, the game suffers from terrible design decisions.  There is next to no group content.  No dungeons or engaging things to do with friends - other than explore the map.  The entire game loop is centered around 1-shotting groups of several monsters, collecting their trash drops, and selling them to a vendor.

After you have farmed by yourself for 15 hours and sold all your trash items to a vendor, you then spend your earned money on a RNG armor or weapon upgrade.  When the upgrade fails, because it more than likely has a 0.001% chance to succeed, the item is destroyed.

This is pretty much the whole gameplay loop for making money and progressing your character's power.  Grind for money via monsters or tradeskills --> Spend money on RNG item upgrade with a very low chance; you fail --> Repeat. 

I check on the game every now and then, hoping the developers have finally come to their senses.

Game has the potential to be the best MMO... But its problems outweigh that potential badly. 
- Pay to win. If you don't pay, then grind and gamble for god knows how long to MAYBE keep up with those who do pay.
- Pay for any good cosmetic. You'll look insanely basic throughout unless you use real money.
- Basically a single player game. It really sucks that there's absolutely NO incentive to interact with players unless joining a guild. Even the text chat is mostly dead.
- Voice chat features don't work, so that dimension of interaction suffers compared to New World, for example.
- Hard to learn for new players - combat feels great but things like workers, enchanting, trade are hard to get into.
- Probably the dumbest housing system. You can get rewarded for having more decorations in your house, so players just turn houses into depressing factories and it sucks. Feels like a damn mobile game there

As for how I think the game could be fixed
- Ditch pay to win
- Have a more clear late game (As in a clear number or level to hit, like GW2. lacking a level cap in an mmo is bizarre)
- Breath life into the social aspects of the game. dungeons, more reliable chat options, and REAL multiplayer content
- Allow new players to reach the highest levels in a reasonable amount of time. Again, they can't really expect to enjoy pvp or guild content unless they grind an excessive amount or P2W. 
- Please ditch the pay to win
- Maybe add in more world events that can reward players with iconic, powerful gear.... So you don't have to enchant.

But I mean I got the game for a dollar on sale so if that says anything.

disqualifying features for some players:
This game has changed substantially over the years, although the play style is similar returning players will be jumping into an entirely new game. So longevity wise don't expect current gear to matter in another few years.
It's slightly buggy, I'd say average for MMO's but FAR worse compared to other for large MMO's
It's something you'll have running 24/7 on a PC pulling power so if that's not something you want in a game I'd say that's the biggest drawback - it seems like an easy feature to have to save electricity like some games (or just not having an AFK component like other's

it has been out for about 7 years now and definitely feels like a 7 year old game - although there are MANY event's to keep players engaged, progression is near impossible without playing seasonal characters. So second big negative is the time commitment to reach softcap is much larger than comparable MMO's

the story is decent, but there is A LOT of it, which could be good or bad depending on your playstyle

if you got this far and there isn't enough deterring you from playing chances are this is a must try RPG so...
NOW, for the positives:
1. arguably had the best graphics of any MMO game closer to release - still upholds some very impressive graphics compared to major MMO's like FF15 and ESO
2. quest pathing makes linear progression
3. One of the largest selection of non-mechanic bosses (low learning curve compared to most games)
4. complex and interesting mass PvP
5. interesting and extravagant outfits for fashion players

I do not play this game on steam, and I pre-purchased it on their website before the game launched. Real-gametime is much higher, with one of my 16 characters having 200 days play time.

Played on and off since launch but uninstalled this year with no intention of reinstalling.

Progression is extremely slow and its very hard to get to the highest tiers of gear. Grinding is pretty fun and there is a large amount of open world things you can do. As someone who enjoys doing *everything* or most things a game has to offer this game is not for me.

It is quite literally impossible to participate in all aspects of this game within a reasonable time period. Skills are slow and time consuming. Open world activities are slow and time consuming. Training past level 62~ currently is incredibly slow. Lots of alternative characters to gear up so having more than 1 set of decent gear starts to get time consuming. Production/crafting is done while afk so you leave the game open all night to do things while you're afk.

This game requires full dedication to achieve any sort of end-game and I am tired of the RNG.

If you're casual and want to immerse yourself and play for a few hundred hours go ahead.
Completionists beware.

EDIT: Game is free atm, try it free, try not to get sucked into the p2w stuff cause youll end up bankrupt. Set yourself reasonable limits. Only buy things on sale, also they are digital goods its only worth what you're willing to pay "sales" are an illusion!

Edited :   The more time I spend with the game, the more I love it.   There are some bugs sure, but this is by far one of the most beautiful game worlds I've had the pleasure of spending time with.    I hope it lives for another decade.    There are some hardcore fast moving players in this game.  Returning players who can level and gear insanely fast.   

If you are a new player,  personally I recommend ignoring their pacing.   Take time to explore each class and play through the main quest line a few times.   Read the story,  stop and smell the roses.     If you're an older gamer and you can take some time to appreciate how far we've come with games you'll enjoy this.   

While I don't expect to be able to rank well, or compete with high level players,  I'm going to be spending some time here just enjoying it for what it is.     The combat is phenomenal,  the classes are built well,  the game world is just amazing.  

My goal is to eek out just enough of a presence to enjoy the different parts of the game without feeling like im grinding myself to dust.   

It's all about fun.

If you're an RPG or MMO fan and you haven't spent some time here,  I highly recommend Black Desert.    Even though there is bound to be bigger and better in the future,  this is one you don't want to miss out on.

10k hours in

you can play it casually. progression isnt as cancer as 4 years ago 

the developers patch the game regularly 

but class balance is a complete joke . so if you are a competitive player you will get mad at either the lack of balance patches to classes or the random insane buffs to certain classes while others seem to be left behind

25 classes and 2 specs for each class so 50 different play styles. not all classes and specs are equal. but play what you enjoy. if you want to chase the meta play what ever the newest class released is at the time in which you want to play

the cash shop has some mandatory stuff in my opinion. but its a korean game so what did you expect
its less cancer than it was 4 years ago. but you will still spend money 

the combat is 1000 out of 10 
the system its self and the feel of classes is incredible i would compare it to playing a 3rd person fighting game more than a mmo. 

the better your pc is the better your experience is. the game has player animations tied to fps so if your a 60 fps gamer, your  skill connection speed and fluidity is much slower than some one playing at 144 fps there is a point of diminishing returns to this speed benefit from high fps but there is no hard cap. 

this means that while the game looks pretty on high graphics, everyone that pvps turns everything to potato mode for advantage.  so if you have a  lower end pc. you have to accept this fact. 

the games default optimization is very poor as it wants to eye candy you . googling a bdo optimization guide will make your experience a million times better. 

open world pvp is unlocked at level 50 
there is life skilling in the game as well and it is very in depth. 

there is seasonal ranked 3v3 called Arena of Solare
there is Team Death Match  game mode called Red battle field

there is Guild vs Guild battles called Node wars and Seige where players fight over open world objectives for territory

the twitch community is a good place to get integrated into the game
also joining the Class Discord Servers for what ever class you choose to play

there are 3 dungeons out right now with a 4th on the way as well. but if monster raiding is your main love in a mmo this game doesnt have much to offer you. Field Bosses arent worth it (unless they rework them in the future) and world bosses are damage sponges

I am an 86 year old pole dancer and great great grandma, and probably one of the oldest on the game.  I am single mother of a 6 year old who might not get to have me in her later years due to my old age.  My grandson (of Asian decent) bought me this game with his allowance money from his strict Asian home. My daughter saw me playing this one day and its been hard for us to connect since i'm not as mobile as i use to be.  So i decided to make her a steam account and get her a copy so she could join me on countless adventures. Me and my daughter then played I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Daughter since my husband had died. It turns she loved it so much i had to get her a custom keyboard for small fingers. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Daughter many happy memories.

Black Desert is a very different MMORPG. It feels almost like a hack and slash but there is tons of amazing combos and free flowing action that take it many lengths further to the realm of action games. And that it has plenty. Action and exploration. 

The customization options are huge and there are tons of character classes. You can tweak the colors of pretty much everything and unlock some really great and even iconic styles, but also buy some amazing albeit expensive costumes with real money if tempted, although you do not have to. 

If you were looking for loot, this is not the game that would excite you with trinkets although there is tons to unlock. You can use the same weapons you got in the beginning, and play all the way to level 60 with just one set that you can upgrade to the max. You can choose out of different styles/looks of armor and weapons. But you do not have to worry where to get them. They are sold cheaply at the store. Of course if you want the super fancy and maxed out items you need to work extra. But you do not need those until you are deep in the game past lvl 60 and what you can get from the store or unlock as gift from your quests look really great.  

This game will excite you with a vast and meaningfully interactive world that you master with every action. A complex network of people and short stories that unlock more options and everyday stories. A deeper element of crafting than other similar games, and even trade of products and produce between cities and investing on lands buying homes, livestock, creating workshops, hiring people, capturing your horse from the wilderness, etc etc. Even horses have tiers and trainable skills. 

It is amazing for explorers. Great distances and vast vibrant towns and cities to explore. Characters you can interact with and unlock dialogues and quests in every corner. Even in the middle of the road. Even in the middle of a forest. If you expect a streamlined and relatively streamlined experience like WoW... this is not it. It is open, and chaotic, and vast. Like a real world. 

Of course, due to all these options and possibilities it can be a very confusing game for a newcomer as there is no teleportation, especially when you start understanding how knowledge works and how it affects who you can talk to, what nodes are and how they work to facilitate crafting or trade, but here's the cool trick, 
A. you do not have to deal with all these things at once, 
and B. the game is designed to take some of the burden of complexity if you so choose, you can just click on a little icon and the game will take you automatically exactly where you need to be while you are sipping your favorite beverage. :P

The game is definitely worth playing and investing time on it. If you need something simple, just to beat some challenging bosses wear a series of shiny throwaway sets and get some fancy loot to brag for a few days to your friends, this is definitely NOT the game for you.  While it has plenty of intense action, and combat mastery with amazing combos for each and every class, it is a lot more than just that.

Understand that I haven't played in a while(I quit before the ownership(?) changed from kakao to just pearl abyss), just thought I'd leave my thoughts as someone who played it for a damn long time, allegedly before this game became 'truly pay to win' as I heard. This'll be a long review, but surprisingly not even that in depth because there's a lot going on in this game.  

Bdo is very much not a sprint, and absolutely a marathon. It's near impossible for someone to reach end game in a short amount of time, but there are plenty of things to do(lots of different life skilling mostly) to take up your time, and your progression never technically stops, which is good. The game does look amazing(although there are quite a bit of pop-ins), and even with newly released mmo's, I still think Bdo is the one with the best graphics with very flash and fluid combat.  

Now, having said that, Bdo(at least at the time I quit approximately 2 years ago) was a very grindy game in every respect. As someone who doesn't like to repeat the same content over and over again, this game quickly became a chore and I ended up life skilling more than killing mobs. Combat that initially seemed cool quickly became dull as you just repeated the same combos over and over again. The many characters may delay this boredom, but it is inevitable unless you like that sort of thing. Mobs pretty much exist to be killed. In higher tier areas, it can get challenging, but there isn't really a reason to be farming there if you can't even kill the mobs efficiently.

To bring 'new content' to the game, there were regular events. Unfortunately, events were mostly the same thing, just with minute differences. Do a few quests(fetch, kill, talk etc), kill mobs for special drops or quotas, login daily; rinse and repeat. It gets quite monotonous, but this is a typical aspect of mmo's so it's not really something to complain about. There's only so much they can do I suppose. The problem is that everything plays the same(Anyone who's sunk more than a few hours will understand). 

The story...exists. If your comprehension skills are over 9000 and you like convoluted messes. 

The end game doesn't exist. No raids or dungeons, so no pve end game unless you count grinding. World bosses are there, but you can start them immediately and get some free loot(I'm not even kidding).

Pvp...exists, but personally I don't think it's very fun(I have fought quite a few people but it's rly disjointed). 

Personally, sieges(Mass pvp) feel boring. It's just a mess that'll blind you in seconds and takes a long while to set up. 

The rng systems implemented are a pain in the ass(to put it lightly), as progression isn't guaranteed, and you may blow billions of silver(Which could take months to acquire) in minutes trying to upgrade ONE piece of gear! I won't even bother mentioning the failstacks you need to prepare as well(which is probably one of the worst parts of this game). This rng system also applies to other things like uptiering horses(which isn't that relevant but they look good and obviously go faster the higher tier you go). 

The cash shop is also something of concern(Which apparently got much worse after I quit). The value-pack and other time-limited boosts like the blessing of Kama feels like a must have if you're going long term. The value pack costed about $20 or so AUD at the time I played, and it gave you more inventory, storage, xp gain etc, which is a damn big difference once you experience it. Fortunately, I don't really have a problem with anything else in there, and these boosts are the only things that felt truly pay-to-win. The costumes were pretty close though. You can also buy outfits to sell in the marketplace for ingame silver, but it's not worth unless you got a lot of $$$ to spend. 

Luckily, both the rng system and cash shop can technically be avoided if you use the marketplace, but you'll need to have quite a bit of patience and a lot of silver. So yeah....whales will definitely have the advantage. I'm not saying it's impossible to have fun and develop to endgame if you're f2p, but it's a damn chore that could take more than a year. If you're aiming to have all the best gear for just one character and you're f2p, then good luck. I'll check back in 10 years. 

Overall, this was a pretty good game but severely limited by terrible systems that any normal person would be annoyed by. The gear upgrade system is quite literally gambling, there is no other way to describe it. The only things that really keep people coming back is the beautiful graphics, combat and something I can only describe as a cross between sunk cost fallacy and stockholm syndrome. I.e. You spent too long with this game, invested too much, became attached(although you don't really know why) and now you're being held hostage and can't leave. It'll take quite a bit of willpower to drop it if you make it past a certain point, unless you got as mad as I did with the shitty systems and found better games to enjoy.

Did I mention that you'll also probably be running this game all day long? Yeah...the electricity bills aren't good...

If you read this far, you must really care about my opinion, or just don't have anything better to do. Either way, I'll end this with a simple question and answer. Do I recommend this game? 

Yea...nah, not really. If you got time to waste, go for it. If you like grinding, play this. If you hate rng progression, steer clear. If you're already in way too deep like I was, I commend you but also pity you. If you have more hours than I have(which there are likely many people), please tell me why.

Came back after a very long time, I wish there was a neutral opinion here since what I'm going to talk about are pretty much two completely different games. 

Seasonal is fun, well balanced, and progress is fast.  It feels very easy to reach max armor/weapons and in general just feels really good to play.  If this game was just the seasonal part this would be an easy recommend.

However there's the main game which suffers from horrible balance, buggy quests, buggy dungeons, most content seems to be geared to cater for late game players.  I was doing main story quests and got to Atoraxxian (I hope I spelled that right) and you cannot even queue for party members until you've cleared it once meaning you have to solo a party dungeon.  I just came back and know noone to drag along with me and tbh I was just enjoying doing my own thing with minimal interaction up till this point.  Bosses such as Karanda and Kutum have variants that seem to have extremely high gear reqs as well as even with full tet I tended to die fairly quickly even while doing mechanics.  Garmoth is still one of the most boring boss fights in the world which I was looking forward to being improved.  The plus side is life skilling in BDO is still good always has been.

TLDR: Personally I'd just play for seasonal/life skilling as most content in the actual game is catered to late game players.

I play MMO's for the style and the scale - not to be social.  This game is Solo-able and a lot of fun.  You can make several characters and they can work together to a degree (not in combat, obviously).  You have to actually play the combats out - like moving, attacking, performing crazy combos, etc.  Each class I've tried has been fun, though certainly some more capable as a solo than others.  The market place pushes for gear to be available to people even outside of a guild / team / gang / whatever.  I found the crafting to be enjoyable, as well as managing my workers and properties.  That's not end game either, you are crafting and possibly building your worker empire within the first couple of hours.  All optional of course, but in this game, in-game-money makes your character blitz through the fights...  which lessens the grind (or shifts it, depending on whether you watch your crafter work or minimize the game and get some sleep while they toil away).  I didn't upgrade my weapons - that system looked like a nightmare.  Just like in life - make your in-game-money however you like and buy the fruits of someone else's labor for the parts you don't like.  Then go stab something.

Anyway, it's a fun game and there's a ton of content before you get to end game.

Black Desert is an MMORPG game developed by Pearl Abyss and published on the Steam platform. Here is a game review for Black Desert:

Gameplay: Black Desert is a vast open-world game that allows players to explore, quest, and engage in combat. The game features a complex character customization system, allowing players to create a unique avatar that represents them in the game world. The game also features a variety of activities, including gathering resources, crafting items, and participating in large-scale PvP battles.

Graphics: Black Desert features some of the most impressive graphics in an MMORPG game, with detailed character models, beautifully rendered environments, and vibrant colors. The game also features a smooth and seamless transition between the overworld and instances, making it feel like a seamless experience.

Sound: The sound design in Black Desert is top-notch, with well-done ambient noises and sound effects that help to bring the game world to life. The game also features a good variety of music tracks that change based on the situation.

Replay Value: Black Desert has a lot of replay value, with a vast open-world to explore, a variety of activities to participate in, and a deep character customization system. The game also features a large number of events, quests, and PvP battles, making it a good choice for players who are looking for a long-term MMORPG experience.

Final Verdict: Black Desert is a highly impressive MMORPG game that is well worth playing. The game features stunning graphics, immersive sound design, and a vast open-world to explore. Overall, Black Desert is a must-play game for fans of MMORPGs and players who are looking for a deep and engaging gaming experience.

gud game.
After 100 hours of playing this game I realized that is is mainly a SOLO game. it has very little to offer in the way of coop. EXP is split in parties, punishing you for party grind.

This game relies on an out of date model of leaving yourself afk overnight to improve skills/earn money but sadly the connection quality of the servers makes it very hard to reliable leave yourself afk, even with a wired 1gb/s connection. If you leave yourself training your horse and you have a minor connection issue it will give you a loading screen and kick you off your horse. Then it puts your horse somewhere fairly far away from you and leaves it to be killed by enemies. Even grey enemies who do 10 dmg add up over time, especially afk over night. That combined with beyond insane failure rates for upgrading anything past duo just makes the game grind to a halt progressionwise. Its a fun game but it had potential to be amazing but like I said the progression system is designed to draw you in with quick leveling, but then you hit 50 and it slows down. 56 and you are starting to grind. By 60 you are going out for 25% an hour with 1300% exp increase.
The first 6500 hours were confusing, but these last 99 have been a blast once I figured out you can move with WASD!

RNG progression feels pretty bad but as long as you don't completely nolife the game there's plenty of pity systems to let you get by without it feeling too overbearing. Possible to P2W but difference is only obvious at very high end PvP, when PvE is the part of the game most people play. All in all, a very good casual-mid level gameplay experience (I play around 15 hours a week), but definitely exhausting if not outright miserable for most late-endgame players.

The game does a lot of things right in the MMO Genre, and breaks the mold in a lot of ways.

The combat is superb with actions that flow into each other, a hybrid between action based and targeting that still can be actively dodged by the player instead of based on a chance. Classes have lots of mobility and the abilities are easy to execute on their own with lots of different combinations possible that add complexity to the combos that you can do with them. Classes are easy to play, but hard to master. 

The world has a level of details and thought put into it that very few games can even match. The cities are unique and without repeated elements. Animations and abilities effects are one of kind for each one. The armor set details surpass those of any other game in the genre. The lore and voice acting in a lot of the quest lines is very immersing if that's what you are after. 

Professions or life skills as they are know in the game are very entertaining and a big part of the game, allowing each character to level all of them, with deep progression, usefulness and differences between them.

The downsides are that the game is heavily influence by Korean gaming philosophy with lots of chance and failure involved to progress beyond the novice level of the game, and with extreme temporary and costly convenience buffs that although occasionally obtainable through seasonal events, still make the experience very poor when playing the game without them. Classes are gender locked meaning that sometimes the class that you would play does not come in the gender you would like. Lastly, endgame content in PVE consists of killing the same world bosses that are little more than loot piñatas, killing packs of mobs in certain areas and pvp and life skills/professions. 

The challenge of the game is based on gearing up enough to get into more demanding mob areas and kill them faster, but there's barely any content in PVE that challenges your skill beyond the capacity to stick to grinding (killing mobs over and over)

Black Desert is a game that promises a lot but fails to deliver in many areas.
The graphics are impressive, but the game's environments and characters are often poorly optimized and can cause lag.
The game's story is poorly written and uninteresting, with characters that are not well developed.
The game's controls are clunky and unresponsive, making it difficult to perform actions.
The game's combat system is often unbalanced and can be frustrating for new players.
The game's developer's have not done much to address the game's issues and update the game.
The game's lack of tutorial and guidance can make it difficult for new players to understand the game mechanics.
Overall, I would not recommend Black Desert to anyone, there are far better games in the same genre that offer a more satisfying and polished experience.

Let me start by saying that visually, this game is awesome. I have a decent rig, so I can only imagine what the visuals would look like on rig with the latest specs. 

What I dislike about this game is that I spent 3 of my 4 hours trying to find a solution to why I can't advance in the Ancient Stone Chamber. Resorting to YouTube, I figured out that there was a cut scene event that never activated. Even upon completely quitting the game and relaunching didn't help (among other TS tactics). 
Unrelated to my main problem: I find it off putting that you can't completely customize your character and that they are locked into a class. For those that don't care about character creation, this would be fine. I personally enjoy spending time creating a character that'll I'll connect to another world with. That immersion doesn't exist for me in this game.

Assuming you can avoid glitches like the one I encountered, the game seems like it will be fun. 

I may edit my review after another run with a new character. 

Edit: Glitch didn't happen the second time around. After completing the tutorial quests and finally getting to explore, the game really takes shape and drops you into a vibrant world. Some things are confusing at first such as housing, storage, and what the bank is actually for. For those of you who decide to become a merchant, good luck to you. Like every game as of late, they really like to push their premium shop so just a heads up there.
As of this writing the game is $10 and not a bad price to take a shot.
