This is a game you will either love or hate. Myself, I have a love/hate relationship with it. I'm new to Steam, but have played the game in another venue since beta. I've literally seen every point in it's evolvement into what it is now. 
At the time it was by far the most incredibly beautiful game out there. It still is among the best n terms of graphics. PA's game engine was brilliantly executed and is proprietary. The combat is engaging, complex, and stirring. Travel by means of mounts keeps the player engaged in the constantly changing environments of the the huge map. There is land and sea content that are basically two different worlds in terms of game play. Dungeons are finally in the game after some five years without them, though they tend to favor elite players. 
I've essentially moved on to FFXIV at this point and have tried to quit BDO many times. But I just can't.
For al of it's greatness, BDO is deeply flawed. These flaws are mainly connected with its gear system. It's among the worst I've ever experienced. It revolves around an RNG scenario that promises numerous falured to obtain the best gear. And those failures are almost always always costly. Ocean content is glitchy and can create some difficult scenarios when they occur. This is obviously a difficult area for PA to address, since there have been marginal improvements over time, but there is a fundamental issue with it's implementation that will require a huge revamping of it to fix. As for its story and lore, it is much better now, but fitting it feels like it was something they had to develop and there was no real creative drive behind it.
Life skills are pretty well developed but are average for a game this size.
Comparing this game to FFXIV, my current game, I'm finding the gear system to be far superior. When you clear the content, you get the gear. Period. FF is story driven and is a masterpiece of storytelling. Gathering and crafting are a deep and well thought out journey. 
All that aside, I highly recommend BDO to anyone who enjoys a great combat system, beautiful graphics, a somewhat supportive community (though a bit toxic on occasion), and determination to work through it's flaws (it's worth it, believe me).

It took me less than 4 hours to realize how broken the monetization is.
Do not take it seriously, by any cost do not even try to compete if you're unwilling to throw a lot of cash out the window for some pixels on the screen.

That being said -- good combat, good graphics, interesting classes (too many for no reason) -- however it does not feel like a literal MMO, it is quite short-sighted, feels very repetitive with the amount of grinding for specific, bland items; might as well call it a Power Level Simulator.
Also lacks a social aspect as far as I'm concerned.
That is my impression for having played for less than four hours, that's the most I was able to unfortunately, maybe others will find the aspects that I found to be negatives likable, but as far as I'm concerned, this is not for me, and I'd assume it's not for many others alike.

It's a better Neverwinter Online. It's mortal kombat style combat in an mmo - though you can also assign abilities to a quickbar, it's much more enjoyable (and versatile) to learn how to combine your combos. to deal the most damage in any given situation. That same style is also applied to spellcasters, and it's done very well. While there used to be much fewer classes, there is now a plethora that allows you to pick just about any combat style you can think of in a fantasy universe. The story is a lot clearer now than it was when Black Desert first came out, and most of it is even fairly enjoyable to listen to (the main questlines have voiced lines for the most part). There are also certain choices of quest paths that you want to take, so there is a little bit of that "rp" from the "mmorpg", something most mmo's now forgo entirely. It also allows you to do a plethora of non-combat things that go rather deep in complexity the more you play. The housing system allows you to specialize your houses for storage, and there are even services that allow you to move items between cities without having to go all the way back and forth yourself. It's a very well thought out game, but the in-game shop is about as predatory as they come. Nothing from it seems required, at least 10 hours in, and after browsing the premium shop for a bit, it seems it's mostly cosmetics and convenience. Just be careful that convenience doesn't find itself too convenient for you, or you might end up spending a whole lot of money - there are a lot of different resources you can purchase with real money. Also, a lot of things you do are tied to your "family" (sort of a Legacy system if you've played SWTOR), as opposed to your character, which makes the game very alt-friendly.

Edit: More playtime.

I first gave this a game a try when it just came out and was a standalone client back in 2015. It didn't grip me back then, but with all the changes they've made since I decided to try it again and I can honestly say it feels like an entirely different game when you give it enough of a chance.

Unlike most other MMORPG's, the game has a lot more of a focus on professions (Life Skills) to the point where it comprises of the entire end-game content and feels more like another world in a sense. Because there's far too much to do, you're forced to specialise in certain areas (as opposed to completing everything a game offers, which would put most players off in this game as it can be very overwhelming) which makes it more of a "Choose Your Own Adventure"; personally I think that gives it a lot of appeal. The new Maegu class is also very fun with great combat flow, though I'm sure other classes have similar perks to make them enjoyable.

If you're like me and played BDO a long time ago (or not at all), consider giving it a fair go. You might find it has everything you've been wanting to experience in an MMO.

Had a really bad experience with this game. (You can skip to the 2nd paragraph)

Black Desert is my first MMORPG game. Originally I was going for New World but they have no server in Asia and I got an unplayable 300+ ping. Ok, fine, let's go for Black Desert. The reason why I didn't go for Black Desert in the first place was that I was skeptical with Korean game companies. I also don't like those cheesy Asian style 3D graphics like in those Chinese RPG games. I really prefer American style graphics.

So I got into the game, the graphics was better than I thought, great. Kept playing, felt good. UI, systems and items are certainly too complicated for a newbie but with explanations here and there, I could managed it. I continued with the main quest for 5 hours and then I got stuck at the "Black Desert and Black Stones" quest (around 1/3 in the Balenos line). Then I spent another 4-5 hours trying to figure out if I missed anything. Then I found a walkthrough video on YouTube and figured out I almost certainly encountered a bug. Seriously? Treat a 5-hour old MMORPG newbie with a main quest bug? If it is with a side quest, it would have been better but now the game is pretty much unplayable. Ya, old time folks can say I can still do a lot in the game but remember I am a newbie, there are so much I haven't learned and didn't know that finishing the main quest would benefit much. I have already submitted a bug report and would like to see how quick they will response.

I may change this review depending on how quick and well the developers respond.

==Update==
The support answered my question after around 2 days. They correctly identified that I did not talk to the right "person". After reviewing two more YouTube walkthroughs, I found out that I have to "talk" to the church instead of the priest. What the heck? The UI is confusing enough. At least change to action to "listen" instead of "talk". Okay fine, I update my review and change it to "recommend". Would give the game 5.5/10 for the painfully confusing UI.

Black Desert is a highly popular anime/fantasy themed Korean MMORPG set in a somewhat generic fantasy world.  The MMORPG is heavily developed with expansive content as well as user activity, with farming, sailing, horse training, all the usual gamut of tradeskills, PvE and PvP content available to all players.

As a Korean MMORPG, you may find advancement in the game is gated by a very significant requirement to grind... however that's par for the course for MMORPGs, I think anyone who decides to dedicate a lot of time to one knows exactly what they're getting into. 

One of the drawcards for the game is the proprietary game engine with a solid reputation for high quality visuals and performance, and Black Desert doesn't disappoint.  You get 4K graphics support and a wide array of customisations and tweaks to ensure the game will run comfortably on any gaming rig.

Given how many hours of gameplay you get for a relatively low entry price, as well as the lack of paygating for content, this isn't a bad investment.  I can't suggest anyone pays additional money for the additional boosts, microtransactions etc etc... but you don't need to.  You can get dozens, if not hundreds of hours for the basic game package.  MMORPG fans should definitely consider this game when on sale or in a bundle.

- ENHANCEMENT SYSTEM
Once you spend a lot of hrs grinding PVE in order to buy weapons, armor, accessory from the Central Market in game, you have to deal with the enhancement system and [b] FAIL [/b] 90% of the time due to a [b] VERY LOW [/b] percentage of succeeding (no matter how many items you use in order to increase enhancement percentage). I am a 149 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently rode his bike across the tarmac of an airforce field and got run over by a f18, as i was cleaning our his room i found this game on his laptop. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play in his memory. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. at that moment my sons ghost appeared and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since he had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well haunting nursing homes and waffle houses. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories, i never thought i would say it but im so glad his ghost found his way from the afterlife back to me.

Black Desert is something else in the MMO market. While I cannot argue for flawlessness or anything exceptionally striking in the game, beyond a considerable character customization option, it definitely sticks its foot forward in regards to combat. While I have lent time to Vindictus, the combat there feels slow and unremarkable. Black Desert is faster paced and feels a slight more streamlined. The quests themselves are fairly stereotypical, the grind is exceptionally long, and upgrades take some time. If you're looking for a time sink, or even a game to play in sporadic bursts, BDO can be an excellent option.

EDIT: Don't even bother with Tuvala Gear at all, literally not worth the trouble.

The game allows you to peacefully collect resources and craft, as well as having fast-paced combat with multiple engaging skills. I have enjoyed both aspects so far and I feel this game is worth a try if you're debating purchasing it.

That being said if you like really getting lost in a game and think spending hours, days, months, possibly years in a game to grind & level is interesting then this might possibly be the game for you. There is literally tons of content in this game, multiple job classes, a housing system, crafting, markets, etc that you can totally lose yourself (and contact with family members if that's what you want to do). The community can be extremely toxic unless you devote time to crafting your own gear and leveling your own characters to max. I decided this was no longer for me, I got out and I will not return--ever.

Update for 2023: They made the game pretty good for new/returning players. I have recently came back about 3-4 weeks ago and I am enjoying my time again. You can easily catch up to softcap gear with the amount of free stuff they give you. You can get free two pen accessories (with a bit of grind 90 days+) and a free pen boss armor piece which I recommend going for rednose or giath when you do the magnus quest.

A lot of people say this game is p2w. And while yes, you can spend money for enhancement materials, it is very much play at your own pace. The stuff you'll spend money on in this game are things for convenience.

I like to say this game costs $20 instead of being free ( you can get this game for free or for a dollar for half of the year ) as you will have to purchase a tent buff. However, if you spend $60 on the in-game cash shop currency during a 2x pearl deal which they usually have around ~4 times a year, you can cover everything you need for convenience. $60 for this game is very worth it. 

There's a massive amount of things to do in game. The core gameplay is grinding though one way or another. If you don't enjoy grinding you may not enjoy this game. However if you don't care too much about gear gains that won't really be an issue. It's a sandbox MMO so you're basically free to do whatever you want. You can hit up a lot of the games' grindspots after a week of gameplay. The game is what you make of it really.

If you're looking for an MMO with cool customization and a gradual learning curve, this is it. I find most MMOs bombard you with crafting, blacksmithing, cooking, etc etc, way too fast. This one is pretty balanced so far. Tutorials for a noob like me are also pretty straight forward and it'd be hard to get lost.

Only critique so far is, there's a lot of boring dialogue early on.

-----------------------------
Upon further Reflection
---------
The best explanation for BLACK DESERT ONLINE... The game designers sat down in a room and looked at every system in an MMO and asked the question "How can we make that system as complex and rewarding as possible". This is the most fulfilling MMO to play for sheer content and true dynamic system complexity. 
When the game dropped the story was terrible and you had the black spirit constantly yelling at you to complete the story, which you didn't want to play. So he never stopped yelling XD. Now he no longer talks outside of conversations you initiate and the story actually has some depth to it. 
New players need to remember this is not a Completion Based MMO. You don't rush the end game in BDO, because the end game is not obtainable (so don't spend real money on the in-game shop), there is a soft end game but this MMO is constantly moving and mainly focuses on Character and Family Building. 
The creators of this MMO are HUGE FAN'S of the Aincrad Arc in Sword Art Online. They wanted to develop a game that gives you access to 5 years worth of content immediately with each system qualifying as a separate game in its own right (PVP, Guild, Life Skilling, Worker Empire Building, Markets, Knowledge Seekers, Player Housing....etc).
I wish someone would have told me this when I started BDO because if you look at this game like other MMOs or RPGs here is what you get. 
The feeling of being overwhelmed because there is too much content ((where do I start, how can I possibly do everything) (especially if you are coming from MMOs or RPGs that path-follow)), the struggle with every system being too complex (why can’t I figure out how to PVP, LifeSkill, Player housing…etc (all I am doing is reading/watching walkthroughs), the fear of being left out (It takes too long to master PVP, LifeSkill, Player housing…etc (what if halfway to mastery my friends or I want to do something else (this game makes me think about my own real-life path, I am unsure). 
So, to enjoy this game take your time, don’t rush, and embrace the complexity of each system as you learn them. Much like taking steps along your real-life path from School to work and finally a family or empire, remember neither is built in a day.

Fluid combat, massive open world, beautiful graphics (if your PC is capable of running them on remastered) and a lot of key features that are proven concepts to work for MMORPGS.
Overall, Black Desert is easy to immerse yourself in & the only real downside in my opinion is how much of a cash grab it can be to get the items you want. Also economy is fixed and steadily monitored so impossible to game the market. However despite all that being said you can still grind for things without having to spend any money and that's not something common within most MMORPG'S nowadays.

BDO's chief problem heading into 2023 is - ironically for an MMO, a general lack of encouraging people to actually play with one other. But unlike many other contemporaries today it's not due to a reliance on being narrative-driven or anything (especially for a game known to have some of the worst questing), but it's that grinding mobs solo is more than sufficient in reward while having the convenience of being mostly independent, outside of using the marketplace.

The act of grinding mobs in itself isn't bad at all and the devs have made sure to make a lot more zones viable, but every other part of BDO is feeling a lot less relevant when a mid-game player can make 300-500m+ worth of silver easily without much risk of being PK'd if at all. Older systems in the game that were formerly more important in the past such as the worker system also matter a lot less. The developers can add in as many journals or questlines as they want but they are just temporary distractions.

To the game's credit, it has seen a [i]lot[/i] of good QoL tweaks and other changes in the past several years, and the 'need' for going AFK overnight is nowhere near as strong depending on what it is you're doing. But many older problems such as the notorious enhancement system, cash shop, and higher FPS = faster combos still exist however subdued or mitigated they might be, and the current direction of the game sees newer ones like the sheer bloat in class count and legacy systems becoming irrelevant as mentioned before.

I would probably give a neutral rating if it were possible but even during a season (which a new player should be doing) it's hard to sell someone on Black Desert already especially when arbitrary self-goals are all I've got to go off. Having an MMO where you actually have to get around the game world without fast travel (Magnus travel costs are not insignificant) on top of having interesting combat systems and some side activities with their own mechanics do all sound nice on paper, but the game is now much more of a mob grinder first (and trying out things in advance for DokeV second) than it used to be and what there is of an endgame is not worth the trouble.

This game is pretty addictive.  Very nicely done.  I've read all the negatives, but jumping in and investing in a lot of characters (pay for those pearls), I still feel I'm going to get a lot of playing time out of this one.

It takes a little time to get comfortable with the UI, but it really is a very flexible one.  Well, mostly.  Why do these developers hate "walking".  I play with controller, and overall it is really nicely done, except there is no walk.  Yea, I know you can toggle walk with emotes (at least last update, mine disappeared), but it is ridiculously done, you toggle walk on, your controller stick only controls direction, you never stop till you toggle off.  Come one.  Pearl Abyss can't develop controller stick support better than that?  Give us proper controller stick support which walks with slight movement and runs at greater movement, as 95% games out there.  Worried about effect on combat, then toggle it no walk in combat.  Geez.  I have to crouch to move more slowly, or draw my weapons to move a little slower.  It just makes the controller support look very sloppy.  But overall, I like what they have done with the D-pad, ring configuration, etc.  Nicely done except for WALK!

But I digress from why this is a positive review.  This game looks great, it is fun to play (once you get used to AI), and yes, it is a pay store money grab, but there is a lot going for this game.  I don't regret spending money on it, it is mostly worth it.  I just wish I could just stroll and enjoy the scenery once in awhile instead of this zipping around like there is no tomorrow.

i hate niggers

I truly loved playing this game, but ever since Pearl Abyss took over publication and hosting for North America, it has been virtually impossible to get the support teams or the developers to respond quickly to serious problems with both the game systems and the community at large. They'll tackle anything that's easy, they'll complete any passion project or content expansion that they can throw into the game whether or not it turns out polished enough, but they won't ever fix the big ticket items that can easily ruin the experience for you. All it takes for this game to lose all value is one psycho that decides it's their personal mission to not let you play normally anymore. So I can't recommend this game to any of my friends anymore because I know far too many other players have all met more than one random psycho that doesn't let them play the game normally.

It's not that the players don't report the issues, or that the staff don't see and acknowledge them as issues, or that they don't have the means to address the issues effectively within their own policies. They do try some of the time, but their solutions to community problems are often too little, too late, or temporary fixes that eventually break again and are then ignored indefinitely. Streamers get banned for using boosting pilot programs, but the majority of the siege community does it out of necessity to stay competitive against other players doing it. Those streamers come back a few months later and are welcomed back as free publicity.

Toxic players that are permanently chat banned for saying atrocious things to people are left to run amok disrupting general gameplay afterward, instead of getting service revoked at the next sign of trouble. Chat bans somehow actually make it more difficult for support to gather evidence for reports, despite those bans themselves being clear evidence of prior negative behavior. Targeted harassment is brushed off as random PKing because it is easier for support to find the first article that applies to a ticket that lets them reject it, rather than address user complaints from every possible angle and make a judgment call after thorough review. Any toxicity that players endure is considered the responsibility of the victims rather than the fault of perpetrators, and players get away with harassing or stalking people for months on end with no serious response beyond "We'll look into it, but we can't say anything" or "this functional use of the system is possible, so it is technically not an exploit or disruption".

Victims of harassment, stalking, one-sided PVP griefing, theft, impersonation, and other hateful conduct are forced to take avoidant measures until the last measure available is quitting the game entirely. The problem with their operational policy is that they have very explicit terms about the extent to which they can punish disruptive, toxic, and hateful players, down to the level of individual and permanent hardware and IP bans. Instead of taking action to correct course for the community, they waffle about any of those kinds of issues until the players asking for help will simply choose to quit the game instead of being ignored again. There are a few good eggs left working for the NA offices, but it's clear that when they try to help their player base they are brushed off by higher-ups in favor of pushing sales or hyping up temporary content or sticking to the intended release schedules.

The newly revamped crystal system was a perfect opportunity to address players' ongoing complaint that the PVE death crystal shattering is more often a punishment issued to victims of desync, server problems, or PVP griefing in PVE zones, than it is to players who bit off more than they could chew while they were grinding. Instead of snowballing the crystal slot and storage changes into a full crystal system overhaul and letting Positive Karma remove PVE crystal breakage outright under the new system, they half-assed it and gave you a bag for your crystals and some presets to switch them. PVP griefers now have the ability to unequip all of their crystals on the fly, stunlock you in a pile of endgame monsters, and let the monsters kill you so all of your crystals break as a PVE death punishment. Despite the cause being obviously tied to PVP, there is no lockout or protection system in place.

Mechanically, the quality of life has been steadily rising, a lot of bugs, exploits, and general inconveniences have been fixed. However, the NA community's quality of life has been completely destroyed by toxic players' behavior going unpunished. The karma systems are archaic despite naval karma being relatively new, and karma mostly serves to encourage good behavior by having no penalty rather than providing benefit. Negative karma can also randomly and excessively punish the occasional slip-up for players that are normally in positive standing. But there are die-hard perma-red griefers for whom the system is a minor inconvenience at best, and remains a reason that they choose to permanently take out their anger on the community at large at worst. Players have been asking for an update to the guild storage system for years due to a handful of thieves randomly dumping entire guild storage banks and destroying all of the other players' hard earned items in an instant.

The players responsible for various exploits have often been named and shamed, with dozens of reports, dozens of support tickets, dozens posts on the community feedback forums, the community is doing all that it can to insulate and protect itself from toxic behavior. But the developers choose not to update the system to prevent the abuse, choose to tell us that we're not doing enough to avoid the toxicity, and choose not to punish the perpetrators effectively, so the problems will never stop occurring. The same can be said for a dozen of the older systemic issues that have not been addressed, and will continue to be exploited by bad actors until the company chooses to remove those bad actors, in addition to updating the systems. The player base certainly has no more faith that the systems themselves will be revamped to a satisfactory degree, so it's up to the developers and support team to actually clean up the community if they want to retain their players.

Worst designed game I've played in a long time. I've spent some time with trash Korean MMOs and I understand that there's a culture/language barrier at play, but it just feels like a fever dream. Nothing makes sense or is explained properly. It's totally chaotic. The UI at the beginning makes you feel like you're going to have a fit. The stories are bizarre, disjointed and the english translations are so weird I can't tell if it's because the translation is wrong or if my mind just works differently from an asian mind. I can see the English words make grammatical sense (a decent amount of the time at least) but after hearing a couple of sentences I'm thinking, "What the  hell was that?!". It's like a scattering of random ideas. The animation is VERY asian and so is VERY over the top with ridiculous voice acting sighs and gasps to fill the space (I had to add Korean language with english subtitles because the english voice acting is even more cheap and jarring). If you like cheap manga then you'll love this, but fuck me, I'd like at least something rational, logical and sensible to give this game some grounding so I don't feel like I'm losing my mind. Never before have I played an MMO where I feel I'm pushing through to get to a point where I can understand and enjoy the game. Every other MMO I've played that journey is somewhat enjoyable, but with BDO I'm just intensely irritated with how bad the storyline, animation (cut scenes I mean, the combat animations are cool) and game design are. I got this on sale for less than a dollar and I don't think it was worth it.

  Compared to "grinding" in MapleStory, Lost Ark, WoW etc., BDO grinding is more interactive. Skill rotations, positioning, 
  pulling is more necessary than simply "I press button, every mob goes boom".

I won't go into enhancement and PvP because those topics are subjective. SEA Server is absolute dogshit and I'd like to sue the South East Asia Developers for giving us only 11 channels when EU has 20+ channels. Every other server is fine, and I'd recommend this if you're looking for the best "non-raid, full grinder" MMO currently.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Pure poo. 

Even if it wasnt a struggle to get this game to work right from the start, with abysmal configuration menu that completely FUBAR's your setup, dosent save it so you have to input in the same changes every time you load, and even alters your systems setup video information to add icing on that cake, I would rate this at less then ZERO. Some aspects of the setup menu you cant even save until you reach a certain level? What genius came up with that? 

The game is HIGHLY monetized and advertised to money grab you right out of the gate, they dont even have the decency to wait until end game to dig their hands right into your pockets. Ads for buffs and upgrades are all over your screen as soon as you finish the intro vid. 

The combat system is garbage IMHO, half of the skills you can add to a hotbar, the rest just float somewhere and you can only utilize them through hotkeys or combos. Remapping these is impossible so you cant even come up with a method other then the default to soften the agony of learning all of these ridiculous key shortcuts. -Note some of the actual KEYS in the shortcuts you can remap, however, you cannot change the sequence or shorten it to something you feel is less annoying. 

NPC interaction is laughable with over-animated NPC's waiving their arms around like they are swatting flies during conversations, and some dont even move their lips as they talk. Graphics are so-so nothing to really awe over and I would say average at best. 

The lore and storyline is drab and boring, painfully obvious that it was thrown in just so the devs can claim its there. 

Dont be fooled by the base cost of the game even if its only a dollar you will most likely feel ripped off after just a few hours of gameplay. The game was engineered to suck money out of your wallet and dosent offer much else. If you really want to grind mobs and thats your thing, your better off with a decent map clearing game like Diablo or POE. 

Leave this in the toilet where it came from.

If you respect your time at all, don't play this game. 
A never ending hamster wheel that feeds off your time, money and dopamine.
Play a better game, not even necessarily an MMO.

I played this game for 50 hours a few months ago running around as Kunoichi since I was a major WaifuHunter #42,017 and I've gotta say, this game takes too much time for me who has to work hourly wage. Look, I'm sorry blessed weaboos with kind parents paying for your rent, cooking your food, paying your car, I am sorry. I gotta pay $600 rent, another $500 for my cars, and about lets say $200-300 worth of ingredients for keeping myself fed each month. I'm barely making $2k a month for a 19 year old such as myself. I really can't fathom taking this game Seriously. I saw real good potential in this game but the true grind is basically someones lifetime. Maybe one day, I'll come back to see this game and dedicate time into it if I became a "Work-At-Home" kinda guy with stable income. In the meantime I say this: "All sane people and Normies avoid this game at all times. Unless you're a YouTuber or Twitch Streamer of course."
